business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER(Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House grants leave for the Votes and Proceedings of the House of Representatives for 10 November 1998 (No. 1 of 1998-99) to be produced in the Melbourne Magistrates Court, and in any subsequent proceedings, in respect of the Member for Calwell.

This motion is intended to grant a request conveyed to the House yesterday for leave to produce Votes and Proceedings of the House for the opening day of the parliament. The document is being made available in relation to committal proceedings in the Melbourne Magistrates Court and in any subsequent proceedings in respect of the member for Calwell. I am advised that there is some judicial authority for the view that the permission of the House is not required on the production of parliamentary records. This is essentially a procedural question. However, the House has never formally abandoned the position that permission should be sought, which is why this motion has been moved.

The substantive question of the use to which House records can be put is not affected. They may be used to establish a certain fact: for example, that a writ was returned endorsing the election of a member and that the member completed the constitutional requirement of oath or affirmation of allegiance. However, they cannot be questioned in any way. If the House grants the request for leave, it will be acting in full accordance with precedent. I have briefly discussed this matter with the Manager of Opposition Business and I understand that there are no objections to the course of action being proposed this morning. It is essentially a procedural, technical matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 is to introduce new measures for sustainable management of fisheries, in particular new powers, offences and sanctions to ensure compliance with fisheries management measures.

The Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 consists of two schedules. Schedule 1 relates to new forfeiture and enforcement powers to combat illegal foreign fishing. These measures are aimed at ensuring more effective fisheries surveillance and enforcement within the Australian fishing zone. Schedule 2 relates to implementing obligations necessary to ratify an international agreement termed the fish stocks agreement. The full title is the Agreement for the Implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982 relating to the Conservation and Management of Straddling Fish Stocks and Highly Migratory Fish Stocks. Is it any wonder it is shortened to fish stocks agreement!

Both schedules of the bill address the growing issue of illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing. Illegal fishing occurs when foreign fishing vessels operate within the Australian fishing zone without authorisation. Unregulated and unreported fishing occurs on the high seas where fisheries management arrangements, established to manage particular stocks, are ignored. This is despite the duties countries have under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea to cooperate to implement management measures under such arrangements.

There is rising concern over the ongoing activities of illegal foreign fishing vessels in the Australian fishing zone, particularly in remote areas of the zone such as our sub-Antarctic territories and off north-western Australia. Australia's sovereign right to manage the fish resources in these areas is challenged by such activities, and the government is determined to take stern measures to deter illegal foreign fishing in the Australian fishing zone. In the sub-Antarctic, illegal fishing and fishing occurring outside management regimes established by the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources costs the Australian industry potentially tens of millions of dollars per year in terms of fish stolen. It also undermines cooperative management under the commission and poses a threat to the Antarctic treaty system itself.

Illegal fishers, particularly those in the sub-Antarctic, are highly organised and adaptable operators chasing very valuable fish in extremely harsh conditions. Penalties for illegal foreign fishing are proposed to be doubled, recognising the high value of such fisheries to Australia, the large profits to be made by illegal operators and the high costs of enforcement. An amendment is also proposed to overcome the problems with enforcement action experienced following the apprehension of the Aliza Glacial, caught illegally fishing within the Australian fishing zone around Heard Island. In that case, a third party, who was the mortgagee of the vessel, successfully intervened to assert the primacy of its interest in the vessel under the Admiralty Act 1988 over enforcement action by the Commonwealth. The amendment makes clear that third party interests will not prevail over Commonwealth enforcement action by virtue of the Admiralty Act.
Amendments under schedule 1 will provide for a more effective catch, gear and boat forfeiture scheme to deter illegal foreign fishing in the Australian fishing zone.

Australian fisheries officers will be able to seize foreign boats, fishing gear or catch which have been automatically forfeited to the Commonwealth as a result of illegal fishing in the Australian fishing zone. The onus will then fall to the illegal foreign fishers to establish their legitimacy for being present in the Australian fishing zone without authorisation. The amendments implement the international law principle of constructive presence. This enables action, outside the Australian fishing zone, against mother ships that support illegal foreign fishers within the Australian fishing zone.

Other amendments will provide fisheries officers with explicit powers to use reasonable force when requiring a boat to stop consistent with international law to apprehend foreign boats suspected of illegal fishing. Such force could include firing at or into a ship after appropriate warning shots have been fired and using devices to stop propulsion of the boat.
The amendments to implement the fish stocks agreement, contained in schedule 2, will provide a framework to address the wider problem of unregulated and unreported fishing on the high seas.

Unsustainable fishing on the high seas directly impacts the sustainability of stocks on which our domestic industry relies. In the Australian context, highly migratory fish stocks include stocks that migrate through our fishing zone, such as southern bluefin tuna and other tuna and billfish species. Straddling stocks include stocks that straddle the boundary of our fishing zone and the high seas adjacent to it, such as orange roughy and in some cases the patagonian toothfish. The value of these species to the Australian economy in 1999 is expected to be over $250 million.

The fish stocks agreement was drafted out of international concern for the sustainability of these straddling fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks. The objective of the fish stocks agreement is to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of these fish stocks. Australia signed the agreement when it was first opened for signature in 1995. The amendments being introduced will enable Australia to enjoy the rights under the agreement and also meet its obligations.

Australia is a world leader in sustainable fisheries management and manages its fisheries in accordance with contemporary fisheries management principles, such as the precautionary principle and ecologically sustainable development. The fish stocks agreement will strengthen the application of these principles, in particular by requiring stock specific reference points to be determined for highly migratory and straddling stocks. The bill will amend fisheries management legislation to require stock specific reference points to be set out in fisheries management plans.

The agreement provides a framework for strengthened cooperation between nations to manage and conserve these stocks by establishing regional fisheries management organisations or similar arrangements. The objectives of fisheries management legislation will be amended to reflect these international obligations.

Ratification of the fish stocks agreement by Australia and participation in regional fisheries organisations will help secure a share to fish resources both within and outside the Australian fishing zone. The regional fisheries organisations will be responsible for devising cooperative measures to conserve and manage the relevant regional stocks. The regime will be legally binding on member countries who will be required to abide by these measures or refrain from participating in the fisheries. Member countries will have rights to enforce these measures on the other parties to the agreement. The amendments will enable Australian fisheries officers to board and inspect fishing vessels on the high seas to check compliance with regionally agreed management and conservation measures.

Once the agreement comes into force members will be required to take on flag state responsibility for vessels carrying its flag. This responsibility will involve regulating the activities of that vessel to ensure it operates in accordance with the principles of the agreement and any regional conservation and management measures. The amendments will expand the application of fisheries management legislation to the high seas in order to fulfil this obligation. The amendments will require the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to authorise Australian vessels to fish on the high seas and impose and monitor the necessary conditions for compliance with any conservation and management measures.
I commend the legislation to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kelvin Thomson) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT) BILL (No. 1) 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Costello:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Crean moved by way of amendment:
"That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House calls on the Government not to proceed with the bill until:
(1) the final report of the Ralph Committee, except for market sensitive information, has been released by the Government;
(2) full consultations have been undertaken with relevant stakeholders regarding the report's proposals; and

(3) matters directly related to this legislation (namely the reporting requirements of PAYG withholders to the Taxation Office which are critical to the proper evaluation of this legislation and are to be included in subsequent legislation) are before the House, so that the House can evaluate the full effects of this bill."

talk.start.para: —In summarising the remarks I made on the A New Tax System (Taxation Laws Amendment) Bill (No. 1) 1999 last night, I would just add some further comments in response to the words of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and also those of the member for Rankin. They both express concern that the new withholding arrangements, and especially the abolition of the prescribed payments system, will encourage the growth of so-called dependent contractors who only work for one organisation. I am advised that the pay-as-you-go withholding provisions are not specifically designed to deal with those contractors. The main issues involved with those contractors are primary liability issues, whereas this bill is about collection issues.

speech.para: Secondly, withholding will not generally apply to payments to contractors. The reason for this is that contractors generally will be charging GST on their services. The government considers that it would be too great a burden for business if both GST and withholding generally were applied to these transactions. It is no surprise that the Labor Party should be pushing that line. The third point, however, is that businesses generally will be required to withhold at the top marginal tax rate from payments to contractors who fail to quote their Australian business number in an invoice. So this measure is designed to prevent tax evasion where payments are made in cash.

Labour hire workers will not be treated like other contractors. A labour hire firm will have to withhold payments to workers for work performed for the client of the labour hire firm. The payment to the worker will not attract GST. As the honourable member noted, these arrangements will address any competitive advantage that labour hire workers have over traditional employees. Finally, we will be rejecting the Labor Party's amendment to this bill.
Mr Emerson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It comes as no surprise, I am sure, to members of the opposition because we read in today's paper that only yesterday the Leader of the Opposition was boasting to his party room about how good it is to be performing in sideshow alley for the Labor Party—how good it is for the Labor Party to be operating outside the mainstream debate in Australian politics. That is intriguing logic. It is great to be here in the fun park, but it is even better to operate a big stall in sideshow alley rather than to be in the main performance arena where the coalition and the Democrats are getting on with the job. That is intriguing leadership and intriguing commonsense.

speech.para: You can only wonder what sort of logic is going through the office of the Leader of the Opposition. I would have speculated that when Michael Costello joined that office he would have added a new dimension to the thinking in the office. Obviously, one or other of two events is occurring. He has no influ ence as the Leader of the Opposition's chief of staff or, alternately, his political antennae are not online at the moment. I will give him the benefit of the doubt. But the Leader of the Opposition is well experienced in this place, so I am surprised that he should say, `It is great to be operating out in the sidecar and let's leave the driving of the motorbike to the coalition and the Democrats.'
Mr Emerson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Rankin knows better than he does.

—Here we have another example of Labor Party guff when they talk about delaying this bill until Ralph comes into play. The recommendations of the Ralph committee are being considered and are going through due process within the coalition and the government—which is appropriate—but why is it that, even at the time of death's doorknock, the Labor Party continue to push hard on ANTS? Why is it that they continue to oppose to the very end every single initiative of the government in relation to ANTS after the substantive bills have been passed by the Senate and the House of Representatives? It is because they are trying to get some relevancy back into their politics. It is a shameful exercise in political expediency and they will be judged very harshly for it.

speech.para: We say that this bill has no relevance to the business taxation review occurring at the moment. We are focusing on getting on with the job of implementing ANTS and we will take the next step as and when appropriate in relation to business taxation. But, yet again, even in this House—and I heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's words on this—the opposition want to be dealt into Ralph and business taxation, in the same way that they wanted to be dealt into the Telstra privatisation debate, the workplace relations and reform program, the new taxation system that went through the parliament and the statement of reconciliation made by this House quite recently.

Why is it that on every single issue the Labor Party is choosing to take an alternate track and is finding that that alternate track leads to a dead-end? I will tell you why: because there is no strategic thinking. The Labor Party has been intellectually lazy since the 1996 election and any dissenting opinion in the Labor Party is expressed but not dealt with by the Leader of the Opposition. If you are going to pretend to be an alternate government, you have to have the intellectual debates about policy and not simply choose the expedient political path which the Labor Party continues to choose at every single hard option.
Mr Emerson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It says a lot about the Labor Party at the moment. I can only speculate that the Labor Party have not yet gone through their cathartic experience in relation to policy development that each opposition should go through, and it is a reflection on people of good intellect. And I will say here, in due deference to the members in the house, that the member for Rankin and the member for Wills do possess good intellects. They do their research and the hard work, and they do bend the elbow in policy debates, but why is it that the Labor Party policies of the 1950s have overtaken the Labor Party policies of the 21st century? Why is it? It is a form of recidivism. They have gone back to gaol. They have not yet come out of the 1950s, and this bill is an example of the sort of guffaw that the Labor Party continues to put before the House—yet again, a senseless motion about an alternative system and an irrelevant point about the relationship to business taxation review. The government rejects it and is getting on with the job at hand. We are about delivering good policy and we will continue to oppose the Labor Party's games. (Time expired)

speech.para: Mr Emerson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Rankin has been persistently reminded by the chair of the obligations he has under the standing orders. His continual interjections therefore reflect on the chair and not on the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation.

interjection.para: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Crean's amendment) stand part of the question.

para.inline: Voting details are recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

interjection.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 1, page 1 (lines 5 to 7), omit the clause, substitute:
This Act may be cited as the A New Tax System (Pay As You Go) Act 1999 .
I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —I express some concern on behalf of the opposition that this amendment has been circulated to us without the opportunity for us to consider it through our usual processes. The amendment changes the title of the bill from the A New Tax System (Taxation Laws Amendment) Bill (No. 1) 1999 to the A New Tax System (Pay As You Go) Bill. We wonder what the government's motivation is for changing the title. Perhaps they want to get away from numbering the amendments to a new tax system because otherwise we might end up with taxation laws amendment No. 50 or No. 100 in due course.

speech.para: The shadow Treasurer suggested that rather than being referred to as the A New Tax System (Pay As You Go) Bill it might better be referred to as the `A New Tax System (Pay Through The Nose) Bill'. In my own contribution to the debate, I pointed out that contained within this piece of legislation there were no fewer than seven different types of tax. There was reference to notional tax, adjusted tax, adjusted assessed tax, GDP adjusted notional tax, adjusted taxable income, adjusted withholding income and adjusted assessed taxable income. Perhaps it might be more properly known as `A New Tax System (Notional Tax, Adjusted Tax, Adjusted Assessed Tax, GDP Adjusted Notional Tax, Adjusted Taxable Income, Adjusted Withholding Income and Adjusted Assessed Taxable Income) Bill 1999'. Notwithstanding the temptation to move an amendment to that effect, I will not, and the opposition will not oppose the change which the government is proposing.

I take the opportunity while we are considering the bill in detail to raise an issue again which I raised in debate last night. Regrettably, the minister at the table did not seem anxious to take this on board to seek an answer at all. Indeed, the Minister for Forestry and Conservation did not seem to have read the legislation at all or have any understanding of what its contents were but wanted to take points of order. So I would redirect this issue to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. It is section 12-120 of the legislation, which refers to withholding amounts where compensation sickness or accident payments have been made.

I had brought to my attention a most unfortunate example of a chap by the name of Michael Quis, who had received a compensation payment, over a course of months, arising from a disability which made it impossible for him to pursue his former occupation. However, tax was not taken out of the compensation payment, nor was he informed that it had not been taken out of the compensation payment. After this had taken place for a couple of years, he was left with a major taxation bill, which of course caused him extreme financial hardship and distress. While I accept the observation being made that this has occurred under the present legislation, it is my understanding from reading the legislation that is before the House—in particular, section 12-120(c), the reference to payments made under an insurance policy to the policy owner—that we have a continuation of this situation. It is certainly not clear to me as to what the policy rationale for this section is. I request the minister and the government to consider this particular issue and provide a response. I accept that it might not be possible to provide a response right now, but I would certainly appreciate it being taken on notice and some response being provided in due course.

talk.start.para: —We had assurances from the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation that the problems of dependent contractors have been dealt with and that everything is fine in this legislation. I cannot accept that. It is an assurance of the Joh Bjelke-Petersen mould of `don't you worry about that'.

speech.para: I want to briefly raise the changing of the title of this tax system legislation. The minister says, `We've got our act together.' This act is not together. If the government have to change the title, it reflects very badly on the passage of the GST and the smooth transition to a GST that they are hoping will be achieved. In fact, before the deal was done by the government with the Democrats, there were 128 amendments before the Senate. There have been dozens more since that time and, as reported in the media yesterday, the cabinet is considering another 40 amendments. So this is looking like anything but a smooth transition to the new tax system. It is looking more and more every day like the Treasurer's 1930s ramshackle, Botswana style GST to me.

It is timely for the government to regroup, have a look at this entire tax system and stop bringing back amendments, including amendments to change the title of the legislation. Not knowing the correct title of the legislation reflects very poorly on the government's organisation and augurs badly for any smooth transition to the so-called new tax system. I think that transition will be anything but smooth.

talk.start.para: —I want to give the member for Rankin a solemn assurance—
—No more amendments.
—that there will be plenty more amendments in relation to the core taxation bills that this House has dealt with over the last 12 months.
—I wouldn't call that an assurance.

—I can assure the member for Rankin that, even if he has the opportunity to come over here and sit on the treasury bench—in the far-flung future, in the fullness of time nearing the end of the next millennium—there will be further amendments to these bills.

speech.para: The member for Wills raised an issue in relation to proposed section 12-120 and the proposed pay-as-you-go arrangements. I will undertake to write back to him with some information on the issues that he raised. I have some preliminary advice at the moment, but I am not satisfied that it covers enough of the issues. So I will ask Treasury to provide me with some information that we could forward to the member for Wills in relation to his constituent.

We are changing the name of this bill because we think that the new name that we are proposing more properly reflects the content of the bill. That is perfectly reasonable. It does not change the substance of the bill. It is a bit like the Labor Party in New South Wales who have designated their rural members `Country Labor Party'. If it walks like a duck, quacks like a duck and looks like a duck, it is a duck. In this case, we believe that this bill is now properly renamed with this amendment.

talk.start.para: —I have one final point. To remove any confusion, when I was talking about contractors I was talking about dependent contractors. I do not accept the assurances that the minister has given to us in relation to dependent contractors.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Hockey)—by leave—read a third time.
Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Mr Slipper:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —These appropriation bills seek to appropriate moneys from the consolidated revenue fund for initiatives flowing from the deal that the government made with the Democrats to secure passage of the GST. The measures are, firstly, for the book industry assistance plan and, secondly, for additional funding for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Plan. Those measures are contained in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 . We have a number of environment initiatives contained in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 , and I will deal with each of these in turn.

speech.para: Appropriation bill No. 1 provides $60 million for each of the four years from 2000-01 through to 2003-04. The main aims of the plan are to provide financial assistance to those producing books in Australia, Australian creators of books and retailers of textbooks in Australia. We need to point out to the House right up-front that this is needed only because of the GST and the impact that it will have on those who are involved in producing, creating and retailing books in Australia. We do this and we question the adequacy of this measure.

We think it is an inadequate response to what in the first place was a most unsatisfactory decision to impose a GST on books. We believe that it has the potential to create an administrative nightmare for every bookshop in Australia and that it is only going to compound the problem. Indeed, bookshops will have the administrative problems that every small business will have with the GST, but now they will have a whole new complex rebate to administer which has not been properly worked through, and this does represent a potential nightmare for bookshops. This measure represents, in our view, small and inadequate compensation for the industry in general for a tax that will be a direct attack on what Australia needs to be—that is, the knowledge nation. So this represents perhaps one step forward but certainly two steps back for the knowledge nation.

The government knows that the GST is bad for the book industry, for consumers of books, for bookshops and for education and knowledge in this country. It had to be embarrassed and shamed into a promise that it would do something in this regard, and we now see it in the form of this legislation which represents just a few crumbs off the table to the book industry when what we really needed to be saying was, `We are not going to be imposing a GST on knowledge.'

It is a totally inadequate measure in our view, unnecessary but for the government's determination to impose a GST on books and, indeed, but for the Democrats' capitulation on this issue. One of the core promises, I guess, of the Democrats when they went to the last election was that they would not allow in any shape or form a GST to be imposed on books, but after the election we saw the Democrats caving in, capitulating to the government on this issue. Now they walk around saying, `We've done wonderful things for the book industry,' when in fact the contrary is true. They had it in their power to prevent a GST being imposed on books in this country but they did not do it.

So what we have here is a piece of legislation which effectively says to the book industry, `We've struck you a dreadful blow and you're bleeding, but here is a bandaid.' Certainly, the bandaid is better than nothing, and we will not be opposing it, but it is our view that it is a small and inadequate response. Those book publishers who have indicated that they welcome the measure say that it goes some way to compensate for the GST, but that is the best you can say for it: that it does go some way to compensate.

Australians ought to be aware that this plan is not good news. Despite its meagre compensation, come 1 July 2000 people involved in this area—authors, bookshops, students, parents, Australians purchasing books—will be worse off. It would have been better, if we had to proceed down the GST path, to exempt books as the Democrats had pledged, rather than to introduce these complicated arrangements. I further point out to the House that it is quite hypocritical for some opposite to be talking about literacy—we hear from the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs from time to time on this front—when this tax will make books, and therefore knowledge and learning, more expensive.

The second provision in this legislation is that which provides an additional $15 million for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program for each of the four years through to 2003-04. The processes for distributing this money to the states are not clear. This is something that we would like some information about. Indeed, in the lead-up to the renegotiation of the agreement of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, we would like to hear more from the government about how this is intended to be distributed to the states.

I should point out that we believe the government has failed to take real action to address homelessness issues. The government's negotiations with the Democrats have led to this $15 million per year being provided for youth homelessness. We think this is trying to solve a major national crisis with, once again, as with the books area, crumbs from the table. The government failed in its budget to address Supported Accommodation Assistance Program funding at all, and the $45 million over six years amounts to a meagre $7.5 million a year and it has been instituted merely to ensure that the staff employed in the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program agencies have and enjoy award conditions. Not one dollar of that amount will actually go towards expanding the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program services to the needy.

Last year, the government sponsored a review by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute which recommended, at a minimum, a 25 per cent funding increase to SAAP in order just to service current unmet demands. The national evaluation of the program, released by the Department of Family and Community Services some three weeks ago, concurred with that analysis and requested that recurrent funding for the first year of the new agreement reach a total of $285 million.

Against that background, the extra $15 million which was reannounced by the government as part of this deal with the Democrats is candidly nowhere near the 25 per cent increase recommended by the government's own review and by the government's own Department of Family and Community Services. The demand for services for the homeless is ever growing. Figures released in budget week showed that the number of people accessing these services had risen from 101,000 in 1996-97 to 160,000—something like a 66 per cent increase—for the financial year 1997-98. This is a matter of considerable concern. The government was saying that it was a good thing that it was providing more services, but we would say it is illogical for the government to be treating as a sign of success evidence that there are more and more homeless people in our society. We are concerned that what is proposed here simply will not address these problems in a serious way.

Appropriation bill No. 2 provides for the environmental initiatives agreed with the Democrats, and I will go through them now. Those initiatives are: support conversions to compressed natural gas or liquid petroleum gas for commercial vehicles and buses that have a gross vehicle mass equal to or greater than 3.5 tonnes—that also applies to trains and ferries—support a product stewardship system for the reuse and recycling of waste oil; support the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential buildings and community reuse buildings; support the development and commercialisation of renewable energy; support the use of renewable energy from remote power generation; support the development and implementation of in-service emissions-testing capabilities for diesel patrol vehicles, where the diesel emissions testing is in connection with the making and/or implementation of a diesel national environment protection measure; and provide for a Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. As you can see, as far as they go, they are welcome, and we will certainly not be opposing them.

It is appropriate at this time to re-emphasise the environmental consequences of the goods and services tax, of which this legislation is a consequence, and the reduction in economic incentives to use alternative environmentally friendly fuels and technologies. The overwhelming body of evidence presented to the Senate committee inquiry into the impacts of the GST on the environment reinforced the view that the government's package was ill-considered and fundamentally flawed. Indeed, the Senate committee's report highlighted negative impacts on a great number of areas which it examined in some detail, including impact on the urban environment, impact on public transport services, impact on emerging technologies and impact on exports. All the evidence that the Senate committee considered tended to point to disastrous and long-term damage to the environment which would occur through an increase in diesel fuel pollutants and greenhouse gases and a reduction in economic incentives to use alternative environmentally friendly fuels and technologies.

The diesel fuel excise cut will result in economic incentive to use diesel fuel transport, a switch from petrol to diesel fuel vehicles, a switch from more fuel efficient rail transport to less efficient and high polluting road transport, and a reduction in incentives to switch from diesel to gaseous fuels and to new technologies such as solar. We want to continue to express the concern that the greatest environmental effects as a result of this measure will be in urban areas and that increased diesel fuel consumption will lead to an increase in highly dangerous particulates in our urban environments. We note that the Australian Medical Association has warned of increased risk of lung cancer and a variety of respiratory disorders.

The direct effect of the cut in the diesel fuel excise will be to make it difficult for the government to even meet those watered-down Kyoto greenhouse targets. One of the clear losers will be the emerging alternative energy sector. The impact on emerging technologies could cost many jobs. Australia is currently a world leader in the development of new technology and the renewable energy sector, including solar. It is clear that the government's taxation package will be highly detrimental to this critical and developing industry. It will undermine the industry's huge export potential. The measures in this bill simply do not adequately address that issue.

Evidence to the Senate committee expressed deep concern that removal of the diesel fuel rebate would also impact on what I have to describe as the already fragile economics of the Alice Springs to Darwin and Melbourne to Darwin railway proposals. The evidence on the environment, as with the evidence on books, is that the GST will impact very adversely and that the government's compensation measures will not be adequate.

It is worth pointing out that the Democrats went to the Australian people with a non-negotiable set of changes to the government's GST proposals. When we look at what they have achieved in this bill, they have in fact achieved none of the changes at all. First, in relation to the diesel fuel rebate, they said that it would be only payable to trucks over 20 tonnes except for those carrying farm produce. In the end, they gave it to all trucks over 4.5 tonnes. Second, they said that they would not allow trips within cities to qualify for the grant. But, when you see what we have ended up with, there is no apportionment at all for diesel used in the city. So as long as a journey crosses a city boundary, wherever it is, then all of the journey qualifies for a grant, even if the overwhelming proportion of the journey is within a capital city. So journeys commencing outside a metropolitan area but ending up in a metropolitan area and journeys commencing in a metropolitan area but ending up outside the metropolitan area will all qualify for a grant for the complete journey.

What we will now see is the redesign of intra-city transport routes to ensure that they briefly leave the metropolitan area in order to qualify for the rebate. Worse still, since there will be no way to ensure the integrity of the scheme, there will be claims based on ficti tious routes which involve a brief time outside the city. This is not going to discourage fossil fuel use; it is going to encourage fossil fuel use. No wonder the Democrats' expert environmental consultant, Dr Clive Hamilton, resigned in despair when he understood where the deal was going. We can see from this bill before the House that the Democrats have been absolutely naive in their negotiations with the government and have been played on a break. They have in fact achieved a system where a lot of the diesel used in cities will qualify for the grant system.

That is a most unsatisfactory situation, as is the situation where we do not have an indication of the boundaries for the metropolitan areas. We have the prospect of a plethora of anomalies and unfair outcomes depending on whether, in the Melbourne context for example, you describe Whittlesea or Werribee or Craigieburn or Kilmore or Seymour or somewhere else as being part of the urban area or part of the rural areas. We regard this as a very unsatisfactory situation. We certainly do not think that what the government has put forward with the support of the Democrats in this appropriation bill No. 2 will address those problems.

Having said that, as I indicated before, we are not proposing to oppose them. We note that there is some $60 million of expenditure for each of the four years in relation to the book industry assistance plan, and some $15 million of expenditure for each of the four years concerning supported accommodation assistance. We also note that the environmental measures are said to involve $214 million of expenditure in the first year, $222 million in the second year, $227 million in the third year and $233 million in the fourth year. On that basis, we will be supporting these measures, but we certainly put the government on notice that we do not think that the measures are adequate to address the adverse effects that its GST package will cause in the area of books, in the area of housing and accommodation and in the area of environment protection. We will be monitoring very closely the impact of this legislation, as well as the impact of the government's GST proposals more broadly, as we proceed towards implementation.

talk.start.para: —The Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 are bills contingent on the introduction of a goods and services tax, a change in the taxation system in Australia. The information contained in the bills is marginal but it is important to the people involved and it has been important to the settling in of the goods and services tax—the new taxation system. These bills are part of the total package and, in part, seek to compensate in some areas where compensation is needed.

speech.para: The previous speaker spent a lot of his time on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, which is a part of the goods and services tax, but did not really deal with some of the issues in the bill. Rather, he complained about how that diesel fuel rebate system would operate. He also complained about the fact that a goods and services tax might apply to books. The goods and services tax is going to apply to a wide range of things. Applying a tax to consumers as they purchase things will allow the government to provide substantial personal income tax cuts, providing choice and opportunities for people that they have not had before. It is a change in the tax system. I remind the House that this government is running a balanced budget. This government does not need additional taxation. Unlike Labor Party governments, this government has been able to bring its house into order, balance its books and therefore be in a position not to make a claim for additional taxation from Australian taxpayers.

The process that we are going through is one of change. It is one that, in the broad, will provide tax concessions and relief for individuals, particularly for individuals with families. It will provide taxation relief for business processes and the export of Australian goods. It simplifies the taxation system and it gets rid of some unconscionable and stupid taxes. Those are goals worth striving for, and they are goals that this government has achieved. These appropriation bills that we are dealing with today are contingent on the introduction of the goods and services tax and, on the margin, are complementary to it.

What do these bills seek to do? The Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) details the way in which two items of expenditure are dealt with. It provides that there should be ongoing assistance not only to the book industry but to readers of books, sellers of books and producers and writers of books. Through this legislation $60 million a year over the next four years—not an insignificant amount of money—will be provided to people involved in the book industry. That $60 million is going to go a long way to supporting the Australian book industry. It is a substantial amount of money. Anybody who is dismissive about $60 million has a pretty peculiar idea of what it is like to earn a living and pay the bills every week. I think it is a very superior attitude, one that is often demonstrated by the Australian Labor Party.

The book industry assistance plan has three main objectives: to provide financial assistance to those producing books; to provide financial assistance to those who are creators of books; and to provide financial assistance to retail sellers of text books in Australia in connection with reducing the retail price of text books for use in studies at Australian education institutions. They are pretty laudable objectives. They are narrow, well assessed and supportive of Australian students and children as well as the creative talent of Australia.

An additional objective relating to this plan is the provision of financial assistance to libraries of Australian primary schools. This is a great program. What could be better than money coming from the federal government to assist primary school libraries? I do not know how many libraries the members opposite go into; I do not know whether they go into libraries. I visit primary schools pretty frequently and I know that the member for Fisher does too. It is very much part of a proper representational role that effective members of the House of Representatives have. We go into these primary schools and look at the school libraries and often we say, `If only there were a little additional money to supplement this splendid collection of books.' There is often no help from the state governments. The money raised by parents is spent on stocking the library. We are doing something about this situation in this legislation.

Another objective of this plan is the collection, compilation and dissemination of statistical information about book production and book sales in Australia. Yes, the industry claims that it has not been able to mount a case for better use of Australian book production because it is not certain of the nature and structure of the industry. This is money well spent. Further, this plan will enable the promotion of the intrinsic value of books and reading.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—Well, it is hardly a `Life. Be In It' program, it is not a `get active and get attractive' sort of program, but it is one that I believe goes to the very core of personal satisfaction and growth. The idea is that the people of Australia should be encouraged—at the same time as having access to some marvellous innovations with the World Wide Web and email, electronic commerce and those sorts of things—to go directly to the creator of interesting ideas and thoughts and read books. I cannot see anything but good sense in it.

speech.para: The promotion of literacy is an additional objective of the plan. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, David Kemp, has done more than any person in Australian history to promote literacy amongst Australian kids. That is a most laudable plan. If you are going to control a population, then take away their capacity to read and write and they will become reliant on broad media presentations churned out by a limited number of media moguls. David Kemp's pursuit of literacy for all has to be encouraged. This literacy promotion plan that the House is dealing with today is a good measure.

The promotion of books of Australian authors, the training of book producers, the support for innovation and infrastructure development in book production and the support of other ancillary or incidental objectives are part of this plan. Sixty million dollars a year will be allocated to this plan. It is a well placed, well thought out four-year plan in support of the Australian book industry. Whilst the Labor Party say they are not opposing this, they are nevertheless complaining about it.

The second measure dealt with in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 is the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program. This covers a wide range of programs. I would like to inform the House that over the next four or five years the Commonwealth intends to raise funding from $140.1 million in the current year to $163.3 million in the year 2003-04. In addition to that, about $40 million goes on an annual basis to the states as part of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement on crisis accommodation. That program must be considered in addition to SAAP that we are currently looking at today.

The additional funding for this program in this appropriation is $15 million a year for four years. This complements the work that has already been done in this area. If any government has done something to help our young people it must be this government. It has introduced the Tough on Drugs and Youth Off the Streets programs. Father Chris Riley and the Salvation Army have been in there doing this work. I know that members of the opposition will complain that not enough is being done. There is never enough being done in these areas. But this government has made honest and sincere attempts to do something and is out there doing this.

We have complementary programs. We see kids as not being in isolation from their families or their society. Kids need support in getting jobs. We have excellent programs to assist kids—whether they started in job clubs and went to the now defined Work for the Dole and Green Corps—which are producing great results. There are literacy programs to make sure that the huge number of young people who are not acquiring jobs because of their lack of literacy skills due to the changes in literacy standards in the schools get assistance. There is assistance to families through taxation relief to make the people in the households more adequately prepared to look after their kids. Then there are programs to assist young people who fall out with their families and cannot any longer live in the circumstances they wish to or their parents may wish them to.

I will give the House a couple of examples of these programs. Hills Accommodation for Youth, which is run in the Hills district where I live, has been starved of funds until recent years. Gradually through families contributing and appeals a stockpile of three homes has been built up to give support to homeless kids. The first focus of this program is: can we get the kids back into their own homes and do they really have to move out of home? There is negotiation and counselling between parents and children to try to establish a stable and ongoing relationship so that the young people do not find it necessary to move out of home. In some instances, tragically, where there is violence or abuse there is no alternative but for the young people to leave home. They consistently work to restore a relationship so that ultimately they can move back into their homes.

Zanita Johnson and her people at Hills Accommodation for Youth have been doing a magnificent job. They have basically done it with little help. The Commonwealth has helped with some assistance. We have been able to, by persuasion, bring pressure to bear on the state government. This additional money will be welcomed by the people who are dedicated to providing accommodation for youth in this Hills district.

I have had drawn to my attention in the last week a proposal from Mission Australia to establish a youth homelessness pilot program in the Penrith district. That would reach out into my electorate of Mitchell and the Hawkesbury district. The statistics from that area are very concerning. The median age for young people seeking support through this homelessness pilot program is 15 years. Just over one-third are aged less than 15 years. The gender breakdown is 43 per cent male and 57 per cent female. Parents requested assistance in 55 per cent of the cases, including 27 per cent of cases where both the young person and the parent requested assistance together.

In 85 per cent of the cases contact was made whilst the young person was still at home or within three weeks of leaving home. The early intervention nature of these proposals is really important. That is what the government is building on. That is what the government is doing here with the allocation of this additional $15 million per annum over the next four years. The median support period is four to eight weeks, longer in cases involving both parents and young people. Four to six or eight weeks is the only intervention proposed for the pilot project in Penrith. That will cover much of Western Sydney. The most utilised family relation strategies were counselling, practical support and mediation.

I want to commend that program to the House and say how worthy I think the early intervention and youth homelessness programs are, seen in the context of a government anxious to create jobs, anxious to see good education, anxious to see stability and reasonable resources within families and anxious to see that abusive substances and influences that debilitate the lives of young people are removed and controlled and that a proper education program about them is put in place.

The second bill before the House today, the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 , deals with a range of environmental matters. I know my colleague who will be speaking shortly will want to deal with some of those environmental matters—it is an area in which he is expert—but I just want to let the House know the breakdown of this four-year program: total amounts will range from $214 million in the first year to $233 million in the fourth year. I also want to say that, as far as this government is concerned, the program is a diverse approach to environmental problems such as degradation of our atmosphere. The program is being implemented by the government to assist. Money will be appropriated from consolidated revenue for seven environmental initiatives: supporting conversions to compressed natural gas or liquid petroleum for commercial vehicles and buses that have a gross vehicle mass greater than 3.5 tonnes, applicable also to trains and ferries; developing a product stewardship system for the use and recycling of waste oil; supporting the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential and community use buildings; supporting the development and commercialisation of renewable energy; supporting the use of renewable energy for remote power generation; supporting the development and implementation of in-service emission testing capabilities for diesel and petrol vehicles where the diesel emission testing is in connection with the making and/or implementation of a national diesel environment protection measure; and a Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. These are all worthy programs. The provisions of this bill deal with these issues.

Again I say that these are substantial funds contingent on the introduction of the goods and services tax, but worthy in their own right in assisting and supporting a cleaner, greener environment for all Australians.

talk.start.para: —In speaking this morning on the cognate appropriations debate before the House I would like to begin my comments with a quote:

speech.para: It is nonsense to suggest that education is GST-free when you are applying a GST to the single most substantial education resource that students should have at their disposal—books.
There is another which says that a tax on books is a tax on `learning, literacy and literature'. And here is one more:
Taxing learning is hardly a path to making Australia a `clever country' as we enter the new millennium.

Whom do we have to thank for all those quotable quotes on the evils of introducing a 10 per cent goods and services tax on books? Why, none other than the very woman who cut the deal with the Prime Minister that would see the Howard-Democrat GST do just that—Senator Meg Lees. The decision of Senator Lees and the majority of the Australian Democrats to do a backflip on levying the GST on books will go down in our country as a dark day for education. I support the thrust of Senator Lees's comments 100 per cent—a GST on books is against learning, literature and literacy. A GST on books will not help us forge a path towards Australia achieving the mantle of a clever country, and no amount of compensation will make up for these facts.

The very act of offering compensation for a tax on books is an admission on behalf of this government and the Democrats that the tax is unfair and that the people suffering from the tax will be worse off. In fact, the compensation measures which this Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 will fund and which we are debating here at this very moment—measures which the Democrats and the government are trumpeting as being the saving grace for the Australian book industry—will just add to the tax compliance nightmare for thousands of people in industry right across this country of ours. Even the Democrats themselves know that the package will not completely make up for the damage that the GST will do to the Australian book industry.

The joint press statement of Senator Lees and Senator Allison on the package, released on 20 August, said it would `largely' cancel out any adverse effects flowing from a GST on books. `Largely' is not 100 per cent, is it? That is not as good as having no GST on books at all. If the compensation package does not completely make up for the damage that the GST on books will do, how much of the damage will it compensate? Will it compensate 40 per cent, 50 per cent, 60 per cent? The Democrats and this government have no answer to this question because they do not know the answer themselves. Later in that same press release Senator Lees had the gall to say that she would have much preferred that books were GST free. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker! I believe it is too late for expressions of remorse from any Democrat senator. It certainly will not mean anything to the Australian authors, to the booksellers and to the publishers, et cetera who will pay the price for the broken promises.

Before I take a closer look at the Howard-Democrat deal on compensation for a GST on books, I would like to make some general observations about the effects of taxing books, both on the book industry and on education standards in this country. I am pleased to see we have some young students up in the gallery. A GST on books will handicap the education of many thousands of children and our young students across Australia, including those in my own electorate. Because books are currently wholesale sales tax free, a tax on books will make them dramatically more expensive and will have the effect of discouraging people from purchasing them. A tax on books is a direct threat to the education of our kids. After the GST is introduced and prices rise, books and their contents will be looked on as luxuries. Low income parents in my electorate will be less likely to buy a book to encourage in their children a love of reading, an important part of developing a child's literacy. Students in high schools and in universities will also find they are less able to purchase textbooks because they have become so much more expensive.

Throughout the long and involved debate over the GST, the government has used the argument that a GST or similar has been introduced in many other Western nations and economies and is therefore right for Australia. When making this argument, one fact it neglects to mention is that, of the 19 major industrial nations with which Australia compares itself, 14 have either no tax on books or a tax at a reduced rate. Canada provides us with a very powerful example of the dangers to education and to the book industry of introducing a GST on this sector. When the Canadian government introduced a seven per cent GST on books, education books sales plummeted by 25 per cent. This was followed by a long-term 10 to 20 per cent cut in demand across all book sectors.

This is the news that sends chills of fear up the spine of the Australian book industry. It sends them cold, despite the compensation that the Democrats and this government are now offering. The Australian book industry is already a very competitive marketplace. As we know, more and more consumers are turning to the Internet to purchase their books through web sites such as amazon.com. The fear within the industry is that placing a GST on books will actually encourage thousands more Australians to purchase their books offshore. It will, in essence, have the effect of herding book buyers towards the waiting arms of these web sites and sending thousands of dollars out of Australia.

The Australian book industry knows this. The Democrats know this. Even the Treasurer of this country knows this—and we all know that he gave his own constituents tips on avoiding the GST on books by doing just that: buying through the Internet. This is what Senator Lees said in a press release on 28 September last year:

A tax on Australian made and sold books will simply see an explosion in the number of books bought through the Internet. Australians are reportedly already the third biggest customers of US online bookstores like Amazon.com.

The fears expressed by Senator Lees last year look like they will now become a reality—and all thanks to her very own work. The government could not get this through the Senate but, with the Democrats' assistance, they did.

What else has the Australian book industry had to say about a GST on books? The Australian Society of Authors has made itself very clear on the subject. It has gone on the record with the following comment:

A GST on books is a tax on thinking. We endorse the British and US models where there are no federal GST/VAT taxes on books. Books and associated products like software and CDs—anything that promotes learning, literacy and knowledge—should be zero-rated.

Australian writers are already lowly paid, earning on average only $5,000 per annum from their writing. Any drop in demand for books will be disastrous. Booksellers and publishers will also be seriously affected.
As for the Australian Publishers Association, its position on a GST on books has been clear from the very start:

The APA has enunciated a clear and consistent position against any form of taxation on books for many years. Despite developments in new technologies and increased electronic communications, books steadfastly remain the most effective tools for providing a lifetime of education.
It went on to say in its remarks:

We are disappointed that the Australian Government has not recognised the educational value of books nor their important role in the community and intends to apply a 10 per cent GST to books in Australia.
What about Bryce Courtenay, one of Australia's most widely published and well-loved authors? What is his opinion of a GST on books? He stated:

Every now and then, governments do something so incredibly stupid, so incredibly inane, so incredibly thoughtless, that it actually amounts to a crime. For a government to come along and say, `I'll tell you what, we'll put a price on the head of a book,' is the most astonishing piece of crass legislation that I've ever heard of. It is just absurd. You can't do anything better than educate a nation, but here we have a government who is committing the kind of crime that is called `dumbing down the people'.
Well said, Mr Bryce Courtenay. Then you have distinguished Australians like the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason. His opinion was also made very clear when he stated:

The tyranny of distance separates us from the main centres of intellectual activity in the world and adds to the price in Australia of books published overseas. The significant depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar is already having a devastating impact upon the capacity of Australians, especially Australian students and libraries, to buy books. And the education sector in this country is faced with an array of problems affecting funding and resources, that is why the impact of the proposed GST on books is so disturbing. The impact on students, not only in relation to books, but also equipment, is harsh.

All of these commentators and observers know what a GST on books really means for learning, education, literacy and the book industry in general. Compensation or no compensation, it is going to be a disaster.

For the book industry, this was chillingly illustrated in an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age in September last year. Written by author Janet McCalman, it bluntly set out, line by line, how the GST will devastate the Australian book industry. Ms McCalman's illustration began with a book being sold for $10 in a shop. Of that, $4 goes to the bookseller, from which all overheads must be paid, leaving them with a profit of around 20c. $2 goes to the distributor, who then must pay for staff, warehousing and transport around the country. The remaining $4 goes to the publisher. $2 of that goes on production costs, being used to pay editors, designers, indexers, typesetters and printers. Of the remaining $2, $1 is passed on to the author in the form of royalty payments while the remaining dollar is used by the publisher to pay such diverse costs as labour, rent, loans, administration, publicity, taxes, charges, insurance and WorkCover.

There is not a lot of fat there. High rollers in the Australian book industry are very few and far between, and profit margins in the good years hover at around two to five per cent. Then add to this equation a 10 per cent GST after 1 July next year. The tax will hit the book industry at almost every level down the chain—from author to retailer. The GST will have to be added to the costs of freelance editors and designers, the typesetter, the proofreader, the indexer, the printer and the binder. Despite compensation, the production cost of the book has to increase as every link in the chain passes on the cost of the tax and its administration to their clients. If they did not, they could not afford to pay it themselves.

According to Ms McCalman, a small publisher might have an annual turnover of $1 million, for example, of which $300,000 is production cost. With a GST, $30,000 will also have to be paid in tax—often far in advance of sales revenue. Publishers in this position will need to add that $30,000 figure to its bank overdraft. The publisher will also have to add into the equation the extra time and labour costs that will eventuate as the company's bookkeeper struggles to get on top of all the extra paperwork the GST will bring to the business.

The end result is that a 10 per cent GST on the book industry will have the effect of driving up the retail cost—not by 10 per cent but by an estimated 15 per cent to 16 per cent, and that is being conservative. The Howard-Democrat compensation deal that was announced on 20 August might soothe a few jangled nerves in the Australian book industry, but everyone in it knows that no level of compensation offered by this government is as good as having no GST on books at all.

The compensation package is in reality one step forward after two steps backward for the industry and for the health and wellbeing of education and learning in this country. Come 1 July 2000, the Australian book industry and educators everywhere will learn this lesson the hard way. The biggest problem with the compensation package is that it compounds the compliance nightmare, the compliance misery, for every participant in the industry.

Those in the book industry will have to grapple with extra new paperwork outlining the new and complex rebate system—a rebate system which neither the government nor the Democrats have even worked out for themselves as yet. Those individuals and organisations in the book industry with their heads screwed on correctly have rightly seen that this package is just a few crumbs from the government's table to help the Democrats save face.
The Australian Booksellers Association makes the point that the compensation package ignores the fact that over 70 per cent of book sales are consumer sales and not school sales. The ABA states:
These books will all be taxed which will lead inevitably to a drop in demand and therefore impact on our businesses. It—
meaning the compensation package—
does virtually nothing for retail sellers of books. Despite the Democrats good intent, booksellers remain unconvinced that the package offsets the impact of a GST on their businesses.
The Australian Society of Authors stated that the educational lending right contained in the compensation package `can never compensate for the effects of a GST on book sales'.

Then you have the small business people, the owners of the bookshops around our nation. These people are the professionals. They are at the coalface and they know how the GST will affect them and their industry. What do they think of the compensation package? `It will be an administrative nightmare in addition to the one already imposed by the GST itself,' says Mr Roger Mackell, the owner of one of Sydney's finest and most popular independent bookshops, Gleebooks in Glebe.

A few weeks ago, a report from the OECD found that the education levels of Australian adults lagged seriously behind those of comparable countries and that those levels would decline further in the future unless something was done to remedy the situation. Placing a 10 per cent GST on books is not part of that remedy; it will become part of the problem.

At a time when Australia should be boosting its education standards and preparing the ground for a knowledge based society, at a time when the government should be actively pursuing policies to improve teaching methods and people's access to learning opportunities, it is imposing a 10 per cent tax on books—a move that nearly every other nation in the world with a value added tax has rejected. It will be a handicap to people's education and it will limit their learning opportunities. In the process it will push our already struggling book industry to the edge.

This compensation package to which the budget appropriation is attached might satisfy the government, it might even assuage the guilt of the Australian Democrats, but it will not go far enough in regard to making up for the damage that the GST will do to the book industry and to education in this country.

This bill before us today is one of many amendment bills that we know are going to have to come before this parliament. It was estimated yesterday—I think in an article in the Financial Review—that over 40 amendments will be forthcoming. As we all know, you can multiply those 40 by hundreds because the government does not have the package right. There are more and more groups around the nation who are going to suffer from some of the GST clauses, when they fully understand and appreciate what the tax is going to mean to them. This is just one of many that this parliament will be debating. This is a deplorable tax. It is a tax that should never have been placed on books and education. I believe that come July 2000 people will understand and appreciate just how badly this government has handled this tax package.

talk.start.para: —In my speech on the appropriation bills made shortly after the budget, I said that Australians would breathe a sigh of relief when the government's tax reform package finally passed through the Senate, ensuring that Australians would be better off and the country as a whole would be in a better position to meet the world's challenges in the new millennium. As we just heard from the previous speaker, the member for Prospect, the debate that we are facing today has little to do with the specifics of Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 and Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 before the House; it is a distaste for tax reform generally.

speech.para: But it is tax reform that the nation has embraced—tax reform that the former Labor government tried to implement but did not have the ticker to carry through. Everybody who knows that we need to finance necessary government works and services understands that we need these tax changes. The bills before the House are supplementary measures to the overall package that we have debated before in this place and that I am sure we will hear more about as time pushes on.

Just as our side of politics was arguing that the budget was a product of decisive leadership action and continuing policy innovation, the Labor Party tried the flimsy argument that the budget was not the real budget—the tax reform package was the real budget. Its logic is looking more counterfeit today than ever before. The budget is a product of the hard work, diligence and policy innovation of the coalition, and these bills we are discussing today supplement that effort and help to bring the next phase of Australia's economic renewal to reality by facilitating the smooth introduction of the tax reform package.

These two bills which are being debated together are an essential part of the transition to the new tax system. They appropriate funds for seven important environmental initiatives, the Book Industry Assistance Plan and the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program. Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 funds the book industry assistance plan and augments the funding of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program.

The Book Industry Assistance Plan is designed to ensure a smooth transition for Australia's book industry and its authors and young readers to the new tax system. It was interesting listening to the member for Prospect. She made the very simple point that the book industry is already struggling. She then went on to talk about what that struggle represents and the industry's various fears. The amazing irony is that those fears and that struggle exist, regardless of tax reform.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the tax reform changes will neither make nor break the book industry. They will not make an unprofitable business profitable. They will not strip away the lifeblood of a profitable enterprise. So, in that respect, it could well be argued that the tax reform package will have a fairly neutral effect on all sectors of the economy. It may make some changes at the margin but, of itself, it will not overcome every fear that every industry may have, nor will it blunt the advantages that industries have. The member for Prospect was very clear in making the point that the book industry has its problems. These problems are unrelated to tax reform. But the terrific thing about the bills before the House today, which include the Book Industry Assistance Plan, is that they tackle the problems the industry already has—those problems that are unrelated to tax reform.

The member for Prospect went on and said that no-one will be able to afford to buy books. What utter, utter nonsense. We know that, as part of the tax reform package, there will be reductions in income tax, there will be a boost in income support, the bottom line being that there will be an increase in the discretionary expenditure in the hands of all Australians. The challenge before the book industry is the same challenge that is before any other sector of the economy: how to get its hands on the available expenditure; how to make sure that it is the one to take more than its fair share of the discretionary income that now will be in the hands of all Australians as a result of the package.

Under the Book Industry Assistance Plan, $60 million will be provided in each of the four years from the year 2000-01 through to the year 2003-04. The Book Industry Assistance Plan has a number of objectives. The first is to provide financial assistance to those producing books in Australia. As the member for Prospect pointed out, those people are having a bit of a tough time of it now. This package will enhance their capacity to com pete, not detract from it. That seems to be lost on the member for Prospect.

Secondly, there is also financial assistance to Australian creators of books. We heard from the member for Prospect about the income that is available for Australian authors—I think, from my recollection, she said around $5,000 a year. Again, here we are talking about a tax reform package that will increase disposable income. It will mean that, of that $5,000 a year, the author will be able to retain more of what they earn. But, above all, it actually is giving a boost to those authors—and I will come back to that point in a moment.

The third objective of the Book Industry Assistance Plan is to assist retailer sellers of textbooks in Australia. Again, this is a point that seemed to be lost on the member for Prospect. The fears in the industry that the member for Prospect spoke about and the `already struggling nature'—as she described it—of the book industry are not the product of tax reform. But these bills before the House, a complementary initiative that goes with tax reform, directly address those issues.

The member for Prospect spoke about Australians being the third biggest customer of Internet book purchases—and that is happening now—and the exchange rate impacts, unrelated to tax reform, being a challenge that the industry is facing. She spoke of thin margins. Again, that is a challenge before the industry, unrelated to the tax reform package, that this group of measures will address. Within the package of the Book Industry Assistance Plan, there is financial assistance to Australian primary school libraries to help them buy Australian books. We are trying to boost demand for the work of the industry and the authors. That goes to the heart of the challenges that the industry is facing, and that is a complementary measure with the tax reform package. But those challenges are not a product of the tax reform. This is the confusion that we get from those opposite.

There is also assistance for the generation and dissemination of statistical information about book production and sales in Australia. There is the promotion of the value of books and reading. Again, that is a demand measure. That is trying to stimulate interest in the product. It is not tax reform. The demand challenge is there today, and this package of measures that accompanies the tax reform will do something about those pre-existing issues confronting the industry. For instance, my little boy Alexander loves books. He loves reading about Hungry Hippo and Sleepy Snail.

talk.start.para: —How old is he?

—He is 20 months old. When he has a moment and he sees his dad or mum sitting down, he goes and grabs a book and we read it together. I cannot begin to tell you how pleasing it is that he has such a passion for books. But that is something we as parents have been trying to instil. This measure will complement those sorts of measures where families will recognise the value of spending some time with their children and generate books and reading as a hobby, as a leisure activity, as something that young people do as a matter of choice. This package has measures that complement that.

speech.para: As an aside, I have been talking with Geoff Masters from the Australian Council for Education Research and Associate Professor Anne Stonehouse from Monash, Victoria about what I might be able to do to help provide useful information to new parents about the constructive things parents can do to help with the development of their kids. Part of that, I believe, will be explaining how parents quite constructively can introduce their children to books. This Book Industry Assistance Plan promotes the value of books and reading. It also promotes books by Australian authors. It also provides training for book producers and support for innovation and infrastructure development in book production.

These are issues that the industry is facing that are unrelated to tax reform, but we have used the opportunity of tax reform to go to the heart of some of the industry's concerns. Some of you would have heard in the media in recent times about new technology where you can actually order a book over the Internet. New printing and production systems mean that you can fire in a text and it will print it for you in a short run. Then you can either collect it or get it mailed to you. That is an enormously significant change in the book industry for authors who might not be able to sell 1,000 or 2,000 books and for book publishers who no longer have to be concerned about overruns where they need to bring those books back to their outfits and write off the cost of such overruns. It removes those barriers.
