That approach failed at Kyoto—the world made it very clear that they were going to impose some disciplines on Australia—so there have to be some measures such as these to start encouraging the shift away from fossil fuel energy use.

I absolutely support the funding of those programs. I just make the point that the government has been dragged into the cart very reluctantly. It has been dragged, kicking and screaming, into making these sorts of funding concessions. In saying that this has been a trade-off, I want to place on the record an observation that I think is pretty significant, and that is that the Worldwatch Institute has prepared a state of the world report on progress towards sustainability and, in that report, the institute views the cutting of fuel taxes in Australia with considerable alarm. Of course it would. We know that the modelling provided to the government predicts that there is going to be an increase of 60 per cent in greenhouse gas emissions from the commercial transport sector in Australia between 1997 and 2015. In other words, bringing in a diesel fuel pricing scheme that encourages even more use of diesel fuel cuts against the whole concept of Australia's international obligations and sensible environmental management. These measures are very important. I hope they are ultimately successful and that the government does get serious about encouraging the shift to alternative uses.

That brings me to the matter that I really wanted to touch upon today which is very local to me—and it is an important time for some decision making locally—and that is how this all fits into the context of forest policy and the management of forests. It is all very well to try to deal with motor vehicle omissions, but this has to be in the context of Australia's continuing obsession with cutting down forests and exporting woodchips and the steps that we are going to have to take to continue to balance this up. In central Victoria, which is at the heart of my electorate, the RFA process is under way at the moment, and it is not going very successfully for the government. The Central Highlands RFA— which I might say was set in train four years ago by the former Labor government—has stalled because the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey, has come to the same conclusion that we have all reached over the years, and that is that you simply cannot trust the information provided to Canberra by the Victorian state government about the management of the Wombat and Cobaw forests. That is quite an extraordinary position to find ourselves in—the fact that you simply cannot trust the information coming from the Victorian government. On the basis of that, the federal minister has now appointed an independent environmental assessor to look at the process.

We are moving into a Victorian state election in three weeks time. There is now emerging a very strong demand from the community to know the future of this forest and how it fits the National Greenhouse Emissions Strategy. In a normal RFA process where you can trust the information, the key criterion is that the state and federal governments can come to an agreement about the forest being well managed on a sustainable basis. That means that the timber allocated to the timber industry is in sustainable volumes, that the residue from that timber that is not suitable for value adding manufacturing is used in an appropriate way and that the environmental management strategy of the forest is consistent with a sustainable, long-term policy. In this particular forest area, we also have some significant water values because it is a catchment area for a significant amount of water both for the Murray Valley and for the south, for Geelong and Melbourne.

The second component in all of this is that whatever policies you adopt need to encourage the industry to invest in significant and upgraded value adding and in research and development. We have always accepted that as part of an RFA process you would be giving the industry long-term security of access to quality timber. It also requires that you recognise the environmental values and the local perspectives and that if you are going to close down the forest, because the use of timber in the area changes or the community perception of the forest changes, the industry is entitled to compensation. All those things are an agreed set of values and an agreed process, but they all hinge on genuine and transparent information coming to the federal government that allows it to be confident about any agreement it reaches.

What do you do when you cannot trust the state government? I am saying very clearly to the federal government that you cannot trust the Victorian state government. That has been very clear and has even been accepted by the federal Minister for Forestry and Conservation. What you do is you suspend the process. You say, `It is flawed, and we won't go ahead with it. We agree that, until the environmental assessment by independent auditors is carried through, this goes no further, because the process is flawed.' Secondly, you say, `Even if it does go forward down the track, what do we do with the woodchips?' Under no circumstances do you provide for woodchips from this forest to be export woodchips. In my time, when Labor was in government, we fought very hard to make sure that the chips residue from this forest went to the local value added plant at Bacchus Marsh, CSR. Since the change of government, CSR has closed, and there is therefore no market for those chips.

This government has got to get off its backside and take the Australian industry to the point where there is an Australian pulp mill so there is somewhere to send these chips. I will not support any process that continues to think that the solution is sending chips out of the forest somewhere overseas so that we can continue to buy back the pulp. It is absurd. Four years after the change of government, we are still in the situation of not having a pulp mill in Australia, yet we send shiploads of chips overseas. And this is supposed to be part of Australia's environmental solution. It is supposed to be part of our sensible approach to greenhouse strategy.

I am foreshadowing to the minister and the government a major local confrontation when this debate comes to a head—and we have not had one until now because we have been able to manage this through sensible principles. I think the state minister—who is attempting to transfer from his upper house seat to the lower house seat of Gisborne, which is right in the heart of this—should ignore Jeff Kennett's instruction not to debate these issues locally. He would be pretty stupid politically if he failed to take up the call to attend a public debate about these issues, because he is in the hot seat. It is his government that is feeding bum information to Canberra. It is his government that is planning to woodchip this forest into extinction. He has three weeks to get himself on deck and to explain his position to the people.

I am publicly signalling here that, unless we get a sound and transparent management plan for this forest, a genuine commitment that any woodchip residue goes to an Australian pulp mill and a genuine, value adding and sustainable outcome for the local timber industry, this forest needs to be pulled out of the RFA process. If it is pulled out of the RFA process, that means no woodchips for anybody. It means the local timber industry is in difficulty, but it also means that you avoid the serious public confrontation which is brewing because the Victorian state government cannot be trusted and the federal government is so embarrassed by this performance that even the federal minister concedes that is the case.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have taken that opportunity to try and be as constructive as I can about this matter, because it is one I have been involved in for a long time. I have the corporate knowledge to know very well that what is happening here in Canberra is spot on. I am putting on the public record via this statement today my suggested approach to a resolution of this issue before it becomes a hot flame in central Victoria. That suggestion is put forward constructively with the intention of our industry building its value adding investment but giving the forest and the people a future.

I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the opportunity to put those points on the table. I reiterate my earlier comments that I support the investment contained in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 regarding alternative fossil fuel options. However, I make the point that it is very little. We should not have had the four-year lag in these programs. I think that circumstances are closing in on this government as its environmental performance and its performance at Kyoto comes under the spotlight.

talk.start.para: —The long title of these bills states:

speech.para: A Bill for an Act to appropriate the Consolidated Revenue Fund for certain purposes, and for other purposes.

In the case of Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 the words `relating to the environment' are added. The purpose of these two bills can best be summed up in the final sentence of the very short second reading speech delivered with these bills, both of which are basically the same sentence. In Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 the sentence states:
The funding proposed in this bill meets these two commitments of the Government—
and with bill No. 1 that is to do with the Book Industry Assistance Plan and the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program—
to the Australian Democrats in the context of our tax reform package.
In the case of bill No. 2, the sentence states:
The funding proposed in this bill meets these environment commitments of the Government to the Australian Democrats in the context of our tax reform package.

That is what these two bills are basically about. These bills seek to appropriate funds for a variety of measures resulting from the government's grubby, puerile, sleazy deal—you pick the appropriate adjective, Mr Deputy Speaker—with the Australian Democrats to ensure the passage of its legislation to charge Australians 10 per cent on nearly everything they do or buy.

These measures are part of the deal under which, after 1 July next year, every time Australians go to buy something, when they put their hands in their pockets into that pocket will go the hands of the Prime Minister, John Howard, and the Treasurer, Peter Costello, and together with them as partners in crime will be the hand of Senator Meg Lees, the Leader of the Australian Democrats. Over the next two and a bit weeks I will be reminding people in Victoria that, not only have they got all those hands in their pockets, but they had better have deep pockets because Premier Jeff Kennett was there as one of the partners in crime to ensure that the Prime Minister got his GST package up. The people of Victoria have to know that, despite his humping around the countryside saying what a tragedy to small business GST compliance costs are, Jeff Kennett was able to ensure at the Premiers Conference that the deal got through.

When it came to books, housing and the environment the government and the Democrats were able to come to some arrangement to reach their deal. However, a casual glance at these two bills reveals just how greatly the government took the Democrats for an absolute ride. It prompts the question how and why the Democrats sold out so cheaply on issues that they professed to be part of their raison d'etre. If the Democrats' non-negotiable GST-free books election policy is looked at, it has been watered down to a book production bounty and grants to assist writers. Grants to writers are an admission that the GST will decimate the book industry, whether it be those writing them or printing them.

These measures add up to $180 million over three years, or $240 million over four years in this bill, and they are vulnerable to budget cuts in the years after that. The Democrats have not in any way secured the future of the book industry in this country. If the government does cut these measures in outyears after that, the book industry is left to the full mercy of the goods and services tax. These measures do not compensate for the massive burden that the GST and compliance to it will place on the industry. They directly compromise the Democrats' GST-free education policy, which they also sold out on and showed no signs of wanting to—let alone being able to—secure from the government.

These bills also appropriate funds for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, or SAAP. The extra $15 million per year appropriated with these bills to deal with a national crisis such as youth homelessness is totally inadequate, but totally expected, given the Howard government's whole attitude towards issues of housing and homeless ness since coming to office. The budget announcements on funding for housing were all recycled previous announcements. In some cases, the Minister for Family and Community Services tried to get away with announcing the same funding three times hoping no-one would notice that it was not new money.

At the time of the budget the government did announce an additional $45 million over six years for the SAAP. Of course, this translates to a mere $7½ million per year. The great irony of this is that the funding is merely to allow SAAP agencies to pay their staff award wages. Of course, those staff deserve to be paid and should be paid properly for their work. However, the fact remains that none of the additional $45 million was to increase services for those in need.

Now comes a paltry amount of $15 million in these bills each year which adds further insult to injury. It is widely known that this amount is too little, because last year the government sponsored a review by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute. The review recommended 25 per cent growth funds for SAAP just to service the current unmet demand. Now it is unclear whether this additional $60 million, which was supposedly extracted by the Democrats from the government, is actually more than what might have been announced late last year in response to other studies. The finding for the need for 25 per cent growth funds was supported by the Department of Family and Community Services, but has been totally ignored by the government. That gives the House some idea of the magnitude of the problem the nation faces with regard to issues concerning housing and homelessness and the total inadequacy of the Howard government's response to it. It also speaks volumes for the Australian Democrats and prompts the question why they sold themselves out on the issue of GST for so little.

Of all the issues the Democrats sold out on in this deal, the environment is perhaps the most surprising, given their rhetoric over some 20 years. The environmental consequences of the GST were totally ignored by both the government and the Democrats. The GST is a disaster for the environment because of the likely increase in the use of diesel fuel and the increase in greenhouse gases. The Democrats' non-negotiable reduction of the tax cuts on diesel and petrol through increased weight thresholds failed to materialise in this shonky deal. Instead, the nation will be lumbered with a totally unworkable system of transport credits for so-called regional transport vehicles. The definition is yet to be outlined.

The Democrats sold out to the government and handed a raft of environmental powers over to the states and territories in the biodiversity legislation. The government have been winding back funding for the environment steadily since coming to office under cover of the Natural Heritage Trust fund set up with the proceeds of the sale of Telstra. Now the Democrats have joined them in this attitude to the environment.

As others have said in the debate, the measures contained in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 which relate to the environment of course have some merit. As was revealed in the debate and discussions which surrounded the talks the Democrats had with the government over the GST, a number of these measures had been earmarked as measures that the government would be putting in place. In fact, even in the measures which are to do with the environment, we find that all we have had is a public announcement that ties these measures into the deal done with the Democrats at that fateful meeting down at 4 Treasury Place in Melbourne after Senator Harradine had made his principled views known on the GST package.

When all is said and done about this deal, after 1 July next year a GST will be put in place. All these measures came about when Senator Lees and Senator Murray sat down with the Treasurer and the Prime Minister around the table at 4 Treasury Place: they discussed the issues; they put certain ideas on the table; they sent Max Moore-Wilton busily off over the weekend, distracting him from what he was really going to say to Mr Barratt, the then Secretary to Defence, about his future; and they cobbled these measures together. Then they came back the next week and the Democrats rolled over and said they would tick off on the GST package. What we get—amongst other things—are the measures contained in these two bills.

It is just not good enough. It is not good enough that a political force in Australia should sit down and so easily agree to measures that in many cases would have occurred; and to measures contained in these bills that go nowhere near far enough to redress the damage that has been done in the case of the book industry and a number of items dealing with the environment. They go nowhere near far enough towards redressing the difficulties that occur in the post-GST environment.

Of course, the opposition have made it clear that they will be supporting these bills, because there is a certain inevitability that we have to in order to put some of these things in place. As I have said, a number of them have merit. But the Australian public has to remember that the issues that arose and that led to the need for these two pieces of legislation have their base in fact in a deal which was made between the Australian Democrats and the coalition government.

As has been indicated in this debate, there are many provisions of these two bills that should have happened and would have happened without this tawdry deal. I would suggest that the next time the Australian Democrats enter into negotiations they ought to have a due diligence test where they at least look at what is actually in the pipeline, is near announcement or has been announced, and not sign off, underline and highlight announcements that are going to be made or have already been made, because that short-changes them on any decisions and deals that they make of this magnitude.

I fear the consequences of the GST package and the damage that will materialise. I fear that, at the end of the day, the Australian public just might forget that it is not only the coalition they have to blame for those consequences, but they have to remember that the Australian Democrats played a very big role in putting those consequences together.

talk.start.para: —in reply—In commencing my summing up I would like to thank honourable members who have participated in the debate on these two important pieces of legislation—the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 —which, as I said in my second reading speech, deliver on the government's commitments to the Australian Democrats on 31 May 1999.

speech.para: It ought to be placed on the record and recognised that the agreement reached between the government and the Australian Democrats represents a defining moment in history. It secured the government's historic tax reform changes of which all Australians can be very proud. I would like to wholeheartedly applaud the words of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Meg Lees, who when commenting on the tax package stated:
The Democrats have won more in 13 hours of talks with the Howard Government than they did in 13 years under the Labor Government.

The Democrats and the government have acted responsibly in securing genuine tax reform for this country, and the Australian people who voted for a new tax system in the October 1998 election will certainly be much better off for it.

It is very sad that the Labor Party continues to criticise members of the government for being prepared to implement the very important changes voted for by the Australian people. It is also interesting to note the Labor members who stood up one after the other and bagged the very constructive role the Australian Democrats played in this legislation. We heard words like `puerile' and `tawdry'. The honourable member for Throsby claimed that the Democrats had jumped into bed with the government. The honourable member for Wills even attacked the Democrats for negotiating on environmental initiatives.

It is interesting that members of the former Labor government who are now in this chamber have turned on the party with which they used to cooperate in the upper house just because the Australian Democrats are displaying incredibly positive initiatives in dealing with the government. Let us just look at editorial comment made following the GST compromise. The Sydney Morning Herald on 31 May said:

The GST compromise between the Howard Government and the Australian Democrats represents a triumph for the Prime Minister. He held his nerve through the last election campaign, and for most of the ensuing tax debate.
It went on later to say:

The significant loser from the GST deal is the Labor Party, specifically its leader, Mr Beazley. For three years Labor has ditched the great economic reforms of the Hawke-Keating governments for a leftist populism that is associated with its prized recruit, Mrs Cheryl Kernot. The adamantine refusal to do anything but launch attack after attack on the GST has led Labor into a dry policy gully.
The Adelaide Advertiser on 31 May said:
The deal is to be supported and even applauded.
The overriding fact is that Australia has overdue tax reform and, had this compact not been made, that would have been impossible for the foreseeable future.
The West Australian on 31 May said:
The compromise deal agreed between the government in the Democrats shows that the system is working.
The deal—
finally opens the way for long overdue reform of our ramshackle, illogical tax system. It heralds the arrival of a transparent and equitable new system.
The Labor Party—
rendered itself irrelevant to the tax debate when it put perceived political advantage ahead of responsible reform.

So, as a result of discussions between the government and the Australian Democrats, we will have a new tax system, and the two bills currently before the chamber are important elements in securing the passage of the legislation. The government is very proud not only about having reached an agreement with the Australian Democrats but also about the very positive measures included in these two bills.

This government, despite what Labor members would have you believe, is the greenest government in Australia's history. We delivered the Natural Heritage Trust, which has spent well over $1 billion on repairing the impact of 200 years of European settlement in Australia. We have an enormous range of environmental achievements, and it is about time that those opposite gave the government credit—the very real credit—for what it has achieved, for what it is achieving through this legislation and, indeed, for what it will continue to achieve in the future.

Labor members also sought to suggest that the GST in some way would adversely affect a greener Australia. The new $1.2 billion strategy to improve air quality and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions was negotiated with the Australian Democrats and will be implemented as a result of the legislation currently before the House. This new air quality package includes faster introduction of new technology machines to cut down on vehicle emissions; cleaner fuels to power those engines; increased support for alternative transport fuels, such as compressed natural gas and LP; incentives for households to switch to solar power; and an extra $100 million a year for increased efforts to combat global warming.

The honourable member for Burke endeavoured to suggest that cheaper diesel would in some way create more pollution. That simply is not true. I want to place on the record that, thanks to the new air quality package negotiated with the Australian Democrats, there will be actually less, not more, pollution. There will be cleaner air and a better quality of life for Australians. The Bureau of Transport Economics has predicted that air pollution levels in the year 2015 will be lower than current levels, because of the changes to engine technology and fuel standards.

The honourable member for Wills seems to participate in most legislation relating to Australia's tax system. He claimed that the process for distributing money with respect to the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program is not clear. I would like to reassure the honourable member that the Commonwealth government will agree on the distribution of the funds with the states in accordance with the normal processes for distributing Supported Accommodation Assistance Program moneys. The extra money being provid ed by this legislation will not adversely impact on that.

The honourable member for Prospect and, indeed, the honourable member for Newcastle both claimed that a tax on books will make books more expensive, as they are currently free of wholesale sales tax. It is true that books will go up in price slightly. We anticipate they will go up by about four per cent—certainly not by the 10 per cent that was suggested by some. But one has to look at the global picture. One must also consider the very positive benefits for the book industry included in this legislation. In addition, it must be recognised that Australians will receive dramatic reductions in personal income tax. The wholesale sales tax is being scrapped. Other taxes are disappearing, and there will be a four per cent boost in pensions and benefits. So people will have more money in their pockets.

The honourable member for Wills also claimed that the legislation before the chamber would provide an administrative nightmare for the book industry. The simple fact of the matter is that there will be less red tape as a result of Australia's new tax system. The government is distributing $500 million to small and medium business with respect to GST implementation, and it has been calculated that across the board there will be reductions in red tape rather than the reverse. Certainly we will be having consultations with respect to the industry, and we certainly intend to make sure that this very positive scheme introduced in this legislation works, and works well. It will work, and it will work in a very positive way.

The honourable member for Prospect also appeared to be caught in a time warp, because a lot of her speech related to the situation that existed before the arrangements with the Australian Democrats. She spoke about what she perceived as being the impact of the GST on books. But one really has to look at the situation which will flow from the passage of this legislation to see the assistance being given to the book industry. I would just like to highlight a media release dated 20 August 1999 issued by the Australian Publishers Association. It said:
The Australian Publishers Association today welcomed the release of details of the Book Industry Assistance Plan.
Further down it said:

Sandy Grant, President of the APA, said today, "I congratulate the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Democrats in working together to arrive at a package which brings benefits to various sectors of the industry.
It also said:

Sue Blackwell, Executive Director of the APA, in welcoming the announcement said, "there has been full industry consultation on the components of this important package. The APA was consulted at several stages during the consultations and we were pleased to be involved."

The legislation before the chamber certainly includes many benefits with respect to textbooks, and I refer to a media release dated 20 August 1999 issued by the Co-op Bookshop, a very well-known university bookshop. It said:

Australia's largest tertiary textbook seller, the University Co-op Bookshop, which runs fifty stores Australia wide, has expressed its strong support for the 8% textbook subsidy announced by Democrats leader Meg Lees this morning.
Further on it says:
"The deal struck between the Government and the Democrats is very similar to the Canadian model proposed in the Co-op's own submission and I believe works very well in that country."

The honourable member for Scullin claimed that this legislation meant that education would not be GST free. The lie to that particular comment is also enclosed in this media release from the Co-op Bookshop. It says:
"The Government made a commitment last year that educational costs would be GST free and with this deal it has honoured that commitment."

The honourable member for Scullin has been caught out with respect to that particular matter. The honourable member for Prospect also claimed that a tax on books would encourage book buyers to buy through the Internet and that money was leaving Australia. She mentioned certain of the difficulties which she considered the book industry was currently experiencing. People in this country, under Labor's old tax system, and in other countries are already buying books through the Internet, and many of the problems of the book industry which the member for Prospect highlighted have absolutely nothing at all to do with the legislation currently before the chamber.

The honourable member for Mitchell made a very much more positive and erudite contribution to the debate on this legislation. He spoke about the benefits of it. He also praised, most appropriately, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs for his absolute determination to improve literacy standards in Australia. The honourable member for Dunkley also referred to the overall benefits of the tax plan. He pointed out, as I just have, that the difficulties experienced by the book industry mentioned by the member for Prospect have absolutely nothing to do with our tax reform proposals.

The honourable member for Fowler joined her colleagues in what I thought was a fairly cowardly attack on Senator Meg Lees and the Australian Democrats. But she, unlike the member for Newcastle, did have the decency to actually praise the green initiatives in this legislation. The Labor Party is not actually opposing this legislation, but the honourable member for Newcastle said words to the effect that this legislation was disgusting and that the $1 billion being spent as a result of these bills was inappropriate expenditure whereas most people in this country, including those in the opposition, would say that these are very positive and important initiatives and certainly worthy of strong support.

The member for Blaxland thought he was speaking on a bill related to Sydney airport, and he only peripherally touched the subject matter of this legislation. I thought it was a pity that he did not spend time praising the very important initiatives being brought about by the government.

The member for Newcastle also criticised the government's responsible economic management. He forgot that when we came to government there was a budget deficit of $10.3 billion. He overlooked that we as a nation simply could not go on spending more than we in fact earned. This government did not create that problem, but we resolutely accepted that we had a responsibility to fix it, and fix it we certainly did.

Certain members from Victoria failed to remember that they were in the federal parliament and sought to bring the Victorian election within the four walls of this chamber. I certainly do not intend to dignify their comments by participating in the Victorian state election.

The government are very satisfied with this legislation. We are very proud of our record in the areas covered by the two bills before the chamber. We have been particularly pleased that what we are proposing has been strongly supported by people in the industry and by the community generally, and it is with a very great deal of pleasure that I commend these two bills to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Slipper) proposed:
That the bill be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to make a few comments on the third reading of the appropriation bills, as they relate to the changes in appropriation post the Democrat and government deal with respect to the introduction of the GST. I put on the record once again my concern with regard to housing and, particularly, the inadequate response with regard to homelessness. The bill allows for funding of some $60 million over four years to be allocated to assist in the increase in homelessness. I believe that is a totally inadequate response by the government, particularly in the context of the failure of the government to implement its own recommendations on the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, SAAP.

speech.para: The government sponsored a review, undertaken by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute, which reported in November of last year. It recommended a 25 per cent increase in SAAP funding. However, what occurred was a $45 million increase over six years in the last budget, amounting to just $7.5 million per year. In real terms that means not one cent in increased funding for services, because that funding was to go towards the award increases for staff employed in SAAP agencies. As a result of the deal with the Australian Democrats, we now have a completely inadequate response.

We have an inadequate response with regard to SAAP funding and with regard to the deal that rents of public and community housing tenants will not be increased as a result of the GST. Whilst that is certainly good news for public and community housing tenants—there is no doubt about that—it is bad news for the public and community housing sector. The $70 million cut, as a result of public and community housing departments in the states having to forgo that extra revenue they would have got from the rent, has not been matched by them not having to pay the GST. That means a reduction of $70 million in the funds available in this country for public and community housing at a time when there is a crisis, with some 235,000 people on housing waiting lists in Australia.

The Democrats failed in this arrangement to ensure that those funds were increased. When you add up the total cuts as a result of the GST—the increased costs of the GST, the failure of the government to index the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and the demand for an efficiency dividend to be produced by state and territory housing departments—they come to some $461 million over the four-year period of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. That is an inadequate response.

The issue of youth homelessness demands action and funds. Today we have seen an announcement by the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, in response to the government's prime ministerial youth homelessness task force, which really is an insult to young people. There is not a single cent of new funding in the government's response. Senator Newman has now announced funding for the Youth Homelessness Early Intervention Program on four occasions since December 1998 and today we get a reannouncement. The extension of the Job Placement, Employment and Training Program was announced over four months ago in the budget. If funding for homelessness strategies multiplied every time Senator Newman announced them, we would have—$60 million multiplied by four times—$240 million. But we do not get that.

The youth homelessness task force called for funding to be at appropriate levels to allow adequate coverage. But, based on a conservative estimate of 30,000 homeless Australians under the age of 24, the $60 million reannounced today amounts to a pathetic $1.30 per person per day. Ten months after the prime ministerial youth task force all we have after today's announcement, the only new announcement, is the establishment of yet another task force.

These bills before the House represent the deal between the Liberals and the Democrats. The only thing that is consistent in the government's announcements is that they announce the same funding over and over again. There was an opportunity for the Democrats to achieve something, given the extent to which the government demanded, wanted and was desperate to get its sleazy GST up, but this inadequate level of increased funding just shows how cheap the price of the Australian Democrats is.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to traverse the debate again, but I want to place on record that all of the GST revenue is being passed through to the states. They will have access to a growth tax. Therefore, they will have money to spend on state schools, hospitals and housing. So the states, for the first time in a very long time, will have access to a growth tax and all of the GST revenue will go through to them.

debateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 30 June, on motion by Dr Kemp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 implements a number of the government's budget undertakings and, in particular, it provides an additional $36.3 million for the national literacy and numeracy plan and for literacy improvement strategies for the middle years of schooling and $26.4 million for the year 2000 to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy.

speech.para: In the lead-up to the 1999 budget, the Prime Minister raised expectations amongst teachers, state ministers for education, parents and even a number of students who follow debate about education policy matters quite closely. The Prime Minister said on the Neil Mitchell program that the 1999 budget would be an education budget. Having made massive cuts to funding for education, including massive cuts to funding for universities and TAFEs, many people were hoping that the Howard government's 1999 budget would be different.

When it actually appeared, unfortunately, the 1999 Howard budget turned out to be—certainly for education—unbalanced, short-sighted and unfair. The reason that we on this side of the House argue that the 1999 Howard budget could in no way be described as an education budget is that, in the first case, it was unbalanced as far as funding for schools was concerned. The government provided a massive increase in funding for non-government schools, with a minimal increase in funding for students at government schools across the nation, so it was unbalanced.

It was unfair because the government abolished the merit based equity scholarships for university students. That was a token program that was established when former education minister Senator Vanstone made the massive $800 million cuts in federal funding for universities. Yet, the Prime Minister in his education budget abolished those merit based equity scholarships, so kids from poor families, rural backgrounds and non-English speaking backgrounds would no longer be able to receive those scholarships. In fact, the $700,000 that the Prime Minister has spent on renovations to the Lodge and Kirribilli could have paid for 200 of those scholarships for kids from needy backgrounds. So we would certainly say that it was not only unbalanced in the way it funded schools but also unfair in the way the merit based equity scholarships for kids from poor backgrounds who wanted to attend university were concerned.

It was also short-sighted because in this so-called education budget no money was found to restore growth funding for TAFEs. Of course, as we have raised on many occasions, the government is continuing to cut back the Commonwealth government's investment in education, training and research. In the last year of the Labor government, Commonwealth investment in education, training and research hit three per cent of gross national product. I have met many people involved in schools, TAFE colleges, universities and vocational training who would argue that, even in 1996, an investment of three per cent of the national income of the Commonwealth's budget for education, training and research was not enough. But if three per cent was not enough to be investing in 1996, look where we are today—investment by the Commonwealth government in education, training and research has fallen away to only 2½ per cent in the most recent budget, with the forward estimates showing a further decline to only 2.3 per cent.

I am sure that the students in the galleries today understand that if Australia does not invest more in their education, does not invest more in giving them opportunities to develop their vocational skills for employment, does not invest more in giving them the opportunities to become software programmers or medical researchers who discover the next big breakthrough for diagnosing and curing illness, and does not invest more in giving industrial researchers better ways to produce goods and services in Australia, then Australia's long-term future will be compromised.

Australia needs to invest more in education, training and research. I know my colleague the member for Rankin, with a number of us on this side of the House, has played a very close role in putting together the figures that demonstrate quite clearly that the 1999 Howard budget—the so-called education budget—was actually a retreat in the Commonwealth's effort for investing in education, training and research.

The point to make is that the government's legislation which is currently before us does a couple of things for schools. I will turn first of all to literacy. I will say a few things about literacy this afternoon, but the first point to make is that we currently have in Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, a person who believes that getting political coverage and grandstanding on literacy are more important than actually improving literacy in Australian schools. That is not the view just of the Labor Party. Speak to Liberal Party state ministers for education around the country and they will point out that in the current Commonwealth minister for education we have a person who uses literacy every time he is placed under pressure.

talk.start.para: —You would spend a lot of time trying to confirm that.

—We will challenge the member for Macquarie to indicate what his views are on these issues because I would like to contrast the views of the member for Macquarie with the views of, for example, the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education, Mr Phil Gude, who, on 15 September 1997, described Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, as a spin doctor on literacy matters. In a media release on 24 September 1997, he said, `This is typical schoolyard bully stuff.' On Four Corners a few weeks ago, on 9 August 1999, Phil Gude, the Liberal Minister for Education, said:

speech.para: Well I think what he was clearly trying to do was to gain a profile on an issue, and I thought it was not cricket if you like . . . to use the kids . . .

talk.start.para: —Are you opposing—

—These are not my words; these are the words of your colleague the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education. Let me give the member for Macquarie the full quote again. On Four Corners , on 9 August 1999—a few weeks ago—Phil Gude, Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, said:

speech.para: Well I think what he was clearly trying to do was to gain a profile on an issue, and I thought it was not cricket if you like . . . to use the kids, use the teachers, use the profession in that way. I've found in my life that honesty has never got me into any trouble.
The interviewer asked Mr Gude:
You accused him at the time . . . [of] `Deliberately and mischievously manipulating data to portray literacy at a perilous level'?

To which Mr Gude answered, `Yes, I did . . . because I believe that's what was done.' There you had the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education saying, `Yes, Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, the minister for education, deliberately and mischievously manipulated data to portray literacy at a perilous level.'

talk.start.para: —A damning indictment.

—It is a damning indictment when the minister for education's own colleagues point out the truth about his attempts to use literacy to advance his own political career rather than to try to make sure that Australian kids have a better chance to improve their literacy skills.

speech.para: It has always amazed me that the federal minister for education would support state governments actually cutting back the number of teachers trying to help students to improve their literacy and numeracy. It has always amazed me that the minister for education would support conservative state governments which have actually reduced the number of teachers who are out there. We were just talking about Victoria. Mr Gude has presided over a reduction of 9,000 teachers in the state of Victoria—9,000 fewer teachers, 9,000 fewer people able to work one-on-one with those students who might be having difficulty with literacy and numeracy.

How can Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, argue that you can improve literacy for Australian kids by having fewer teachers available to sit down and work with students to resolve their problems? It is our contention that if the federal government were prepared to work cooperatively and try to develop a spirit of bipartisanship in improving literacy, then we would do a lot better than by using bullying and headline grabbing as Dr Kemp, the minister for education, has sought to do.

The most recent development is that the states have now sidelined the federal minister for education. We had an announcement on 4 August by the Labor government in New South Wales, the Liberal government in Victoria, the Liberal government in South Australia and the Liberal coalition government in the ACT that they would be undertaking nationally comparable tests, with the Labor government in Queensland to participate from next year. All of this completely excludes the federal minister for education. We welcome that the states are doing what Dr Kemp could never achieve. The states are getting together to make sure—

talk.start.para: —It was a Commonwealth initiative.
—So it was a Commonwealth initiative, was it? I hate to tell the member for Macquarie—
—The member for Dobell will ignore the member for Macquarie.

—I know he is testing your patience, Mr Deputy Speaker, but we do our best to educate members such as the member for Macquarie. We do our best to try to make sure that they understand that it is their own coalition colleagues who have sidelined the minister for education.

speech.para: It is certainly true that the federal minister for education stands up in this House and claims credit for the fact that the states have sidelined him and that the states have now established comparable tests in literacy. But I make the point that these are not tests that have been developed by the federal minister for education. These are tests that have been developed in spite of the federal minister for education. These are tests that Labor and Liberal states have put together through a spirit of cooperation. If the minister for education were more interested in advancing that cooperation and spirit of bipartisanship rather than seeking to grab headlines for himself, then even more progress could have been attained.

You would almost think that there was no focus on literacy until the federal minister for education came along. That completely ignores the fact that as far back as 1987 New South Wales was conducting basic skills testing. In Victoria and South Australia, it has been taking place since 1995. Since his first day as the minister for education, the member for Goldstein has sought to use literacy as a platform for self-promotion. He has dishonestly portrayed the National Schools English Literacy Survey, set up under the Working Nation plan of the federal Labor government, as his own initiative. The member for Goldstein has never acknowledged that $17 million was provided in 1995 and 1996 under the former government's early literacy program.

He has also never acknowledged that he manipulated the results of the NSELS in order to manufacture a crisis atmosphere. Of course, he was not happy with the initial results that were produced by that study so he had the figures redone to produce his own benchmark figures, which then allowed him to go on 60 Minutes—a disgraceful performance—in September 1997, where he suggested that there was some massive conspiracy between the teacher unions and state departments of education to cover up the fact that one-third of all kids cannot read and write properly. If that were true, how does the minister explain the results that have been coming through since the mid-1980s in states like New South Wales? How does the minister explain that his own Liberal colleagues, in states where his party has been in control, completely reject the bogus conclusions that he has developed? It is quite clear that on literacy more progress needs to be made.

Just before I leave the matter of literacy, there is the important issue of parents working with their children to improve their literacy by sitting down at night and reading to their kids. Reading in the morning rather than letting their children watch TV would also help. A few minutes ago in this House we had a parliamentary secretary arguing that the government's new GST and its rebate for books will mean that education is now GST free. This bill provides funding for schools because it says there should be more money going into literacy. But what the government cannot deny is that its GST legislation places a 10 per cent tax on books such as this one—Test your child's reading level 3—that parents can use. A parent in your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, can purchase this book at a bookshop in your electorate and work to improve their child's reading, assess the level of reading that their son or daughter may have and then work with their teachers to try to improve it. All of these books will have a 10 per cent GST placed on them. None of these books will qualify for the rebate if they are purchased by a parent, and it is completely misleading for the government to claim that education will now be GST free—let alone the GST that will be imposed on the uniforms, the bus fares, the lunches and all of the other expenses that parents have in making sure their children get a good education.

I would like to turn to the second element of the bill that seeks to provide $26 million for the year 2000 to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy. We note that the minister's praise for this program and its value in developing cultural understanding and skills for participation in the global economy never includes recognition that this was established under the former Labor government, with strong support from governments such as the Goss government in Queensland. It was through the cooperative efforts of the federal and state governments in those days that these Asian language programs were introduced in schools right across Australia.

This is no surprise, given that the current federal minister for education also takes credit for other Labor government initiatives such as the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and the Jobs Pathway program. He actually told the House in question time on 25 August that the Jobs Pathway program had been established by the coalition—a complete and utter falsehood. This minister tries to take credit for the good ideas of others when he has never had a single good idea himself.

We believe this minister has an obsession with undermining our great public institutions—our universities, our TAFE colleges, our government schools. This minister has an ideological agenda about shifting education as far and as quickly as possible from our great public institutions into private institutions. It is effectively a privatisation of education. The point we make is that it is not the way the future of education in Australia should go.

The other point is that on budget night there was a commitment from the minister to provide an additional $77.7 million for teacher professional development. `Teacher professional development' rang a little bell. While we welcome these funds, we have to point out that it was the former Labor government and not the Howard government that introduced funding for professional development for teachers. But it was the coalition that broke its 1996 election promise to continue to fund the professional development programs that the Keating and Hawke governments had funded.
Mr Nairn interjecting—

talk.start.para: —So you do concede your promise on professional development funding was broken? I thank the member of Eden-Monaro for that concession. You promised in 1996 to provide professional development funding, and you broke that promise. In this budget you again promised $77 million for teacher professional development, but where is it? This is the bill that funds budget announcements from the 1999 budget. There is money there for literacy in middle years, there is money for rolling over the Asian language strategy, but where is the money for teacher professional development? That is the money that will give us the best chance to raise the quality of teaching in our schools, that will help teachers update their skills to make sure that they have the latest training and the latest information at their fingertips and that they are providing the best possible quality of education to students in schools right across the country. Where is it? We are entitled to ask.

speech.para: This is the bill that implements budget promises. The sum of $77 million was promised for professional development for teachers to increase the quality of teaching in our schools, but it is not in this bill. So this afternoon we challenge the federal minister for education to tell us where the money has gone. Where is the $77 million that was promised for professional development for teachers? The coalition broke the promise in 1996 to continue the Labor government's funding for professional development for teachers. Again the government promised $77 million in this budget, but it is not in this bill. So, as he enters the chamber, we challenge the minister for education: tell us what happened to the $77 million, David, for professional development for teachers. You broke the promise in 1996 and there is no money in this bill that implements the budget promises for the professional development of teachers. The point we make is that this money needs to be committed now so that the money can be allocated from 1 January next year.

While the minister is in the chamber, let me set a question for the minister—a question that every primary school student who might be in the gallery here today can answer. What is 32 minus four? Every student in the gallery could tell us that it is 28. When David Kemp, the federal minister for education, subtracts four from 32 he gets 33. In this House he told us there was an increase in new apprenticeships from 204,000 to 232,000 and that that was an increase of 33,000. Do you remember that, Minister? Two days ago the minister said that 32 minus four is 33. You would fail a primary school student who made that mistake. We say this minister has failed on many occasions in the way that he has manipulated and distorted statistics. He is the person who needs some numeracy education, and today I am prepared on behalf of the Labor Party to fund a numeracy remedial course for this minister of education. We will pass the hat around to fund a remedial course in numeracy for this federal minister for education because he does not know that 32 minus four is 28 and not 33.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
—I inform the House that the Minister for Sport and Tourism, the Hon. Jackie Kelly, is ill and will be absent from question time today. The Minister for Defence will answer questions on her behalf.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Community Services. Minister, I refer you to the report released last week by the Australian National Audit Office entitled Managing data privacy in Centrelink . Didn't the report criticise Centrelink for breaches of privacy, including the insecurity of clients' paper files, the emailing of confidential client information, the downloading of client data for possible sale and the photocopying of customer credit cards with full details and expiry dates? In light of this damning report, if you were one of the 6½ million Australians who are Centrelink customers, would you be assured of the security of your private details?

—I thank the member for Lilley for his question. Yes, I am aware of the ANAO report that was tabled last week. There were 11 recommendations. Six of the recommendations have already been evaluated by Centrelink, and they will be endorsing the lot.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of the June quarter national account figures released this morning by the Australian Bureau of Statistics? What do the national accounts indicate about Australia's economic performance?

—I thank the honourable member for Macquarie for his question. Today's national accounts for the June quarter showed that growth had moderated for the quarter to 0.2 per cent but showed an average growth throughout the year of 1998-99 as a very strong 4½ per cent. Four and a half per cent was a little above the government's forecast in the May budget of 4¼ per cent and indicates that during the year 1998-99 Australia grew faster than G7, OECD and regional economies. The government has been anticipating a slowdown from 4½ per cent plus rates of growth in 1999-2000. In the May budget, we forecast growth of the order of three per cent. The 0.2 per cent for the June quarter came on the back of a revision upwards of the March quarter to 1.4 per cent, showing trend growth of around 0.9 per cent, which is consistent with those forecasts for 1999-2000.

answer.para: The good news is that the national accounts show that inflation remains subdued in Australia, with the household consumption deflator rising only 0.1 per cent in the June quarter for 1.1 per cent through the year. The government has forecast a slowing in 1999-2000 ahead of a world economic pick-up in 2000-01, which will give external impetus to the Australian economy and allow it to resume somewhat stronger rates of growth in following years as the world economy generally picks up. Today's result is very much consistent with the budget forecast which the government put out. The government will be considering its official forecasts, however, in the context of its midyear review, expected this year to be released in November.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Community Services. Minister, can you explain how 101 confidential social security files were dumped into two wheelie bins belonging to Harry's Hubcaps, a small business in the Queensland suburb of Brendale? They were the types of files which contain personal details of clients, their home address es, details of complaints they had lodged to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, personal correspondence outlining intimate details as well as the final recommendation of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Will the minister urgently investigate and report back to the House on who dumped these confidential files in the wheelie bins, where they came from and why they were not properly secured? Will you immediately institute an inquiry into the breakdown of privacy safeguards within Centrelink and your department?

—As always, I would like to thank the member for Lilley. It is one thing being in the gutter; it is another thing being in the wheelie bin. But I take very seriously the question put forward by the member for Lilley. Indeed, I am aware that there are a number of documentations, including Social Security Appeals Tribunal documents, which I might add are also given to customers and not just to Centrelink officers. These were found in these wheelie bins. I have asked that Centrelink ensure that there are no breaches and that there are adequate and secure disposal procedures. That will be well investigated.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, in recognising the great efforts of the government in ensuring the jobs of thousands of young Australians through the continuation of junior rates, would you inform the House whether any obstacles still remain which could see this deal on junior rates negotiated by the government overturned?

—Our understanding was that the Senate would deal with this matter this week and now we find that, to the convenience of the Labor Party, this issue is not going to be dealt with by the Senate. The shadow minister said this morning that he is having discussions with the Democrats.

answer.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Brisbane!
—The member for Brisbane is defying the chair, and any such defiance will be dealt with.

—Why would you be having discussions with the Democrats if you were going to support the legislation, as it went through this House last week? We find that the Labor Party has been having meetings with the ACTU. What do the ACTU say when asked to comment on the meeting? They say, `No comment.' We are entitled to be suspicious about your approach to this issue, particularly when only a week ago you were getting a dusting over by the very same ACTU that yesterday said `no comment' on the issue. There are four members of the shoppies union in the Senate—three of them in the Labor Party, two ex-state secretaries; people dependent on the shoppies for their preselection—and there is every reason to believe, as we believe, that the Labor Party is looking at what it can do to backtrack on last week's deal.
—Last week you moved our amendments.
—I take the interjection. He said that last week he agreed to his amendments.
—No, you moved our amendments.

—Your amendments. Let us accept that they are your amendments. Why would you be contemplating with the Democrats what will transpire in the Senate if you are not thinking of moving away from your so-called amendments? I think it is great that you think they are your amendments.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under what standing order can I raise a point of order when a minister is talking absolute baloney?
—If you don't know, sit down.
—Is there one that enables us to deal with figments of imagination?
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. He is aware that that is not a point of order. He is also aware that the answer is in the hands of the minister.

—If they were fair dinkum on this issue, this bill would have gone through the Senate this week, as understood, without any question about the Labor Party supporting Democrat amendments. The shadow minister said this morning that the Labor Party will not be moving any amendments. But, of course, that is not the game, nor is it the proposal from the shoppies union. It is a simple plan: get the Democrats to plant a poisoned pill in our legislation and in that way claw back from the position that you had.
—That's a lie.

—I will tell you the words that we did agree that were your words. Those words were that we would give an undertaking that, once this issue was dealt with last week, that would be the end of the matter. Those were the words that you put to us. It was fair enough that we would agree to them. Why wouldn't we? We got what we wanted. Why would we not want to see certainty in this issue for employers and young people, knowing that the legislative regime was properly in place? Now we find the Labor Party scurrying around the backdoor talking with the Democrats about what amendments the Democrats are going to be moving.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Is there another standing order that enables me to deal with completely manufactured and preposterous propositions? There must be something there.
—The Leader of the Opposition is well aware of the forms of this House.

—There is no hiding behind the fact that the Labor Party are under a lot of pressure. We know the Leader of the Opposition, from the words of Neal Blewett, has a long history of giving way to the latest bit of pressure put on him. He has had a heap of pressure from the trade union movement and he is sulking around the corridors of this place looking for a clawback for the ACTU as usual.
—You're a liar!
—The member for Batman said:

answer.para: In the world I was brought up in, it also means that when you give your word you honour your word.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The standing orders do say that it is unparliamentary to cast reflections on members, and this absolute lie that he is telling is an absolute reflection on the member for Brisbane and on all of us here who are not doing any of the things which this lunatic is pretending and inventing.
—Order! Was the member for Gellibrand seeking the call?
—I was rising to ask a question. I thought that the minister had finished but, if he hasn't, I will wait.

—I in fact had not responded to the comments made by the Manager of Opposition Business, and I was waiting for the House to come to order. I will recognise the member for Gellibrand in just a moment, as I will the member for Batman. The Manager of Opposition Business has raised a point of order about reflecting on members. I would remind him that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is, as he knows, equally guilty in having used unparliamentary language in reflecting on the minister, and I ask him to withdraw.
—Ask him but not him.

—One issue at a time. I want to indicate to you that I had in fact not interrupted the minister, but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had used unparliamentary language in reflecting on the minister, and I require him to withdraw.
—Are you going to require the minister to withdraw his blatant untruth?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is required to withdraw the statement he made during the ministerial answer, unconditionally.
—I withdraw, but he should too.
—Unconditionally.
—These are blatant untruths, and he knows it. This is a man who cannot be believed.

—This sort of behaviour will not be tolerated. The minister has been unnecessarily provocative, but he has not used the unparliamentary language that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition used. Clearly, that is the reason I asked the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for a withdrawal.
—Mr Speaker—
—I am not inviting the member for Batman to ask a question. Is he seeking the call for a question or to comment?

—Mr Speaker, it goes to the question of the minister deliberately misleading this House. It goes to a question of relevance and parliamentary expectations of balance and truthfulness. My word is my bond.
—We will stick by our word. There has been no change to the Labor Party position. I ask the minister to stop lying to the House.

—I have just witnessed an abuse of parliamentary privilege from both sides of this House, an abuse that will not be tolerated and an abuse that the member for Batman knows he just deliberately exercised. I warn him.
—Mr Speaker, this is a pretty simple issue—
—Mr Speaker, you have not actually ruled on my point of order, unless requiring the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to withdraw constituted ruling on my point of order.

—The point of order of the Manager of Opposition Business was not overlooked and, if he thought it was, I apologise to him. In fact, I had indicated simultaneously that the language used by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was distinctly unparliamentary. That was not a distinction that could be made about the language used by the Leader of the House.
—Mr Speaker, just to clarify my point of order: I was not saying his language was unparliamentary. I was saying it was a reflection on all of us and that we require his lie to be withdrawn.
—The Manager of Opposition Business knows perfectly well that there is nothing that has been said by the Leader of the House that under standing orders he is required to withdraw.

—The Manager of Opposition Business also knows that, if the chair were to require general reflections to be withdrawn, we would be perpetually having comments withdrawn. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made an unparliamentary comment about an individual and I rightly required him to withdraw it. That is entirely consistent with rulings in this place over the 16 years that I have been in this chamber.

—We had an agreement with the Labor Party. I simply make the point that we would like to see the agreement that was reached in this parliament and which was announced publicly, an agreement effectively with the Australian people and particularly young people—

answer.para: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the member be not further heard.
