answer.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —This issue could be settled this week. It could be settled by the bill going through the Senate this week without any changes.
—I move that the member be not further heard.
—The Leader of the Opposition has moved a motion that the chair cannot accept. The House has just divided on that matter.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Speaker's ruling be dissented from.
Government members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition is perfectly able to move a motion of dissent from my ruling if he so desires. That motion currently has precedence. The House will come to order.
—The relevant standing order in relation to closure is standing order 94, which says:

speech.para: A motion may be made that a Member who is speaking, except a Member giving a notice of motion or formally moving the terms of a motion allowed under the standing orders, "be not further heard", and such question shall be put forthwith and decided without amendment or debate.

There is no qualification on that particular proposition. The member concerned here had started speaking again. That was quite clear. There was therefore a gap between the time when the House last considered the matter and the time when I moved the motion. That is the only criteria that ought to apply here. Of course, if I had moved it immediately he stood up, it would not be appropriate. I waited until he had got another couple of his utterly untruthful sentences out and then I moved it.

It is necessary for me to move it—and, I am afraid, to move dissent from your ruling—because what is going on here is a get-up. That is what is going on here as far as this minister is concerned. He has manufactured out of nothing a set of propositions to overcome the smarting he has done from being obliged to accept our position on youth wages. I can comprehend his smarting on this matter, but what I cannot comprehend is why he would want to take it so far by being persistently and deliberately misleading in this chamber. There have been no meetings. The question of who is in control—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—The Leader of the House does not have the call and will not have the call until members on my left exercise some restraint.
—Under the standing orders you are not entitled to allege that someone has been deliberately misleading the House. It should be withdrawn and then we will get on to the debate.
—The Leader of the Opposition has the call and did in fact indicate that he was withdrawing, but it may have been before the microphone was re-engaged.

—I do withdraw, Mr Speaker. But I persist further with the reason why this person should be no longer heard and why it is in the standing orders that he be no longer heard on this matter. There is absolutely nothing in his claim: nothing, no meetings—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—They are the people in control of the agenda in the Senate. Bring on your bill.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Leader of the House has raised a point of order.

—My point of order is that the motion before the chair is a limited one. I do not mind if he wants to go to the substance of the debate in the matters which I raised in my answer, provided that I will likewise be able to express my concerns about the Labor Party's attitude and caving in to a bit of pressure on this issue.
—Mr Speaker—

—The Leader of the Opposition does not as yet have the call. The Leader of the House has raised a point of order. There is some validity in the Leader of the House's point of order and the chair finds itself in some difficulty in ruling on a point of order on a matter of dissent from the chair's ruling. I would invite the Leader of the Opposition to confine his remarks more directly to the motion before the House.

—Yes, Mr Speaker. But, of course, in the process of moving a motion that a person be not further heard, one ought to have a few reasons for it, I suppose. And in those circumstances it would be pretty reasonable to explain myself in that regard. It is a very easy explanation.
—The Leader of the Opposition will in fact refer to the motion before the House, which is not a matter of whether or not anyone be heard; it is a motion to dissent from the chair's ruling.

—Mr Speaker, dissent from your ruling revolves around both the action of the minister in this regard and also, of course, the standing orders themselves. There is no qualification on the standing orders. There is no qualification which says that once a person has begun speaking again, you cannot move a motion that a person be not further heard. There may be an anticipation that that would not be frequently applied. In the course of standing orders on any particular day, there would be that anticipation that such a motion would not be repeatedly moved against a particular member.

speech.para: But of course this set of standing orders was written by somebody who did not have in the House the current Leader of the House, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. It would not be within the experience of the people who wrote that particular standing order that one would see in this House a person so mendacious in the way in which he presented himself and government policy on these matters. So perhaps there is a weakness in the standing orders, as the advent of the minister for workplace relations in this place could not have possibly been considered by any reasonable person when drafting the standing orders but, unfortunately, the accident has happened. The accident having happened, the standing orders have to be thoroughly tested. The standing orders have to be thoroughly tested in the way in which they are being tested here.

It would have been—even though these standing orders are silent on the matter—unreasonable for me to have immediately moved a motion to no longer hear this particular minister. Therefore, it was necessary to wait for a moment or two—as any reasonable person ought to have been reassured that the views we have on this matter were firm and being proceeded with—so that we could hear the first two sentences of the minister. He could have said words to the effect of, `Oh well, despite the fact that I have wandered around the place misleading, in my usual mendacious way, I now accept the assurances from the Leader of the Opposition that I am talking complete baloney.' But because he was unable to stand up and confess that he was talking complete baloney, it became necessary for us to again move that he no longer be heard. And the standing orders protect the capacity of members of this House—which is why I am moving this dissent from the chair's ruling—to be able to deal with members who are standing up and talking complete baloney in this place in the way in which the minister for workplace relations was doing.

Mr Speaker, you have a problem. You have a problem that you have to preside over these standing orders, which were drafted without the anticipation of the arrival in this place of the minister for workplace relations. You somehow have to attempt to deal with the problem of a minister who has engaged in the most extraordinary piece of fantasising for political purposes which any of us have seen in this place. It really makes you wonder whether this is a person you could possibly hold a discussion with, let alone deal with in this particular area. Mr Speaker, you have to preside over this set of circumstances in which we have an unusual minister in this place—a person who is prepared to stand up and, without one jot or tittle of evidence, use the cowards' castle of question time, which normally gives ministers the capacity to say anything they like.

This minister is on notice and the government is on notice: they are not going to be able to stand up in this place and say anything they like. When they choose to stand up in this place and persist, despite the fact that they are getting from across the chamber total denial of what they are talking about, then the full force of the standing orders available will be used to deal with them. We will deal with them in the way the standing orders permit us to deal with them.

We took a sensible decision on these matters underpinning a number of aspects of the development of our policy and we obliged the minister to come to the party. He has been smarting since he has been obliged to come to the party, but standing order 94 could never have anticipated that a person dragged kicking and screaming to a conclusion would then decide to stand up in this place, in order to try to bogusly get ground back, and accuse his political opponents, without a jot or tittle of evidence, of something that he conjured up in his own mind for political advantage.

Why would he do that? Why would standing order 94 have to be put in place in this regard? He is absolutely determined to convey the impression, as far as this is concerned, that he has got what he wants. He is absolutely determined to convey that impression when he knows he has not got what he wants. He knows he is not going to be able to oblige the Industrial Relations Commission to mandate youth wages wherever a young person is employed in an industry. He knows that, much against his will, the freedom of action of the umpire has been preserved.

This is indeed embarrassing for this particular minister. Therefore, it was necessary for him to confect in his mind a crisis and hope that the gullible in the media will think that something is on when nothing is on. He will hope that the gullible in the media and public will think that there are meetings taking place on this matter between the shadow minister for industrial relations and the Democrats, which is completely untrue. He would think that it is the Labor Party delaying the consideration of these matters in the Senate when, in fact, the Senate is, as usual, bogged down by the incompetence of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate. He would expect the gullible in the media to accept at face value that that is the situation that is taking place.

We have standing order 94 to deal with these mendacious performances. That is why we have standing order 94. It permits a member in this place, when dealing with somebody talking absolute garbage, to take out the trash can, to take the garbage out in the wheelie bin, by ensuring that the person is no longer heard. That is what that standing order permits us to do. It permits us to do it at any time, except perhaps in the very reasonable circumstance of moving it immediately after a particular resolution on the matter had been considered. It would not, Mr Speak er, in moving dissent from your ruling, have been appropriate for me, having had the matter determined immediately before, to have stood up and moved it again.

In those circumstances, I thought it would be useful for me to wait for a moment or two and hear the minister say, `I have tried my little trick on this matter and I now accept that my cover has been blown. There have been no discussions whatsoever between the opposition and others on this particular matter. The fact that I was obliged to get up and move the opposition's amendments to my particular bill still stands. That is the situation which continues to apply. I accept that now. It is a nice try on. That is the sort of thing I like to do—wander around and throw the odd bomb and see who it blows up on and hope desperately it blows up on my opponents rather than on me.' On this occasion what we have seen is a minister taken out by friendly fire—in this case his own; the fire is not friendly from our side.

I find from advice from my Senate colleagues that what has been occurring in the Senate is that the ALP has been ready and willing to vote on the junior wages issue since Monday night but we have not been given the opportunity to do so.
Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Batman has already been warned.

—I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition is obliged to be relevant to the question at hand. If it is his view that he would be prepared to see the legislation go through this week without change then he now has the opportunity to say so.
—What point of order does the Leader of the House have?
—He cannot help himself. He blusters in here and says, `You move a motion in this place and give us an assurance that you will see this matter passed through this place this week.'

speech.para: Mr Reith interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Again, he uses the same tactic to assume that there was a problem in that regard. Why did you not move it on Monday night in the Senate. What is your answer on that? Have you been hanging on to it for some purpose?
—The Leader of the Opposition knows that he has an obligation to confine his remarks to the motion before the chair.

—That is why I moved and am entitled to move, under the standing orders, closure at any time. This is yet another demonstration of this. We have been in a position to vote on this for a couple of months now. We were in a position to vote on it in the Senate from the moment it came into that place on Monday. Who determines the Senate list? The government determines the Senate list. Why has it not been debated? It is reasonable to ask the managers of government business why they have not brought it on.

speech.para: Now, should I start a process of fantasy? Should my fantasy contemplate the possibility that they have delayed this precisely so that the Leader of the House can try to manufacture a bogus crisis? Is that why the government has not permitted us to discuss these matters in the Senate since Monday night, though they have complete control of the agenda as far as that is concerned? Would it be a fantasy on my part to assume that it was a deliberate strategy being pursued by this particular minister to confect this particular crisis or is it just as usual the bungling, bumbling ways of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, replicated by the bungling, bumbling ways of the Leader of the House in this place?

Mr Speaker, you cannot find anywhere in standing orders a statement which says that this particular motion of closure on a member cannot be moved at any time. There is, I think, a reasonableness test that would apply to it, and that reasonableness test would be that it persistently was being moved in the absence of a continuation of remarks. That would be a reasonableness test. There is, in fact, no reasonableness test here, for that particular test of being reasonable does not apply in these circumstances, either, because we had an opportunity to hear further from him. Unfortunately, Mr Speaker, you are a victim of the other side of the House in this regard. You have been obliged to make a ruling that cannot be sustained by reference to standing orders simply because of the behaviour of the government's bomb thrower; a bomb thrower who manages to throw them without powder so that all that is left is the detonator and, in this instance, the detonator has taken his fingers off with the launch. That is what has happened as far as this particular minister is concerned.

It is a shame that the minister has produced a set of circumstances that oblige us to move dissent from your ruling. But I strongly suspect that after today, Mr Speaker, we will see one of two things happen. Either these standing orders will be altered in order for the government to be able to ram anything through this particular parliament that it likes or the behaviour of this particular minister will be markedly improved. That may be the triumph of hope over experience, but I certainly do not think his colleagues along the frontbench will thank him for raining on their parade during the course of today. It may well be that the general public finds this tedious, but what we will get out of this is a few standards from this minister.

talk.start.para: —I very happily second the motion because the standing orders make the right of the Leader of the Opposition to move this motion very clear. But we do have some sympathy for your position, Mr Speaker, because we know that nobody who proposed these standing orders would have envisaged anybody behaving like this. Alfred Deakin, when he proposed this particular standing order, never envisaged anybody would behave like this, particularly because you should not have exercised the discretion you have in interpreting the standing orders in the way you have. You have created an opportunity for this person, who knows what he says is not true because he is also the Leader of the House. He is also the person who gets advice about how the legislative program is going in the Senate.

speech.para: I used to be the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate. We used to communi cate with the Leader of the House all the time about how the business was going in the other chamber. They would have told the Leader of the House that the RFA Bill has been dragging on all week, that the youth wages bill is next, that we are ready to debate it and that when the Democrats proposed sending it to a committee we said, `No, we're ready to go now.' On Monday we said that, today we say that. Tuesday, today, any day you want—bring it on now. We will vote on it now, and we will be very happy to be judged by our actions. But why has this matter come on? Why is there some speculation that we might change our position? Because he created that speculation. He went out and, on a doorstop, released his own transcript—because nobody else would do so—saying, `I think they might be about to reverse their position.'

talk.start.para: —The Manager of Opposition Business knows he needs to bring his remarks back to the decision.
—Mr Speaker, my point is that you have exercised a discretion, and I am trying to put the argument why it is inappropriate.
—You nonetheless understand the need to focus on the motion which is before the chair.

—I understand that, because failure to do so would be an effective endorsement of someone coming in here creating a circumstance in which they can say things which they know not to be true, in spite of the objections of all the opposition members, and persist. And, if your interpretation is upheld, there is no remaining protection for the opposition in the face of blatant untruths being told by ministers who deliberately fabricate a circumstance in saying that the ACTU thinks this might be right when the ACTU said your comments are an absolute beat-up. The ACTU said it was a beat-up. We say it is a beat-up. If we were supposed to have had a discussion, who was there who thinks you are telling the truth? There was an assertion, Mr Speaker, that we might have had a meeting about this matter with the Democrats. We have not. There has not been a meeting on this matter between our shadow minister and the Democrat shadow minister—none. There has been no contemplation.

speech.para: If we allow this sort of behaviour to continue, we are creating a circumstance in which this Kamasutra Pete can come in here, have all sorts of positions on everything and lower the standards of the place even further than he has already done. He, I remind you Mr Speaker, is the person who is supposed to assist you in the management of the place because he is the Leader of the House. The standing orders never envisaged a circumstance where an individual would come in and, knowing that it is within his capacity to have the matter dealt with, try to make an issue out of the fact that it is not being dealt with. He knows there has been no discussion. There has been no meeting.

talk.start.para: —He said it publicly this morning.
—You have been eating magic mushrooms again, Pete. You are imagining it. You are hallucinating.

speech.para: Government members interjecting—
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Manager of Opposition Business has the call. The House will come to order.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—We suspect that the problem is that he cannot stand the fact that there has been an agreement. He has to foment conflict. When there is agreement, he has to overturn it so that there is a bit of conflict again, so that he can adopt a new position and try to find some new way of scoring political points. He was horrified at the fact that he has been forced to do something in the national interest. Youth wages has been an issue he has been playing with as a political toy since 1996. He has been playing political games with it and he has suddenly found that his toy is going to be taken away from him. So he comes in here—

speech.para: Mr Downer interjecting—

talk.start.para: —and deliberately fabricates a circumstance—

speech.para: Mr Crean interjecting—

talk.start.para: —which he then seeks to exploit at question time.
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—He deliberately exploits it at question time. He cannot stand there being an agreement.

speech.para: Mr Downer interjecting—
Mr Crean interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I have in the past described negotiating with this Leader of the House as being—
—Order! I warn the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—We have previously described trying to hold discussions with the Leader of the House as `amiably useless'. The only thing that I would change now is that it is not going to be very amiable from here on in, because you cannot take his word. Nobody in Australia and nobody on that side of the House takes his word. The member for La Trobe has left because he probably does not want to have to vote on a motion in support of him—and I do not blame him. Nobody over there believes that the word of this minister counts for anything. And why? Because they have to deal with him more often than we do. He probably tells them they are going to go home on time. Leaders of the House have been known to do that.

speech.para: This is a very serious circumstance. The standing orders say that this is a motion that can be moved at any time. The House of Representatives Practice refers to the circumstances in which discretion might be exercised about accepting that motion, but it certainly does not envisage this circumstance; that is, the circumstance in which the opposition has been confronted with deliberate, provocative, misleading, wantonly irresponsible and untrue statements by a minister commenting on a circumstance which he himself has entirely fabricated, and then coming in as if that fabrication, which he has made and distributed himself, were a fact and then seeking to comment on those `facts'. It is as if he thinks, `If I say it, it must be true. If I invent this circumstance, it is now a fact upon which I can comment.'

There is no justification for this at all. He starts his statement by saying, `I have great fears,' but there is no basis for it. He does not say it might be true; he does say, `We now know that the Senate is not going to deal with the issue this week.' How does he know it? Because the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate told him, and he would have told him why. The RFA Bill is going on and on, not because of us—we are ready to vote on that too—but because Senator Brown has been going on and on. And they would have told this person, the Leader of the House, the facts of it. They would have told this person that, when it was proposed to send this bill off to a committee, we said, `No. Let's deal with it here.'

We are ready to deal with that bill now. We were ready yesterday and we were ready on Monday and, if you move a motion to bring it on, we will do it. I was Manager of Government Business in the Senate and I know who sets the schedule by which bills are dealt with, and that is your problem. Every morning, they ask the Manager of Government Business, `What sequence do you want the bills dealt with in?' And you have a discretion. You can say, `I want Youth Wages first today,' and nobody can do anything about it. The opposition cannot stop you; the minor parties cannot stop you. All you have to say is, `That is what I want.' Any morning you could have rung up Ian Campbell and said, `Put the youth wages bill on now,' and it would have been on.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Manager of Opposition Business knows that we are straying a little from the dissent motion.

—It is absolutely why the discretion which you exercised was an inappropriate exercise of that discretion, because he knows—or should know and is in a position to know—that everything he said is untrue. He said it deliberately and he persisted in saying it up to the point at which—

—I have a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Manager of Opposition Business is in breach of standing orders, being unparliamentary. The fact is that we have asked them two of three times to put on this bill in the Senate this week and we have been told no on every occasion.
—The Leader of the House has made his point of order and will resume his seat. The Manager of Opposition Business will withdraw any reference to the Leader of the House deliberately misleading—

—I did not say `deliberately misleading'. I said he said something untrue that he knew was untrue. That is not unparliamentary; it is fairly standard. And I will say it again: he knew it was untrue and he repeated it.
—The Manager of Opposition Business understands that that does nothing to elevate the debate, but he has the call.

—I regret that it is true, but what I have said is nevertheless a fact. It is very bad for the parliament that it is so. Nevertheless, the Leader of the House knows, or should know, that the government can set the schedule every day. He is saying that we would not gag the RFA Bill, and that is true. They never would when they were the opposition. No opposition ever does in the Senate. That is not the way it works. But they could have deferred the RFA Bill and put this on ahead every day.

speech.para: If we do not stand up on this occasion and say that we must in these extreme circumstances have the right to move motions like this, the opposition is down to no rights at all. Remember, Mr Speaker, that we tried other avenues to protect ourselves from this deliberately untrue remark by this minister. We tried to say that saying that we were all telling an untruth was a reflection and we sought to have it withdrawn. You said it was not, and I do not dissent from that ruling. You said that we did not have that manner of protection of ourselves from this deliberate, wanton, untrue statement by this man.

If we do not have that protection, what alternative do we have? We can say that he should not be allowed to continue to do this and so we moved that motion, but he persist ed, and so we moved it again. If we cannot do that, there is no mechanism that prevents the opposition from being harangued in this misleading, untrue way by this man every day. You are stripping away the last protection we had. If saying that we are going to do something which we are absolutely not going to do, and if saying we are going to breach our word when we are going to keep it, and if saying that we are going to act dishonourably when we are going to act honourably is not a reflection, we have no other protection but this.

If this ruling of yours is upheld—this interpretation of standing order 94 which, on its face, says quite clearly that the Leader of the Opposition or any other member can move this motion at any time, other than when someone is raising a point of order or making a personal explanation—then we are in the circumstance where there is no protection left. We absolutely need, and every opposition that is ever confronted by someone of this type—someone whose word is so worthless, someone who cannot be relied on in any way—will require in future, the protection of standing order 94. There is no other.

This is a circumstance which, as I say, I am sure the people who previously had to interpret the standing order never had to envisage. Let us think about the circumstance and the consequence of it because, if this ruling is upheld, these circumstances can continue—that is, someone can fabricate a story like this, can come in and tell lies about that thing which he has fabricated, reiterate them in here and persist in telling lies about every opposition member and reflect on the standing of every opposition member with no recourse in the hands of the opposition. Why did anybody expect that we would sit idly by and allow that to happen? Why would anybody accept that we would just sit here passively complaining?

The other form of complaint we have is one which is also in breach of the standing orders and for which we might serially be thrown out, because the statement which you required the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to withdraw, I have to say, Mr Speaker, has been stated by all of us. I will collectively withdraw on behalf of us, but we all said it and we all meant it. It is clear that this person has no respect for the truth and no respect for telling the truth in this House. This person does not even understand the significance of the fact that, when he is caught out for not telling the truth, he might at least have the dignity and the grace to sit down and shut up. But he went on and on. If this ruling is sustained, Mr Speaker, there will be no protection for the opposition against any such arrant nonsense and deliberate untruth in this House and these sorts of attacks on the opposition which flow from that.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, the government obviously will support the ruling which you gave. It was a sensible one. It passed the reasonableness test, which is a fair guide, and, as I will demonstrate in a moment, it is also entirely in accordance with standing orders. That should be no surprise, Mr Speaker, given your comprehensive understanding of the standing orders. You certainly have a better understanding of them than anybody on the other side.

speech.para: Let me start by saying that today we have seen the death throes of the Leader of the Opposition. Today we have seen the most disastrous tactics by an opposition that have no policies, no direction, no idea of what they are doing and, to boot, are 10 points behind in the polls and very worried about that as well. We have an opposition leader who is a sucker to the last person who pressured him into a policy position different from the one that he had last week. This is a man who for years and years as a member of the Hawke-Keating government could never withstand a bit of pressure from a student group, from a bureaucrat, from a trade union leader, from an ALP member—he had a policy for each and every one of them and a different policy at that.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Leader of the House has an obligation to confine his remarks, so far as the previous remarks have been confined, to the motion before the chair.

—Well, Mr Speaker, let them move their motions that I be not further heard. Let them move an amendment to standing orders to make me the first member of the federal parliament who was such a threat to the other side that a special standing order was required to deal with me—the Reith standing order. I thank them for their quiet compliment, I am sure they would think undeserved.

speech.para: I have seen a lot of ridiculous and stupid stunts during question time over the years, but this one takes the cake. Question time is when the opposition ask the government questions. There are 10 issues that an opposition that could organise itself might be able to think up for question time. But, no, it has decided—and I thank it for it—that the issue today is whether or not the opposition will be able to stick to a deal, an agreement, that it agreed to last week in this parliament.

Let me deal briefly with the formalities—a moment will suffice to put away the motion of dissent. We should note—not that anybody would know it from listening to the two speakers—that the motion is a dissent from your ruling that you would not accept a further motion, namely, that I be not further heard. I was asked a question and I was giving an answer, expressing my concerns that the Labor Party might overturn a deal. I would have thought that was pretty simple and I will go through my reasons for saying so.

The Labor Party then moved the extraordinary motion that I be not further heard and, as a result of that motion being put, it was defeated. When a motion has been defeated, I think it would be fair to say that it is rather repetitious to put it up again, especially when you know you do not have the numbers and you are not going to win it. It is clearly an abuse of process not to accept the umpire's ruling when we have had a ruling, it has been voted on and the motion has been put down.

Not only does that proposition pass the reasonableness test—in other words, the House has just voted that I should be able to continue to speak, so naturally enough it would be reasonable for you not to accept yet another motion on exactly the same subject—but I had got out only three sentences. The three sentences, which were described as a lie by the Leader of the Opposition, were to the effect that we could easily settle this matter if you pass the youth wages bill this week and that, if my concerns are right, that would not be a problem for you, to which the interjections were, `Lies, lies' and `Shock, horror!'

There was displayed an incredible sensitivity which, from my long experience, suggests that they have been looking for a deal. They say they are not. Well, that's great. If they are now saying that this legislation will go through this House, I can assure you, Mr Speaker, no-one will be happier than I if we can secure the jobs of hundreds of thousands of young people. That has been our policy for years. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition, all the way back in 1992, knew that the ACTU's position on this was a bad position. Very expressive remarks were relayed to us, courtesy of Neal Blewett's book, that years ago the Leader of the Opposition knew the ACTU's position was wrong but for seven years he was not prepared to act on the issue. He was not prepared to act on the issue, until he felt the heat of public opinion which would obviously support the government's position to ensure that young people can keep their jobs. It was not the light of day that he saw last week, it was the heat of political pressure, and no-one bends more quickly or further than the Leader of the Opposition under a bit of political pressure.

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the House will come to the motion.
—Mr Speaker, on the question of the standing orders, in support of your ruling, I refer you to standing order 169:

speech.para: Subject to the provisions of standing order 233, the Speaker or the Chair may, in his or her discretion, disallow any motion or amendment which is the same in substance as any question, which, during the same session, has been resolved in the affirmative or negative.

In other words, you cannot just put it up, have it voted on and then put it up again. That is exactly what has happened here. Mr Speaker, that is why, again, just as a matter of commonsense, now supported by standing order 169, your ruling was entirely fair. Furthermore, Mr Speaker, standing order 86 says:
The following matters are not open to debate . . .
(g) Motion that a Member be not further heard (standing order 94) . . .
Then further on in that standing order it says:

Should any of these questions be negatived, no similar proposal shall be received if the Speaker or the Chair is of the opinion that it is an abuse of the orders or forms of the House, or is moved for the purpose of obstructing business.

talk.start.para: —An absolutely open-and-shut case.

—An absolutely open-and-shut case. You could not get it clearer. No special Reith amendment is required here. This has been clear since the opening of the federal parliament in 1901—clear to everybody except the Labor Party. Certainly, Mr Speaker, it completely substantiates the commonsense of your ruling. In the event that anybody requires the matter to be put further beyond doubt—and none on our side would but maybe there are some on the other side—if you go to House of Representatives Practice , it says:

speech.para: The Speaker has the discretion to disallow any motion or amendment which is the same in substance as any question which has been resolved in the affirmative or negatived during the same session.
So, again, Mr Speaker, not only according to the printed word in the standing orders but also in House of Representatives Practice , your ruling was entirely fair.

Quite frankly, on this side, we are entirely bemused as to why you would take this matter as far as you have. We can only think that it portrays some sensitivity on the issue. The reason I have been concerned about this issue of junior rates is that obviously it is a big issue. The trade union movement is very unhappy with the result. I was trembling in my boots on the night before the deal was consecrated in the House—and why? Because they have a long history of giving into the trade unions. And why would I be concerned about that result? Because a lot of young people's jobs actually hang in the balance. A lot of young people need to have the security of having a job and knowing that they will have that job not just through to 30 June next year but also in July and August and every month thereafter.

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the House will bring his remarks back to the motion.

—I was naturally concerned when on two, if not three, occasions we asked the Labor Party whether we could organise affairs in the Senate so that the youth bill could go through, and on each and every occasion we were told no, it could not. That naturally concerned me. It concerned me when the shadow minister told a reporter at 4QR—it was reported on today's radio—that Labor had spoken recently to the Democrats. Why shouldn't I be concerned about that?
—What's so remarkable about that?
—I will tell you what is remarkable about that. If your position is that the agreement, as it is going through, will go through without any change, why would you talk to the Democrats?

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Brisbane! The Leader of the House will bring his remarks back to the motion. A great deal of latitude has been allowed in this debate both to the Leader of the Opposition and to the Leader of the House.

—The same sort of latitude has been extended.

speech.para: Opposition member interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, it is a fair point. If you have agreed that the thing will go through chapter and verse, word for word, as it went through last week, why would you be talking to the Democrats? You are supposed to be new and liberated. Mr Speaker, they are supposed to be liberated. This is the New Labor Party—`We're going to stand up for principles.' This is the party that, 13 years after doing nothing for workers, suddenly reckons that it wants to help workers. This is the Labor Party that is finally interested in whether or not we have a surplus, the same party that for years gave us deficits. This is the New Labor Party that is pure as the driven snow. It will not have agreements with other parties, even though it did an agreement with me only last week. I think any reasonable person would say, `Well, if the Labor Party is talking to the Democrats about youth rates, then we are entitled to ask the question, "Are you going to stick to the agreement?"'
—The Leader of the House will bring his remarks back to the motion on the dissent ruling.

—For all the incredible excitement on the other side, we have simply raised that question today. We are entitled, on behalf of young people, to get from you a clear statement as to your position. That is not unreasonable. Certainly it is not unreasonable when we know that you have the ACTU breathing down your neck. When you go over to the Senate, Mr Speaker, you can see the Labor Party front bench in that chamber is full of people who are former shoppies union officials. In fact, you have four if you include Brian Harradine.
—The Leader of the House must bring his remarks back to the dissent motion. Sufficient tolerance has been exercised.
—Complete this sentence and bring it on now.

—I must say that I am absolutely delighted if the consequence of my raising this issue today is our having flushed the Labor Party out. If they are now prepared to secure the passage of this legislation without any changes by the end of this week, then this government will have done a great job for young people. When Senator Ian Campbell asked on numerous occasions this week, `Can we organise it to get the youth employment bill though this week?' the answer from the Labor Party was no, on every occasion.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It must be hard being the Leader of the Opposition because, when you get the blowtorch from one side, you bend one way and you are off talking to the ACTU.
—The Leader of the House will bring his remarks back to the dissent motion or resume his seat.

—Mr Speaker, if I were the Leader of the Opposition and took a position which the ACTU did not like, do you know what I would do? I would stand up and say to their objections: bad luck! That is what I would say.
—The Leader of the House will resume his seat.
—The member for Burke will resume his seat. He did not have the call. The member for Burke now has the call.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The minister has made a complete farce of your position. You have asked him several times to come back to the dissent motion and he has just ignored you. What are you going to do about it?
—The member for Burke will resume his seat. The question is that the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition in dissent of the Speaker's ruling be agreed to.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—
Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Brisbane will resume his seat. I call the Leader of the House.

—Mr Speaker, I have abided by the practice that you have established, and that is that members do not return to the dispatch box until they are called. I have not finished with the Labor Party and I would like the pleasure of doing so.

—The Leader of the House will resume his seat. The Speaker had, on a number of occasions, drawn the attention of the Leader of the House to the motion before the chair and asked him to resume his seat. The member for Burke raised a point of order, and I believe that it is now appropriate for the motion to be put to the House. For that reason, I—

—I warn the member for Watson. I was merely stating the motion to the House. As every reasonable member of the House was aware, the motion that I was stating to the House says that the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition in dissent of the Speaker's ruling be agreed to. I call the member for Brisbane.

That the motion (Mr Beazley's ) be agreed to.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I have completed my answer.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—Is the member for Gellibrand seeking the call?

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House take note of the following paper:
Letter from the Chair of the Committee to examine the use of the term `Drug Free' together with the final Recommendations of the Committee and Explanatory Statement.
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There are forms of the House to enable people to draw the Speaker's attention to any inadequacy they feel in the way the House is being conducted, whether the microphones are turned on or anything else. The form, as every member knows, requires them to do nothing more than rise to their feet and seek the call. This chorus of intervention is totally unacceptable.

interjection.para: Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.
—On page 5 of today's Australian , an article headed `Apology doubts anger banker' states:

speech.para: The banks' top representative, Frank Cicutto, yesterday attacked federal Liberal MP David Hawker for claiming his apology for the John Laws cash-for-comment deal was not genuine.
It then continues detailing an expansive apology not made by him previously. Further on, it says:
"If Mr Hawker and his committee had contacted me I could have confirmed that for them."
Another part of the article states:
. . . Mr Cicutto also attacked the Hawker report for suggesting the banks made unreasonable profits at the community's expense . . .
In his speech yesterday Mr Cicutto also said:
No indication is given as to what constitutes unreasonable profits.

The report he is referring to is the one by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration entitled Review of the Reserve Bank of Australia annual report 1997-1998 , which I tabled last week. Firstly, to address the point about contacting Mr Cicutto, on 22 June I wrote to the Australian Bankers Association, of which Mr Cicutto is the chairman, offering the ABA the opportunity to appear before the standing committee. That offer has not been accepted. Furthermore, in his speech to the Catholic ethics conference and at the following press conference, it was indeed, as stated in the committee's report, unclear as to whether it was an apology for the sin of being found out or whether it represents a genuine intention to take steps to raise the standard of ethical behaviour of ABA members.

talk.start.para: —The member for Wannon must come to the point on which he was misrepresented and not his report.

—Secondly, to address the point regarding unreasonable profits, if Mr Cicutto reads the committee report that was tabled last week he will find on pages 41 and 42 the following quotes from the Governor of the Reserve Bank relating to the governor's views on the problems created by banks closing branches in country areas and unreasonable profits.
—The member for Wannon must come to the point on which he is now misrepresented, not the report.
—Yes, but he said it was the Hawker report, so it is me. I have not finished.
—The member for Wannon will resume his seat. He has indicated where he has been misrepresented. Misrepresentation of his report may reflect on other members as well as on him.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—This morning the Daily Telegraph ran an article based on the assertions made yesterday afternoon in this House by the member for Werriwa. The member for Werriwa asserted that preferential treatment was given to Mr Max Dunbier, the owner of Oakdale Collieries, during the time that I was Premier of New South Wales. I categorically deny any knowledge of preferential treatment to Mr Dunbier or his companies during my time in the New South Wales parliament. In particular, I deny any knowledge of any loan of $1.8 million to Mr Dunbier, any state government contracts or road works beneficial to Mr Dunbier's haulage companies. Further, Mr Dunbier was never part of a fundraising group called The Friends of John Fahey.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.
—I am misrepresented by the member for Macarthur, who has now conveniently forgotten his friends. Max Dunbier participated in a Friends of John Fahey fundraising event—
—The member for Werriwa must indicate where he has been personally misrepresented or resume his seat. The member for Werriwa is warned.
—I have received advice from the Chief Opposition Whip that he has nominated Mr Murphy to be a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in place of Mr Mossfield.
