talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The failure of the government to address the slide in household savings, widening household debt and the worst ever current account deficit.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —On Monday, the Prime Minister claimed Australia as the `miracle economy'. Today's national accounts and Monday's current account figures should send him a wake up call. In all the government's hubris and arrogance, there are fundamental issues that need addressing—our current account, our savings, the composition of our growth and the sustainability of that growth because that is what determines whether or not we get the jobs.

speech.para: Not only are these issues not being addressed, the government will not even talk about them. It will not debate them. The Treasurer will not come into the House and debate the economic policy in this country. He sends his shadow into this place because he will not come and debate the issue.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is a very fulsome shadow, and gets more fulsome by the day. We are commenting about those new suits. It is all for the fitting.

speech.para: The truth of it is that, if we are to achieve sustained economic growth, all of the issues have to be addressed, not only those that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer choose to speak on. The Treasurer will not come into this place and talk about the current account. He will not talk about the increasing imbalance in our economic growth. He will not talk about his decimation of household savings or how he has lumbered households with debt.

That is pretty extraordinary because, prior to 1996, you could not stop him talking about these things. This is the man who gave us the current account measured per hour in nominal terms and the foreign debt measured per person. In a week that has seen our nation's athletes strive for and win gold, the Treasurer has been racking up his own records. He is now the Australian record holder for a record high current account deficit, a record high foreign debt, a record high trade deficit, a record quarterly drop in business expenditure on capital, a record low household savings rate and a record high household debt rate. It is little wonder the cartoonists are lampooning him for the miracle economy.

This is the Treasurer producing world records that he is ashamed of and will not talk about. These records are not the product of an accident; they are outcomes which neither the Treasurer's hubris nor his smirk can ultimately hide. It is the economy that Treasurer Costello will not talk about. It no longer surprises us that he will not come into this place when he is required to and debate it.

This afternoon I want to highlight the Treasurer's wilful economic negligence in failing to heed the wake up call that has been sounding for months now to highlight the economy that he just will not talk about. But we need to look right across the economy, not just stand up and pretend that it is all good and that everyone is a winner. For all the rhetoric of miracles, there are underlying problems emerging in the economy. The benefits of growth are not being shared. This is the current reality. The future reality is that, without a rebalancing of the economy, the growth that he always wants to champion and rave about will not be sustainable. Quite frankly, the bankcard has its limits.

Only this week when the Australian Bureau of Statistics released data on Australia's twin deficits—the current account deficit and the foreign debt—the Treasurer talked about everything but the current account deficit and foreign debt. This is the Treasurer who claims to have fireproofed the economy, but the current account deficit has blown out to a record 9.4 thousands of millions of dollars, to use the Treasurer's preferred linguistic term. One would have thought that he would have heeded his own advice of February 1995, when he said:

I mean, look, my analysis is this . . . my analysis is that this is a government that has completely failed Australia on the current account deficit and produced the highest current account deficit ever, which is a total failure of economic policy. That's my analysis.

But, when asked, the Treasurer simply dismissed the problem saying it was ignorant to use dollar figures. What hypocrisy! Not use dollar figures? Really? He claims it is ignorant today to use dollar figures but what did he say in 1995? I quote him again:

A $1,500 million deficit is better than a $2,000 million deficit, but it's still a deficit—it's a jolly big one. If we were in government, we wouldn't be parading a $1,500 million deficit as a success.
Sounds like dollar figures to me from the Treasurer who now says we cannot talk in them. Why? Because what they are exposing are the flaws in his economic management.

Beyond the hypocrisy, his defence this week to his record current account deficit was, first, to blame the Asian crisis—but this is the same person who trumpeted about having fireproofed us from that same crisis; second, to blame the domestic economy; and, third, to claim the record a success because he had predicted failure and he achieved it. This is a Treasurer who believes success comes from predicting failure. This is a Treasurer who aims low and achieves it. This is a Treasurer not in control of the fundamental issues that need to be addressed so far as the economic management of this country is concerned. On 20 September 1995, the current Prime Minister launched the infamous debt truck.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Do you remember that? That was the truck that broke down on the hill up the Blue Mountains. It is now a B-double. The Prime Minister in relation to that debt truck made two promises to the Australian people.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I would remind some members of the warning that they are under, and it would be most inconvenient for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition if I were to take any other action. Out of deference to him, I call him.
—This is what the Prime Minister had to say in making two promises about that debt truck:

speech.para: I can promise you that we will follow policies which will, over a period of time, bring down the foreign debt.
What a joke. He continued:
Our first priority as Peter Costello and I have made repeatedly clear, our first priority in Government economically will be to tackle the current account deficit.

Two promises? The facts clearly speak for themselves. This week not only did the current account blow out to be 42 per cent higher in 1998-99 than in 1997-98, but Australia's foreign debt grew to be nearly 20 per cent higher in the period that Peter Costello took over the debt truck. As I said before, that debt truck has now been upgraded to a B-double.

The current account deficit is really the manifestation of a more fundamental problem, an imbalance between savings and investment. Without genuine micro-economic policies, social policies and a coherent strategy for employment or a commitment to the future, neither the efficiency nor levels of investment and savings will improve. When the Treasurer slashed programs to help the unemployed, when he raised the costs on families by increasing child-care costs, when he pulled the shutters down on the futures of young Australians by cutting education and when he abandoned policies to increase research and development, he claimed that these would all rescue national savings.

Despite destroying the basis by which we invest in our future, 3½ years later after all of that pain, national savings have barely moved but household savings have plummeted and household debt has skyrocketed. Not content with running down the savings of Australian families, he is now going to lumber them and Australian businesses with a new GST. His advice to families has been eat, drink and be merry, charge it up to the bankcard, but we won't mention the hangover. His response these days is to quote the balance sheet. What he will not tell you, though, is that households are far more susceptible today to changes in external factors. No doubt he will also be claiming that putting families at risk is another one of their successes.

What we have seen under this Treasurer is an increasing imbalance in our growth. Consumption is dominating the composition of it, and it is beating investment by a long way. Whilst one would never begrudge Australians their consumption, and economic sustainability is importantly dependent on it, what we need for prosperity is a better balance between consumption and investment. I will quote someone who believes in that:

You can't run sustained economic recovery without growth in business investment. You can't run it off diminished savings and you can't run it indefinitely off increased consumption and this is where the risk is going to come.

Who said that? None other than the erstwhile Treasurer. This is the Treasurer's assessment about what needs to be the balance in growth, but it is a balance that we are not seeing. The economic facts again speak for themselves. Growth in private investment has slowed under Peter Costello compared to Labor's last three years. Today's figures demonstrate that the contribution of consumption for the quarter is 0.7 per cent but business investment is minus 0.2 per cent and net exports are minus 0.5 per cent. A sustained economy is one that grows from consumption, investment and net exports, but this one is going back wards on the latter two fronts according to the most recent quarterly figures.

Last week, the Treasurer presided over the largest quarterly fall in private expenditure on capital since the ABS series began, and the average annual growth rate since he took over has been minus 0.2 per cent—minus 0.2 per cent in the time that they have held office and he claims that he has got it right. Research and development has been nobbled. Education has fallen dramatically. In short, what we are seeing the Treasurer preside over is nothing other than economic irresponsibility.

What Labor wants to do is this: we want to invest in our people, in their education and in their wellbeing, in their ideas. We want to develop the knowledge economy, invest in our future and share the benefits of growth. We need a return to balance in the economy, to lift savings and to lift investment, to make them more productive and to foster net export growth. The national accounts today ought to be the wake up call, and we hope the government hears it. This is a nation of huge opportunity. But if we continue down this path we will squander that opportunity. Labor repeats its call for a bipartisan approach so that we do not squander that opportunity.

The next important policy issue that this government has to address is business tax reform. Labor's position on this is absolutely clear: call on the government to release that report, not hide it. What are you hiding? Why won't you release it? We want there to be an opportunity for consultation around that report. We want the government to talk with us and negotiate to try to find the common ground. This, like so many of these issues, ought to be above the bickering across this table. It ought to be the basis upon which we do reach agreement, and I can assure you that there are many areas on which we can reach agreement. If we get that agreement, we will guarantee speedy passage for the agreed matters. We could leave it up to the leader of government business in the House to muck up that process, but we would guarantee speedy passage. Getting process right from the start obviates the need for a long Senate process. In this way, we can avoid the mess that the GST got the country into.

These are issues of great national importance for which Labor offers its bipartisan support. The Treasurer has taken us down an unsustainable path. It needs to be corrected. We need a return to balance in our growth. We need to invest in education, training and innovation. We need to invest and save more and invest and save better. The Treasurer must start addressing these issues and deal with them—not strut and remonstrate, not show his hubris and arrogance every time he gets up at question time in the parliament but rather come in here and debate the issues sensibly to find the common ground. Labor stands ready to be a participant in it.

talk.start.para: —We have just had a dissertation from the sand boy—from the guy who runs on to the field and hopes one day to play in the game. Yet again we have heard from the Labor Party how they want to be in there, how they would like to have a bipartisan approach. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes into the House and says, `We want to work in a bipartisan way. We want to be there. We'll guarantee a speedy resolution to the bills before the House.' Why hasn't he the courage to come in here and lay on the table Labor's proposals for business taxation reform? He will not do it. I will tell you why he will not do it: because the Labor Party stand for nothing. They believe in nothing. They have no policies. They have no policy debate. When it comes to taxation and the economy, the Labor Party are bereft of ideas, especially at the leadership level.

speech.para: Let us look at their record. First, the Labor Party ran up budget deficits totalling $70 billion in their last five years of government compared to our surplus budgets, which are starting to pay off the Beazley black hole. Second, Commonwealth general government net debt rose from $16.9 billion in 1990-91 to $95.8 billion when we came to government—from $16.9 billion in 1990 to $95.8 billion when we came to office. We have already repaid $24 billion of their debt. Third, when Labor were in power, business interest rates, as so many small business people know in Australia, went to above 20 per cent per annum in 1989. Today, business interest rates are at their lowest rate in 30 years.

Fourth, unemployment under the Labor Party and specifically under the now Leader of the Opposition as the then minister for employment reached the highest level since the early 1970s of around 11.2 per cent in 1992. So unemployment at a record level was 11.2 per cent. Today it is seven per cent. Fifth, inflation under the Labor Party averaged 5.2 per cent per annum. Today, under the coalition, it is one per cent. And the Labor Party has the gall to come into this House and lecture us about budget deficits and lecture us about unemployment and lecture us about the performance of the economy and lecture us about household debt when in every single case the Labor Party set records when it was in government.

The credibility of your argument today is assessed on your performance in the past. Promises are absolutely meaningless if you do not have the capacity to deliver what you promise. The Australian people on every indicator will ask the Leader of the Opposition and will ask the Labor Party, `How can we believe what you are saying?' You know what, it is a fair question. The punters out there are smart. They know exactly what this mob are up to. They know the hypocrisy and the gall of them coming into this House and lecturing us about the performance of the economy. They know they are telling untruths. They know they are telling half the story. Why? Because seared on the minds of every Australian small business is a 20 per cent interest rate under the Labor Party. Seared on the minds and in the memories of every Australian mortgage payer—the battlers out there—is an interest rate of up to 22 per cent on their household mortgage.

And seared on the minds of a generation of Australians is the performance of the Labor Party on unemployment. When youth unemployment reached 44 per cent, nearly one out of every two young Australians could not find a job under the Labor Party. And 11.2 per cent of the general population could not find a job under the so-called workers' party when they were in government. Yet this mob comes into this House and lectures us about economic performance.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition today decided that he was going to talk about a number of issues, including the current account deficit. He said, `The country is in a slide now.' The Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes into this House and talks about the country being in a slide because of the current account deficit, which came out at 6.2 per cent this week. What he conveniently forgets is that, in 1985-86 under Labor, the current account deficit was 6.5 per cent. In 1989-90 under Labor, the current account deficit was 6.5 per cent. In 1994-95 under Labor, the current account deficit was 6.5 per cent. Today it is 6.2 per cent. Do you know what was said in 1995 when the Labor Party had a current account deficit of 6.5 per cent—higher than what we have now? Ralph Willis, the then Labor Party Treasurer of Australia, came into this House and said:
It is all about improving savings. . .
The policy of the government is to improve national savings by reducing public sector dissavings.

The Labor Treasurer of Australia came into this House and said that the way to solve the current account deficit was to increase government savings. He then went out of this House and lied to the Australian people, along with the Leader of the Opposition, about the state of the government's budget. They said that it was in surplus. They told the Australian people that we had a surplus budget, yet it was $10,000 million in deficit.
Mr O'Connor interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for Corio will withdraw that remark.
—I will consider withdrawing the remark if the minister withdraws his imputation about the Leader of the Opposition lying about the budget deficit.
—The honourable member for Corio will withdraw unconditionally.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, in deference to your position in the chair, I unreservedly withdraw and ask you to ask the minister to do the same.

—I was unsure whether the minister had actually referred to a serving member of the opposition at the time that he made that remark. That is why I allowed that to go through. I would hope that both the honourable member for Corio and the minister will take care in the comments that are made.

—The Australian people will judge him for that sort of activity. It is disingenuous. Everyone knows that the Leader of the Opposition as Minister for Finance pledged a surplus budget during the 1996 election campaign. This follows the words of the Labor Treasurer at the time saying, `The only way to solve the current account deficit is to have public sector savings, that is, run public sector surplus budgets.' The finance minister at the time ran a $10,000 million deficit. That was his solution. Over the course of two budgets, when the current Leader of the Opposition was finance minister, they ran up over $20 billion of government debt at a time when we had a current account deficit higher than it is today.

speech.para: It is hypocrisy. And the Australian people can pick it a mile away. They have a great capacity to see the wood through the trees. They have a great capacity to be able to see through the rubbishy rhetoric that can come out of this place and make a value judgment about whether someone is telling the whole story. So when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes into this House and starts talking about major problems with the current account deficit and about the diminution of household savings, the Australian population out there—the plumbers, the doctors, the lawyers, the factory workers, the farmers, everyone—makes an assessment on how many bucks are coming into their pockets each week, whether they can pay their bills, whether their kids can get into a decent school, whether they can give their kids a holiday each year. They are the sorts of issues that Australian people make a judgment on about the performance of the economy. I ask the Labor Party to speak with Australians and ask them if the economy is in terrible shape.

It so happens that we have got the best performing economy in the world. That is not us saying that. That is every independent analyst. That is Paul Krugman from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's leading economists; the South China Morning Post; the Wall Street Journal; the Economist; Forbes magazine; and every investment banker in New York and London and Tokyo and Hong Kong and Singapore. They are all saying that Australia's economy is the best performing economy in the world. We have done all this when our two most significant trading partners—Korea and Japan—are in recession or depression. We have done it in the middle of the worst Asian economic downturn in history.

Our trading partners have gone into depression and Australia is running the strongest economy in the world. Yet the Labor Party has the gall to come into this place and lecture us about the performance of the economy. They say, `No, no, no, we can do it a lot better.' I heard the words of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He said, `The best way to solve Australia's problems'—which he failed to identify—`is for the government to spend more money on a range of issues.'

The solution is to spend the budget surplus—the budget surplus that has insulated us from the Asian economic downturn, the budget surplus that is repaying Labor debt, the budget surplus that has caused some political hardship on this side but we do it not because we like doing it but because we know it is in the best interests of the country. That is why we do it. The policies on this side of the House are not politically pragmatic, they are in the best interests of Australia. That is why we had the best performing economy in the world during the worst Asian economic crisis ever.

Everything the opposition Labor Party do is aimed at destroying the initiatives we put in place, whether it is taxation reform—which Australians overwhelming support and which they re-elected us with—whether it is junior wage rates, whether it is workplace relations reform, whether it is the sale of Telstra. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes in here and says, `We want to be bipartisan on business taxation reform. Give us a look at Ralph. We will talk to you and we will give it an expedited trip through the parliament.' If they cared about Australia they would give it an expedited trip through parliament without any qualifications. Instead, as an opposition they choose to oppose everything that has been proven globally and historically to be in the best interests of our nation.

We will talk when the opposition comes in here and says, `Let us work together. We will support you guys because you have runs on the board, you have delivered the fastest growing economy in the developed world, you have delivered a better outcome for all Australians.' That is a deal. But on every occasion until now the Labor Party has shown itself to be full of hypocrisy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On Monday the Treasurer was finally forced to come back into this House and talk about the current account deficit. He was forced to do that because he had yet another bad current account figure. Before that, day after day, he has come in here and had a rave about how brilliantly the economy is going and a rant about how badly it went under Labor. All of the time I have been in this parliament, the one thing that he has stayed right away from talking about is the unsustainably high current account deficit. He has talked about everything except the one thing that he should be focusing on.

speech.para: Is he ignoring it? Does he hope it will go away? Or worse, does he not understand it is a problem? One thing is certain, he has taken no action to reduce the current account and he offers no strategy for reducing the current account. He will wait for world economic events to realign and solve Australia's current account problem. It is an optimistic strategy for an optimistic Treasurer—or a fool in denial. Rather than adjusting policy to meet the challenge, the threat, of a high current account deficit, the opposite has been the case.

The fundamental cause of Australia's current account problem is Australia's poor domestic savings performance. In the March quarter of 1996, the last period Labor was in office, the household savings ratio stood at 5.6 per cent. Now after three years with Peter Costello as Treasurer it has collapsed to 0.4 per cent.

On Monday, in one of his rare shifts from rhetoric to brief interludes of substance—and they were brief; there were only about four paragraphs that had any substance at all—the Treasurer used as an authority the FitzGerald report commissioned by Labor in 1993. Mr Costello said:
The one thing that the FitzGerald inquiry and report made clear, the one thing that the Labor Party would agree with—
and we do—
is that building public sector savings is the best thing that a government can do in the face of a current account.
This was confirmed as government policy by the Secretary to the Treasury in his post-budget Australian business economists speech, when he said:

In recent years, we have not been asking monetary policy to address the current account problem. Rather emphasis has been appropriately put on the role of fiscal policy—the generator of budget surpluses and contributor to national savings—to do that job, leaving monetary policy free to concentrate on its objective of maintaining low inflation without undue constraint on growth.

This is a very desirable balance in the use of monetary and fiscal policies which may hold part of the answer to our longstanding current account concern; it is also part of the framework which underlies the judgments on medium term growth potential.

The simultaneous achievement of sustainable CAD outcomes and low and stable inflation would be put at risk by a complacent attitude to the use of fiscal surpluses. A breakdown in the performance of one policy inevitably compromises the other.

My fear is that that complacent attitude to the use of fiscal surpluses is exactly what we are about to see with a dramatic loosening of fiscal policy provided by the Howard government's so-called new tax system. If fiscal policy is the chosen instrument to control the current account deficit, then why is the Howard government contemplating a large fiscal loosening through its tax package when the current account deficit is already historically high?

A second related question is: how sound is the surplus on which this fiscal loosening is built? Let us look at the Treasurer's $5.4 billion estimated surplus this year. In it there is a 43.2 per cent increase in dividends from government business enterprises—that is, $1.8 billion. Take that away and you have a $3.6 billion surplus. That is a very modest improvement on the 1998-99 outcome of $3.1 billion.

There are always extraordinary items in any budget or set of financial statements, but there has not been much, if any, real growth in the size of the surplus. Even after the big fiscal loosening next year with the introduction of ANTS, the surplus will be only $7.2 billion. However, when you look at the underlying cash surplus next year, that is projected to be only $3.1 billion. The principal reason for that discrepancy is the bringing forward under accrual accounting of PAYG, although the tax is paid in subsequent years. That suggests that after the introduction of ANTS the government will not be left with much latitude as far as the surplus is concerned. In his post-budget speech to the Australian business economists, the Secretary to the Treasury, Ted Evans, put all this in some historical perspective. I regret that the minister has left the chamber. Mr Evans said:

Looking at Chart 1, which shows the underlying cash balance over a long period, we see that surpluses stretch out into the projection period. We should keep in mind, however, that of the six years of surplus there shown, only one is currently behind us. The 1999-2000 surplus we could take as being reasonably assured, but beyond that we are talking about mere projections, subject to all of the uncertainties of the world economy. Taking the 1999-2000 surplus as being `in the bag', the cumulative surplus over the three years would amount to 1.5 per cent of annual GDP. The scale of that might be assessed against the surpluses in the late 1980s, our last period of fiscal consolidation. On that earlier occasion, the cumulative surplus over the first three years amounted to 4.1 per cent of annual GDP—well over twice that achieved in the latest round.

The original A New Tax System package had a negative effect on the fiscal balance of almost $5 billion. To that must now be added the further loosening resulting from the Howard government's agreement with Democrats—at least a further $1.4 billion. In my view these are risks which need to be considered after eight years of continuous economic growth when loosening fiscal policy to such a significant degree in the face of a record high current account deficit. The Treasurer's explanation for the high current account deficit is entirely an external one—it is not his fault. He said on Monday:

. . . when you are running a strong domestic economy and you are in the biggest downturn of your time—meaning export values are low—you would expect pressure on your current account. We forecast it. We do not control the prices of Australian commodities.

Australia is presently operating with a current account deficit of about six per cent. A large contributing factor is the high level of domestic demand which is sustaining a higher than expected growth performance. Admitting that fact might cause the Treasurer to have to do something about it. Instead the Treasurer thinks he can forecast the current account deficit away. On Monday he said:

Why is it that we forecast the current account to come down next year? Because the international economy will pick up. The Australian growth rate will be lesser but the international economy will pick up.
What does the Treasury say about that? The first sentence of Statement 1—Fiscal Strategy—of Budget Paper No. 1, says:
The 1999-2000 Budget demonstrates the Government's commitment to maintain the budget in surplus while Australia's economic growth prospects remain sound.

The key word is `while'. What does `while economic growth remains sound' mean? It depends on whether and how far economic outcomes diverge either up or down from the budget forecast. One of the reasons for the early election last year was that the government was, at the time it was called, much more concerned about the outlook for growth this year than it seems to be now.

Statement 2—Economic Outlook—contains a section specifically dealing with risk in this year's budget papers. Weighed against doubts about the sustainability of recovery in East Asia and Japan is the possibility that the US could continue to exceed expectations. Of course, US economic performance may not continue to exceed expectations. Treasury admit that the downside risk is worsening of the current account deficit should the world economy not pick up. On the other hand, we must also look at the upside risks. If growth is stronger than expected, particularly if the contributing factor is higher than expected US economic growth and even a monetary tightening there which would be combined with the impact of the government's loosening of fiscal policy with its raid on the surplus and some additional inflationary pressure, including from the GST, then pressure on the current account will be higher than would otherwise have been the case and the momentary authorities may have to decide that interest rates will have to go up. This concern was raised in a Senate estimates committee by the Secretary to the Treasury earlier this year.

The high current account deficit means this is not a good time to loosen fiscal policy in the manner prescribed by the renegotiated ANTS package. Australia is presently operating with a current account of six per cent. It has only had to do so three times previously in Australia's recent economic history. The first time was in 1986, and resulted in a currency crisis. The second time was in 1989-90, and it was corrected with monetary policy which resulted in recession. The third time was at the beginning of 1995. That was, however, controlled without crisis by intelligent use of both fiscal and monetary policy. On that occasion we recognised we had a problem, we told the markets and the public we had a problem, and we took appropriate corrective action on both the fiscal and monetary fronts. Let us hope that this current account deficit can be moderated without crisis.

It is certainly the case, as was demonstrated in 1995, that as a result of the economic reforms of the last Labor government Australia is much less vulnerable to external shocks than was previously the case. However, without an appropriate policy response there is a significant risk that there could be a rapid market response with implications for the rest of the economy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I can only interpret the remarks of the previous speaker as being a call for an increase in the interest rates. That is all I can see that Labor Party policy comprises—increase interest rates and release the Wallis report. What a policy you have: Australia living on more reports produced by the ALP and putting up interest rates. They are familiar with that story. They know those policies and they have rejected them. That was the whole theme of the address to the House by the previous speaker, as it was the theme of the shadow Treasurer. Sure, if one goes back over a period of time, one sees that during the Labor Party's time in office Australians did save. But we have to look at what they are doing now. They are not saving now. Why is that? I just looked at the statistics put out by the ABS, and I find that they are wealthier. How can they be wealthier if they are not saving? They are investing. That is why they are wealthier. They are investing.

speech.para: I refer the House to the statistics that are freely available to any member that wants to gets them. It just so happens that the Australian Labor Party has not chosen to draw on the full range of statistics. It is strange, isn't it, that it should half-tell the story? If one looks at what the average Australian citizen has done over the period of the past few years, one will see that during the mid-1990s, before the election of the current government and during 1996 and half of 1997, Australian families saved. They saved because they were concerned about the future. They did not know what was going to happen to interest rates and were uncertain about their jobs, and so they put some money away for a rainy day—very sensible people, the Australian people.

If the Australian Labor Party ever learnt to trust them, they would know that they can learn a lot from their average fellow citizens. So, when things were uncertain, what do the statistics show? That Australian people, Australian families, were actually saving. They were putting money away because interest rates were uncertain and because they were unsure of their jobs. And they did not trust the current government either, for the first 12 months, to put interest rates down and keep them down. They were uncertain about whether we would create jobs as well. And so for 18 months after the election of the current government they kept saving.

But from that point on they started to release their savings, and what do you know has happened? If you look at the value of the average Australian household and the value of unincorporated enterprises in Australia—which is the way we measure households—their wealth is increasing. Analyse the statistics, my friend. It is so easy to do. I know that the chief whip does this all the time in his spare moments. He understands the Australian people. He understands what they are doing and he understands the fact that they are not saving. Where is their money going? It is going into dwellings, superannuation and investments—into things like Telstra, with record sales.

Australia is a high investment owning nation now, and that started about three years ago. As people relaxed and knew that the unemployment figures were coming down and that they could depend on the government to retain low interest rates, and as they learnt to trust that we would stick to what we had actually promised, they started to do other things with their money. Instead of squirreling it away at 1.5 per cent or two per cent in a bank savings account, they put it into something that was going to be of real benefit to their future. They put it into new homes or into expanding their homes. They put it into renovations and additions. They put it into superannuation for their retirement. It was far more important to them in many instances than having holidays was, to make sure that their retirement was safe.

They also invested in great institutions. They put it into shares: into Telstra and even into the Commonwealth Bank—which you said you would not sell but which you proceeded to sell. Surprise, surprise! Another promise broken. The Australian Labor Party encouraged people, by that hypocrisy it put on the Australian people at the time, into investing in institutions. So what have we got? We have got a completely changed scene in Australia. We have got families who are now more certain of their future because they know what their home payments are going to be. They know that they can borrow to extend their mortgages to buy a new house and to do renovations. They know that their job is secure and that they will be able to continue to save for their retirement with superannuation. They also know that, if they continue to invest in the great Australian institutions, they will benefit by that ultimately.

talk.start.para: —Where do you live?

—Look, my friend, just read up on the statistics. The ABS can tell you everything. If you just pull out the statistics, I think even the simplest of the members opposite will be able to see for themselves the way that this government has changed the whole outlook of the Australian community. It is very interesting to read the press about the Labor Party's attitudes. I refer to the press of 24 August and the report of your caucus room. You do not like being told about your caucus room, but the report in the press says that Mr Beazley told Labor MPs and senators that a lot of voters could see that the economy was going well but believed that they were missing out on that success.

speech.para: He referred to some polling, we are told, which showed the confidence that is in Canberra by politicians and said that their confidence in the economy is not necessarily reflected out there in voterland—as a caucus spokesman told reporters. The caucus spokesman went on to say that Mr Beazley made a point that Costello's comments about there being sufficient in the surplus two or three years out to consider further tax cuts was a good omen from the point of view of the Labor Party, and that meant they might not be hamstrung in terms of the limitations of the budget, assuming they won the next election, than they thought they might have been.

There you have it: a big spending idea of, `We hope they have got a real nest egg for us to get into if we should be elected at the next election.' It is out there in print. Fancy saying that in public. It will be quoted back to you, my friend, time and time again during the next election that you want the nest egg to fritter away and waste again. You will get into the hard-won savings of the Australian people and you will waste them. You will increase interest rates, because that was the argument here today. Higher interest rates was the call from your front bench today.

Not only was it a call for higher interest rates but it was a call for irresponsibility as far as the savings of the Australian people are concerned. They are wealthier now. They have more assets than they have ever had before, because they can now trust the government with interest rates and with jobs. They have made that investment, they have made that decision and they will continue to support the Australian government that they have today.

Let us go back through some of the statements of the Australian Labor Party over a period of the last week or so, because it seems to be that the call consistently for the past four or five months has been from the front bench to say, `Things are in a mess; you need to make a change.' At the time that the Labor Party leadership is saying that things are in a mess, Australians are investing in shares, in superannuation and in housing. That is because they are confident. If you want to spiral down confidence, I guess that you have to keep saying that things are in a mess. Mr Crean and Mr Beazley have been consistently saying that over the last few months.

I take the House back to 1 June, when the opposition spokesman, Mr Crean, said that the Treasurer should take his eyes off the changes to taxation and focus on Australia's deficit. For goodness sake! If anything is going to encourage the accumulation of wealth and assets and a sense of security, it is going to be a better tax system. So here is Crean, the shadow Treasurer, calling on the Treasurer to take his eyes off tax cuts.

Then just yesterday Mr Beazley said that we were paying a big penalty for our private savings—the same argument we have had here today. He did not look at where they are putting their money. They are putting it elsewhere. They are not saving it because they are confident and they have certainty. Mr Beazley on 24 August said that Australia has become a credit card economy depending on foreign savings and that the government is to blame. What a joke that is! He has not looked at any of the statistics. He has not looked at the real economy. He has not looked at what the small investors are doing. He has not looked at what the mums and dads are doing. He has not looked at what small business is doing.

The Labor Party will never get into government if they continue to talk the economy down in that way. There has to be more substance to it than that, because the facts are not there. You have only to go through the basic statistics. I am sure that the Australian Labor Party would learn if they would only listen to the way the Australian people think. So, despite the talking down of the economy, despite this credit card talk of the Leader of the Opposition, the facts are quite different. The facts are that Australians have never been better off, they have never been more wealthy, they have never had better incomes and they have never had better job certainty. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House:
(1) notes the fiftieth anniversary of the Four Geneva Conventions of 1949;

(2) congratulates the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement on its continuous fostering of the principles of international humanitarian law to limit human suffering in times of armed conflict and to prevent atrocities, especially against civilian populations, the wounded, and prisoners of war;
(3) recalls Australia's ratification of the Conventions and of the two Additional Protocols of 1977;
(4) affirms all Parliamentary measures taken in support of such ratification;
(5) encourages the fullest implementation of the Conventions and Additional Protocols by the military forces and civilian organisations of all nations;
(6) encourages ratification by all nations of the Conventions and Additional Protocols; and

(7) recognises the extraordinary contribution made by many individual Australians, including Australian Red Cross members, volunteers and staff, to the practical carrying into effect of the humanitarian ideals and legal principles expressed in the Conventions and Additional Protocols.

On 12 August 1949 the international community took a momentous step in the name of humanity by adopting the four Geneva conventions to protect victims of armed conflict. The experience of World War II was still very much part of the global consciousness, and there was a determination to do all that could be done to ensure that there was no recurrence of it. At the same time, there was also a recognition that, where conflict does occur, it should be carried out according to rules respected by civilised peoples. The Geneva conventions represent this ideal and make comprehensive provision for the protection of those most in need of it—namely, the wounded on the battlefield, those shipwrecked at sea, prisoners of war and civilians in the hands of the enemy.

The conventions also contain numerous other important rules. They proclaim that certain violations of them constitute grave breaches and that it is the duty of all states to investigate, prosecute and punish those who commit them or, alternatively, to deliver perpetrators into the custody of a state which is willing and able to do so. This duty exists regardless of the place where the offence was committed and the nationality of the perpetrator. The conventions also recognise the distinctive emblems of the Red Cross and Red Crescent and require their respect and protection.

Today, the conventions have attained almost universal acceptance, having been ratified by 188 states. They are universally recognised as forming part of customary international law. During the 1970s it became apparent that there was a need for the conventions to be supplemented, based on experience of the changing nature of warfare and the development of new weapons.

A series of international conferences was held, culminating in the adoption on 10 June 1977 of two protocols additional to the conventions. Protocol 1 deals with international armed conflict and makes detailed provision in relation to a number of areas. It provides enhanced protection for civilians. This recognises that, tragically, more and more civilians are the victims of armed conflict. It has been estimated that—whereas at the start of the 20th century 90 per cent of the casualties of war were military personnel—at the end of the century 90 per cent of the casualties of war are innocent civilians.

Protocol 1 also attempts to codify some of the rules regulating the methods and means of warfare. It extends the grave breaches provided for in the 1949 conventions and also makes provisions relating to the conduct of civil defence tasks, meaning those humanitarian measures intended to protect civilian populations against the dangers of hostilities.

Protocol 2 also recognises a harsh reality—namely, that most modern conflicts are fought not between nation states but among dissident groups within states. Protocol 2 deals exclusively with armed conflicts of a non-international character. The 1949 conventions had contained limited provisions about internal conflicts, but these are significantly supplemented by protocol 2, which enhances the protection of the victims of such conflicts.

The two additional protocols have also been widely accepted in the international community. Protocol 1 has been ratified by 152 states and protocol 2 by 144. Australia ratified the conventions on 14 October 1958.

This parliament enacted the Geneva Conventions Act 1957, the major purpose of which is to provide criminal sanctions for the grave breaches of the conventions and to endow Australian courts with jurisdiction to try them. Australia ratified the two additional protocols on 21 June 1991. The Geneva Conventions Act was amended at that time to include the grave breaches of protocol 1 within the jurisdiction of Australian courts and to provide for criminal sanctions for them.

In Australia our national Red Cross Society has made an enormous contribution towards implementing the humanitarian ideals and principles expressed in the conventions and protocols. Praise is due to the many Red Cross staff and volunteers who have made individual contributions. Special recognition is due to Mr Jim Carlton, the former member for Mackellar, who is currently the Secretary-General of Australian Red Cross, for his tireless work in this and related fields. I also acknowledge the interest in the Geneva conventions and the Red Cross of a former Minister for Justice and senator, Michael Tate, who actually suggested this motion.

I would like to conclude with mention of two recent examples of Australia's commitment to the ideals of international humanitarian law as expressed in the conventions and protocols. The first is the prompt ratification by Australia of the Ottawa Anti-Personnel Land Mines Convention and the implementation of our obligations under the convention in the enactment by this parliament of the Anti-Personnel Land Mines Convention Act 1998. This convention is an important step in the elimination of antipersonnel landmines and represents an enhancement of measures in earlier treaties, including protocol 1, directed toward the regulation of the destructive effects of weapons of war.

The second is the adoption of the Statute of the International Criminal Court. The court is intended to try perpetrators of the most serious crimes of concern to the international community. Included within the court's jurisdiction are the grave breaches of the Geneva conventions and other serious violations of international humanitarian law. It is a source of pride that Australia chairs the group of like-minded nations committed to the establishment of a viable court.

In conclusion, it is appropriate that this House commemorate the 50th anniversary of the adoption of the Geneva conventions, that it recognise the role of the Red Cross movement in international humanitarian law and that it note with pride Australia's record in this field.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Australian Labor Party, I congratulate the Attorney-General for bringing forward this motion in the House today. We also recognise the work of the Australian Red Cross generally, and specifically in relation to this motion the work of former member Jim Carlton and former senator Michael Tate who have continued their public office at an international level.

speech.para: The Attorney spoke of Australia's honour in respect of international humanitarian operations and I think it is fair to say that not only has the Australian Red Cross been involved successfully in those activities but also the Australian defence forces are regarded internationally as the pre-eminent peacekeeping force in the world. Of course, they do apply the provisions and principles contained in the Geneva conventions and also the first and second protocols to which the Attorney has referred.

I would like to speak about the background to the Geneva conventions and their implementation. The 20th century is often described as the century of war. With two world wars and countless regional and local conflicts, there has not been a single day of peace in 99 years. As the Attorney indicated, at the start of the century 90 per cent of casualties were in the armed forces and currently 90 per cent are civilians. They have been killed, and are increasingly being killed, in unparalleled numbers in the wars of the century.

However, the 20th century has also seen the advancement of humanitarian treaties and organisations designed to prevent and respond to the excesses of war. Today, wherever we see war, we also see those who seek to mediate disputes and respond to the plight of those who are injured, captured or who are mere bystanders in conflicts they do not understand, let alone control.

First and foremost among those many agencies is the International Federation of the Red Cross and the Red Crescent. The Red Cross was born from the vision of one man, Henry Durant. On 24 June 1859 Durant witnessed the battle of Salferino between the Austrian and French armies; 300,000 men fought in that conflict and 40,000—over 10 per cent—died or were wounded. In the aftermath of the battle, Durant commented on the sense of helplessness that he experienced, only able to assist those immediately in front of him when there were literally thousands crying out for help. But, rather than be debili tated by his despair, he acted and proposed the establishment of societies for the relief of the wounded and the adoption of a convention to protect the wounded soldiers and medical personnel on the battlefield who were attending them.

On 9 February 1863 the Geneva Society for Public Welfare established a five-member commission to implement Durant's ideas. On 17 February that year the International Committee for Relief to the Wounded in Time of War was founded and on 26 October 1863 the now familiar symbol of the Red Cross was adopted. In 1864 at a diplomatic conference convened by the Swiss government, the first international humanitarian law, the Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded in Armies in the Field, was ratified. In 1919 the International Federation of the Red Cross and the Red Crescent was established. The Red Crescent is used in many Islamic nations out of respect for the faith of those people that the federation seeks to assist.

Today the federation has over 175 member societies and an active humanitarian presence in over 50 nations around the world. Beyond its duties to protect those injured or imprisoned by war, the federation also visits people deprived of their freedom, protects civilian populations, traces the families of those dislocated by war, conducts relief operations and helps prevent war through diplomacy and humanitarian action. It also provides an advisory service on international humanitarian law, including, importantly, in respect to the status of refugees.
This year the federation is commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Geneva conventions through its People on War project. As the federation itself says:

. . . the 50th anniversary of the Geneva Conventions should be more than simply a commemoration. On the eve of the 21st Century, this anniversary is a historic opportunity for the world to reflect on what has occurred in the half-century since the Conventions were adopted, to take stock of the present and to consider the future of international law and humanitarian action.

I encourage all Australians to participate in this project. If the 21st century is to be, as we all hope it will be, the `century of peace', then commitment to international humanitarian law and action must be the cornerstone of all that we do. I commend this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —As the chair of this parliament's Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I am very pleased to stand and support this motion introduced by the Attorney-General. The Geneva rules form part of international humanitarian law and are found, as we have heard, in the four Geneva conventions of 1949 and two additional protocols of 1997. The previous speaker has outlined where the Geneva convention came from and where the Red Cross came from all that long time ago in 1864 and 1863 respectively and the principles of the Red Cross.

speech.para: One might ask: what is the relevance to those things of so long ago to today? I would like to quote the UN Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, who made the same allusion as the previous two speakers about the switch from the number of casualties being 90 per cent soldiers to being 90 per cent civilians. She made the point that today:

. . . conflict takes place within States, and 90 per cent of the victims are civilians—unarmed children, women and men, the elderly, the sick, and refugees. The greatest threat to human rights is war, but even war has its rules . . .

Rather than writing new laws, she emphasised that what is needed is to implement what already exists, including the Geneva conventions. She called on states to abide by the conventions and to ratify the Statute of the International Criminal Court. It is interesting to note that 56 more ratifications are needed before that statute can enter into force.
The United Nations Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, said in his address commemorating the 50th anniversary:

While the United Nations Charter may be seen as a reflection of our experience, and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights an expression of our ideals, the Geneva Conventions have for half a century represented humanity's determination to ensure, even in the midst of war, a minimum of respect for humanitarian principles. . . .

In this final year of a century of war, genocide and immense suffering, we do not meet in celebration of the respect for these conventions. We cannot say that civilian populations have been spared in the conflicts of the last decade. And we should not believe that the next fifty years will require any less determination and commitment on our part to limit the suffering of civilians in war. . . .

By making palpable the concepts of accountability and individual criminal responsibility for war crimes, the International Criminal Tribunals for the Former Yugoslavia and Rwanda have invested the Geneva Conventions with new life and new relevance. . . . They continue to remind us that in every conflict where civilians are targeted—whether it is in Bosnia, Rwanda, Cambodia, Kosovo or Sierra Leone—there are violators and there are victims. The creation of the International Criminal Court is further evidence of the commitment to ensuring global justice . . .

It is interesting to note that Kofi Annan and others launched an appeal in Geneva on 12 August this year. The idea of the appeal was to reject the idea that war is inevitable and to work to eradicate its causes; to demand those involved in armed conflicts and who are in a position to influence such conflicts respect the essential humanitarian principles and rules of international humanitarian law; to spare civilians the agony of war; and to foster relations between individuals, peoples and nations on the basis of the principles that inspired the Geneva conventions—namely, respect for human dignity in all circumstances and compassion for those who suffer.

I have seen first-hand and experienced some of the impacts of war in a number of places in the last 40-odd years. I have seen it in Europe; I have seen it in Malaya as it was then, Malaysia as it is now; I have seen some of the incredible suffering on the Afghanistan-Pakistan border area; and I have seen it in Laos. I am sure a number of other members of this chamber have had similar experiences. I therefore have no hesitation in strongly commending this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to join with previous speakers in recognising the 50th anniversary of the Geneva conventions. I want to take the opportunity to pay tribute to the International Committee of the Red Cross for their humanitarian aid and assistance to those hurt and displaced by war and to compliment them on their People on War project. The International Committee of the Red Cross believe the Geneva conventions are central to international humanitarian law and recognise them as:

speech.para: . . . the most important international instruments to defend human dignity in war and among the most widely ratified treaties in the world.

Under these conventions, countless numbers of people have been shielded and protected against war. But at the same time we must recognise that, despite these conventions, immense suffering, trauma and horror has stalked and struck down millions in war and conflict.

Tragically, of course, given the modern nature of war, many of the victims of this trauma have been civilians—non-combatant women and children—inescapably caught in the horror of modern weaponry which does not discriminate between soldier and civilian, woman or child. Landmines are a prime example of such weapons but not the only one. Of course, this parliament has worked with the Red Cross and other NGOs and ratified the Ottawa agreement.

Poised as we are on the threshold of a new century, we as a nation should reflect on how fortunate our country has been to largely escape the devastation of war on our own soil. With that reflection in mind, however, we must turn to the future and recognise the inevitability of armed conflict in the next century with the knowledge that, in the face of modern warfare, we in Australia are as vulnerable to its cruelty, its horror, its devastation and its ravages as any country in any other region of the world.

Distance and isolation are no longer a means of defence, and morally as a nation we must recognise our responsibilities to continue to work toward a sense of global security by supporting the Geneva conventions. We must continue to stand strongly in support of humanitarian issues and, with resolve and determination, confront those who threaten these conventions in the recognition that every man, every woman, every child on the face of this earth is a potential combatant when these conventions fail.
I strongly endorse and support the People on War project being run by the International Committee of the Red Cross and I quote from its document:

People on War is a worldwide project that intends to increase awareness around the world of the rules that already exist for people's protection in wartime and to encourage discussion of humanitarian law in the context of modern-day conflict.
It is designed to involve those who have experience of war.

Those who are actually experiencing the reality of war are rarely consulted, because debates on the subject take place in meetings they cannot attend and the findings are reflected in documents which they do not write or have the opportunity to read.

It is the ambition of the International Committee of the Red Cross to bring people in war-torn societies back into the global arena where the humanitarian rules and decisions of tomorrow are generated, and to make the process less of a monologue and more of a dialogue.

The federal parliament of this nation, the House of Representatives, is the prime arena of Australia where humanitarian rules and decisions of tomorrow can be generated. We in this place must never lose sight of what our responsibilities are, not just in relation to Australia and our region but in a global sense. The International Committee of the Red Cross also says this:
The purpose of international humanitarian law is to limit human suffering in times of armed conflict and to prevent atrocities.
Further, it says this:
Even wars have limits.
Our strong support for the Geneva conventions will help set those limits, and I support this motion and compliment the Attorney-General on his bringing it forward.

talk.start.para: —What a pleasure it is to be able to speak on this motion. I stand in the parliament today and pay tribute to the Australian Red Cross members, individual Australians, volunteers and staff who have dedicated their lives to ensuring that innocent people are protected from the casualties of war and the collapse of governments around this world.

speech.para: In this last year of the decade, we have witnessed a past century of war and conflict that has evoked genocide and immense suffering. In fact, we have witnessed ethnic wars that have seen genocide and ethnic cleansing as almost acceptable in some parts of the world. We have seen violations of international humanitarian law in the form of rape, torture, mutilation, executions, denial of food and medicines and denial of basic rights.

The year 1999 marks the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Geneva conventions. This anniversary is more than simply a commemoration; it is an opportunity for us to reflect on the past, to come to terms with the present and to look ahead to the future. There is no doubt that countless people have been protected by the Geneva conventions, and there is also little doubt that many hundreds of thousands more will need this protection into the future. As my colleague the member for Cowan has pointed out, we should not rest on our laurels. We should know that the next 50 years will require even more determination and commitment on our part to limit the sufferings of civilians in war and political treachery.

The four Geneva conventions form a major part of the body of law known as international humanitarian law, which regulates the conduct of armed conflict. The conventions were adopted on 12 August 1949. They were one of the major responses of the world community to the horrors witnessed during World War II. However, we were to witness even more atrocities. These atrocities would astound the world and require a special commitment from leaders all around the world. Each convention is directed toward the protection of different classes of the victims of war, namely, the wounded and sick in armed forces in the field; the wounded, sick and shipwrecked among armed forces at sea; prisoners of war; and civilians in the hands of the enemy.

It was the `civilians in the hands of the enemy' clause that led to the additional protocols of 1977 being adopted in recognition of the changing nature of warfare in the latter part of the 20th century. In particular, it was recognised that, to a far greater extent, the victims of war are civilians and that most modern conflicts are of a non-international character. The convention is a necessary international instrument and has a unique and important role to play in recognising that human suffering, conflict and war are not particular to time, race, religion or culture. The convention is important in bringing to justice those who violate the human rights of others.

The International Red Cross has been instrumental in establishing the Geneva conventions and continually brings to our attention the importance of protecting individuals who are caught up in armed conflict. The Geneva Conventions Act 1957 makes provisions for the prosecution in Australian courts of grave breaches of the conventions, regardless of the place of commission of the offence or the nationality of the perpetrator. The act also provides for the protection of the distinctive emblem of the Red Cross, so often seen in the heart of war-torn countries and areas of civil unrest.

Australia is recognised internationally as being at the forefront of those nations which respect and promote the principles of international humanitarian law. The world has now come to expect that war victims will be assisted by humanitarian agencies such as the Red Cross and that, for many, humanitarian aid is an essential lifeline. This is particularly so for women, children and the elderly, for whom aid often provides the very basis of their survival. I am honoured to offer my support to the Red Cross and the Geneva conventions, and I am proud to be part of this Australian parliament that encourages ratification by all nations of the conventions and additional protocols.

talk.start.para: —I support the motion moved by the Attorney-General and supported by other speakers. Some might argue that it is a contradiction to speak about human rights, especially international humanitarian law, in connection with war. Surely war, with all its horrors—not least the horror of armed conflict—is the ultimate breakdown of human rights. It is the very opposite to the ideals expressed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The Geneva conventions—the 50th anniversary of which we are commemorating with this motion—have for half a century represented humanity's determination to ensure, even in the midst of war, a minimum respect for humanitarian principles.

speech.para: However, in this final year of the decade—in a century of war, genocide and immense suffering—one cannot say that civilian populations have been spared in the conflicts of the last decade. Indeed, when one looks at the conflicts, one aspect stands out—that is, the increasing practice of making civilians the very targets of warfare, genocide and ethnic cleansing. Increasingly, it is not a question of protecting civilians in armed conflict but of protecting civilians from armed conflict—and civilian populations are being used as instruments of war. These flagrant violations of international humanitarian law—the wholesale expulsion of an entire people from their native lands, summary and arbitrary execution, mutilation, rape, forced displacement and denial of food and medicines—are a sad litany.

It must be made clear to the perpetrators of flagrant violations of human rights that the world will no longer turn a blind eye to what they do. By making individuals responsible—through the concepts of accountability and individual responsibility for war crimes—the International Crimes Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda have invested the Geneva conventions with, I suggest, new life and new relevance. As the Secretary-General of the UN recently reminded us, the Geneva conventions continue to remind each of us that in every conflict where civilians are targeted—be it Bosnia, Rwanda, Cambodia, Kosovo or Sierra Leone—there are violations and there are victims.

The creation of the International Criminal Court is further evidence of the commitment to ensuring global justice. Of course, for this to be effective, it will require ratification swiftly and universally. I am pleased that this motion recognises the extraordinary contribution of many individual Australians, including Australian Red Cross members, volunteers and staff, to the practical carrying into effect of the humanitarian ideals and legal principles expressed in the Geneva conventions and the additional protocols.

We live in a far from ideal world. Even in our own region we have seen recent conflicts—for instance, in the Solomon Islands—and of course events in Timor over the last few days and today worry us all. We are sickened by the suffering of many people innocently caught up in conflict and used as pawns in a power struggle. It is time to reflect on the past 50 years. People point to civilian suffering—the very people that the conventions are supposed to protect. It is the atrocities—where the conventions break down—that regrettably attract attention. What is rarely reported or documented is the silent diplomacy. How many atrocities and how much suffering has been avoided by the Geneva conventions of 1949 and the additional protocols? It is also time to look forward to what may be achieved in the 50 years ahead. I congratulate the Attorney-General for bringing this motion forward and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, I present the committee's report titled, Examination of annual reports for 1997-1998 in fulfilment of the committee's duties pursuant to s.206(c) of the Native Title Act 1993—Fourteenth report , together with evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Today, as Deputy Chair of the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, I table the committee's 14th report. It examines the 1997-98 annual reports of the National Native Title Tribunal, the Land Fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation. The committee has now reported on the tribunal's first five annual reports and on the ILC's first four annual reports, in that the ILC did not commence until 1 June 1995. With one exception, the committee has held public hearings each year to consider the annual reports, which it has a duty to examine pursuant to section 206(c) of the Native Title Act 1993.

speech.para: The National Native Title Tribunal and the ILC have given significant assistance to the committee throughout the public hearings. Particular mention should be made of the senior officers of the National Native Title Tribunal who assisted the committee in its deliberations and examination of the tribunal's annual reports. In that instance, I want to acknowledge the contribution of Justice Robert French, who was the tribunal president from 2 May 1994 to 31 December 1998. As only the second president, he was responsible for much of the work to establish the tribunal's operations. He also made a significant impact in the provision of public information about the nature of the native title process. Justice French was supported by the tribunal's second registrar, Ms Patricia Lane, who retired on 31 December 1997. The tribunal is fortunate to continue to benefit from Ms Lane's expertise, in that she has been appointed a part-time member of the tribunal for a term of three years.

In relation to the ILC, there has been a similar contribution from the persons initially responsible for the administration of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Mr David Ross was the inaugural chairperson, beginning his four-year term when the ILC commenced on 1 June 1996. Similarly, Mr Peter Yu has been the ILC deputy chairperson in a part-time capacity. He was appointed until 31 May 1999, when Mr Ross also retired.

Both Mr Ross and Mr Yu have been available consistently to provide evidence to the committee about the ILC's activities. The committee has relied on their assistance. Notably, within the term of office served by Mr Ross, the ILC approved about 200 properties for purchase and divested about 30 to indigenous corporations. This is a significant achievement, for which Mr Ross and Mr Yu deserve to be acknowledged. The committee has wished them well for the future. On a personal level, I want to acknowledge their dedication, hard work and friendship.

Turning to the committee's 14th report, mention should be made of the most significant matters. With regard to the tribunal, the committee commented on the issues of impartiality, workload, amendments to the act and public information. In its 13th report the committee noted that a tribunal member, Mr Sean Flood, resigned from the tribunal on 13 October 1997. At its public hearing on 30 March 1999, the committee heard from the new president, Mr Graeme Neate, that tribunal members must act in an impartial manner for as long as they hold office. The committee supports the continuation of this approach by the incoming tribunal president.

The tribunal's workload has similarly been a matter of continuing concern to the committee. At the end of the 1997-98 reporting period, a total of 804 claimant applications were lodged. Future act activity was also intense, with almost 4,000 notifications. This significant workload confronted the tribunal at a time when there had been a reduction in the number of tribunal members through retirement and resignation. The committee has expressed the judgment that the tribunal should not retain consultants to manage this workload but provide advice to government so that an adequate complement of members will be available.

With regard to amendments to the act, the committee was pleased to learn that, in the tribunal president's opinion, amendments passed in 1998 in the Native Title Amendment Bill have provided new tools for more flexible and expeditious resolution of native title claims. For example, before the amendments were made, the tribunal had relatively few statutory processes to deal with indigenous disputes. The committee has commended the tribunal for its efforts in disseminating information about native title. The committee will continue to consult with those who may be affected by the lack of information with a view to ensuring that adequate and accurate information is available from authoritative sources.

In relation to the Indigenous Land Corporation, the committee's 14th report has similarly referred to substantive matters in regard to the ILC's 1997-98 annual report. These include land management and operational challenges. In its 13th report the committee had expressed concern that its recommendation to the ILC to provide a comprehensive account of land under management had not been followed. It is pleasing to note that the 1997-98 annual report has adopted this suggestion. Appendix 4 of the ILC report details land management expenditure during 1997-98 on land held by the ILC as well as assistance provided to indigenous land-holders. In addition, the committee has been able to confirm that the ILC was involved in the actual management of land purchased by the ILC in the 1996-97 period. The committee will continue to monitor the land management activities of the ILC, and it welcomes the ILC's assurance that its next annual report will treat the issue of land-holding costs in more detail than it has previously.

Regarding this annual report, the ILC is to be commended for the way in which it has described the operational challenges that it faces. The ILC addressed matters such as land needs planning, expectations of property vendors and divestment of title. Another significant issue that the ILC has reported concerns obstacles confronting the purchase of grazing homestead freeholding leases and grazing homestead perpetual leases in Queensland. Under the Queensland legislation, these forms of tenure must be held by individuals and operated, in effect, as family farms. The ILC's legislation prevents it from acquiring land on behalf of individuals, and such leases may not be transferred to corporate ownership, including the ILC. The committee was pleased to learn at the public hearing on 25 March 1999 that a short-term solution had been achieved. The State Governor in Council agreed to exercise discretion to transfer the lease of a property to the ILC so that it could then be transferred to an Aboriginal corporation. The ILC is currently pursuing similar exercises in relation to a number of other properties. I commend the committee's 14th report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I rise as a member of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund to speak on the occasion of the tabling of the committee's 14th report, entitled Examination of Annual Reports for 1997-98 in fulfilment of the committee's duties pursuant to s.206(c) of the Native Title Act 1993 . The purpose of this report is to examine the 1997-98 annual reports of the National Native Title Tribunal, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Land Fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation. I also add to comments of the deputy chair regarding the recognition of the senior officers of both the Native Title Tribunal and the ILC who have always made themselves available to facilitate the committee's examination of their annual reports, as well as to provide information about their broader functions and activities.

speech.para: In his capacity as tribunal president from 2 May 1994 until 31 December 1998, Justice Robert French made a significant contribution to the establishment of the tribunal's operations and in raising public awareness and understanding about native title and the native title processes. I am pleased to note that the tribunal's second registrar, Ms Patricia Lane, who retired on 31 December 1997, has been appointed a part-time member of the tribunal for a term of three years.
