The tribunal will no doubt continue to benefit from her substantial expertise. I also recognise the work of the inaugural chair and the deputy chair of the ILC, Mr David Ross and Mr Peter Yu. The terms of Mr Ross and Mr Yu expired on 31 May 1999. Both Mr Ross and Mr Yu have provided significant information to the committee regarding the activities and role of the ILC since its commencement on 1 June 1995. The committee looks forward to a cooperative working relationship with the new chair and deputy chair of the ILC.

The committee's 14th report contains a detailed examination of the National Native Title Tribunal's annual report for 1997-98. At the outset, it is important to highlight that, in the committee's view, the tribunal has pro duced its most accessible, accurate and professional report to date. The committee's report focuses on the most significant issues arising from the tribunal's 1997-98 annual report, including workload, impartiality and the effect of the Native Title Act amendments.

Mr Sean Flood stood down as a tribunal member as a result of public comments he made about the government's native title policy. Mr Flood resigned from the tribunal on 13 October 1997. The committee supports the view expressed by the new president, Mr Graeme Neate, at the public hearing on 30 March 1999 that tribunal members must act, and be seen to be acting, in an impartial manner while they hold office.

The increasing workload of the tribunal is also an issue that the committee takes a close interest in. At the end of 1997-98, 804 claimant applications were lodged with the tribunal, as well as almost 4,000 future act notifications pursuant to section 29 of the Native Title Act. The tribunal also convened some 5,000 preliminary conferences in relation to objections to the expedited procedure. This issue remains one of ongoing interest to the committee, particularly the fact that this increase in workload coincided with a reduction in the number of tribunal members due to retirement and resignation.

In examining the tribunal's annual report, the committee was pleased to note that, in the opinion of the tribunal president, the amendments to the Native Title Act have provided processes for a far more flexible and expeditious resolution of native title claims. At the public hearing on 30 March 1999, the new president outlined a number of important developments arising from the amendments. These related to the registration test and its role in the reduction of overlapping claims, the ability to isolate and refer issues to the Federal Court and the ability to deal more effectively with intra- indigenous disputes.

The committee's 14th report also reports on the most significant issues in the ILC's annual report for 1997-98. In the reporting period, the ILC approved the purchase of 77 properties, acquired 30 properties and divested 10 properties to corporations representing the interests of the traditional owners. This is a significantly greater number than in previous years. In total, to March 1999, the ILC had approved the purchase of almost 200 properties and divested almost 30 properties to indigenous interests. This is a significant achievement in a relatively short period of time. The ILC's annual report responds to the main issues raised in the committee's 13th report, particularly in relation to land management and consultancies.

The ILC's report provides a detailed account of land under management, which has been an issue of concern in the committee's 13th report. Further, the ILC has confirmed that it did engage in actual land management activities on land it purchased in 1996-97. Further, the committee's 13th report recommended that a detailed list of consultancies be included in the ILC's annual report. Indeed, this recommendation is adhered to by the inclusion of such a list in appendix 3 of the ILC's 1997-98 annual report. In relation to its significant land management responsibilities, the ILC also announced its intention to establish a wholly owned subsidiary, Land Enterprises Australia or LEA. The role of LEA will be to manage the commercial aspects of the ILC's land management functions. The ILC also established two other subsidiaries in the reporting period relating to the management of particular pastoral properties.

The ILC's annual report also deals comprehensively with the operational challenges it faced in the reporting period. In particular, the ILC reported on difficulties that it experienced in relation to vendor expectations that the ILC will pay higher than market value for properties it wishes to purchase. On 25 March 1999, the ILC's general manager reported that 66 per cent of the ILC's property negotiations had resulted in an acquisition below valuation, with the remainder being achieved at, or close to, market value. Due to public perception that market valuations are much higher than best industry practice could justify, there remains a necessity for continued committee scrutiny in this area. The ILC also reported in detail on operational challenges in relation to land needs planning and the development and implementation of its first land management policy, particularly as this policy represents a significant shift from previous land management policies. I commend the committee's 14th report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—We are considering three annual reports prepared pursuant to section 206(c) of the Native Title Act 1993. They are examined in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. They are: the National Native Title Tribunal annual report 1997-98, the Indigenous Land Corporation annual report 1997-98 and the report regarding the administration of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund for the period 1997-98. The committee has examined the annual reports prepared pursuant to part 4A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 and section 133 of the Native Title Act 1993. On its examination, the committee finds them to be satisfactory.

speech.para: We live in interesting times. I have some comments about Mr Sean Flood, who is now no longer a member of the National Native Title Tribunal. I should point out that I served with Mr Flood as a public defender before I came into parliament. He resigned from the tribunal and again took up an appointment as a public defender for 12 months, representing indigenous Australians. That was a funded position from ATSIC. At the end of that appointment, Mr Flood was appointed a magistrate in New South Wales by the New South Wales government, so he is still continuing to serve in a public capacity. There is great respect for him in the community. Mr Flood is a passionate advocate and has been in the past. His impartiality is beyond dispute, and I regard him as a personal friend. That is the end of that chapter. I did comment on him last time we were tabling reports. He continues to serve the community in that professional capacity as a magistrate in New South Wales.

As to the Indigenous Land Corporation, the terms of the inaugural chair, David Ross, and deputy chair, Peter Yu, expired on 31 May 1999. They were excellent appointments by the Keating government. The Indigenous Land Corporation has been exemplary in the way that it has conducted itself, and those two people, together with the general management team and staff, have run an excellent organisation as far as the Commonwealth is concerned. On each occasion Mr Ross and Mr Yu have been before the committee in their offices, they have acted in a professional and courteous manner. They have provided committees continuously with any information that they have sought. They are two great indigenous Australians who also are passionate advocates for their people. They have not left the arena in the current debate on native title, land rights and a whole range of other things. They are out there in the public arena.

They are not acting in a token way; they are acting in a passionate way on issues they believe in. In a way, I think that is engendering respect for them in the broad community. David Ross, in particular, is one of the most outstanding indigenous Australians in this country today. He does not necessarily have the flair in terms of advocacy, but he is as tough as teak and as honourable as they come. Peter Yu, in recent times, was prominent in debates over the Wik amendments. It is true to say that, in recent years, the indigenous community has been under siege with this government and people like Peter Yu and David Ross have been at the forefront of defending indigenous people.

It shows that the old days of tokenism and compliance are over, that we have articulate, professional representatives prepared to stand up. There is a lot of misinformation out there in the community and it is not easy in difficult times. It is all right for members of the government who have not necessarily suffered discrimination, who have not had to speak on behalf of communities that have suffered the devastation that these people have. They are not homogenous communities. There is a perception out there, or a double standard, that Aboriginal people, or the migrant community, necessarily speak with one voice. I am a member of the Lebanese community. I am very careful when I speak on matters relating to that community because there are divisions in that community.

Peter and David have always consulted widely with their communities. They have maintained links with elders in the community. They are well respected. Members on both sides of the House have seen their professional conduct when they have come before the parliamentary committees, and I pay tribute to them. I have always been a fervent believer in public service. Too often there are people who ridicule public servants or people who are committed to public service who say that you have to go to the private sector to get the best. In my view, David Ross and Peter Yu were the best of the best when they served on the ILC. They are big shoes to fill, but I join with the honourable members opposite in looking forward to working with the new appointments.

They have different views, but we have to have the tolerance and understanding to listen to the other side, to respect that there are different views in the communities and try to embrace them. Recently, the member for Kalgoorlie, my friend the honourable member for the Northern Territory and I tabled a report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. We did not start off with the same views, but we ended up with a report that will withstand scrutiny.

The people who have served during the period of these reports have served in a professional capacity, a capacity which the community and the parliament can be proud of. They hold strong views, but let us not attack the person; let us go for the policies. These people have been under siege, and I know in their own communities there is some criticism for the fact that they even engage in government. There are plenty out there in all the communities who like to be in the crowd on the sidelines who are the knockers. These people are not. They are in there having a go and they have not left the arena. I look forward to seeing them in the future. I commend these reports to the parliament. They have the big tick—one, two, three.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —Before question time started—
—What question time?

—and was so rudely interrupted by a number of matters, I was actually making the point that the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has a problem with numeracy. On Monday, he told the House:

speech.para: At the end of March 1999 there were 232,000 new apprentices in training, up from 204,000 at the end of December. That is an increase of 33,000 in the March quarter.

I am sure that someone who is as good at arithmetic as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, knows that, if you subtract four from 32, you do not get 33. The point we make is that David Kemp is doing for numeracy what Dan Quayle did for spelling. If the federal minister for education does not know that 32 minus four is 28, he has a problem with numeracy, and the Labor Party repeats its offer to pass the hat around and fund the remedial numeracy course for the minister for education.

I know these days that high quality staff are advising federal ministers of the Australian government, and I know the staff would not make a mistake like this. We can only put it down to the fact that the federal minister for education does need a bit of help on his sums. What made it worse was, instead of coming in yesterday and fessing up to the fact that he made a mistake, the minister said:
Since question time yesterday—
that is, Monday—
I have been advised that December's figures for apprenticeships have since been revised upwards from the previously published figure of 206,400 to 219,810.

So we are entitled to ask: if on Tuesday the minister could claim that there was a previ ously published figure of 206,400, why did the minister for education tell the House that it was 204,000? So he not only mixes up 32 minus four but also does not understand that four is not equal to six. We simply ask whether the minister will go for the trifecta and try to spell `potato' tomorrow because he does have as big a problem with numeracy as Dan Quayle had with spelling.

The second point we made before question time was that the minister needs to explain whether he intends to keep his promise to provide additional funding to improve the quality of teaching for children in Australian schools. In the 1996 election campaign, the government promised to maintain the National Professional Development Program, a Labor government program. As soon as they were elected, that promise was breached. We hoped they had realised their mistake in the 1998 election campaign; they certainly promised to restore the program. Page 10 of the 1998 coalition schools policy said:
The coalition will provide $75 million over three years to strengthen the skills of the teaching profession.

That was announced again in the budget earlier this year, but here we have the budget bills before the House today and there is no money for professional development, there is no money to try to ensure that the quality of teaching in Australian schools improves. So we ask the minister: why is there no money in the school legislation before the parliament today? Where is that $77 million that was promised? How will the minister meet the commitment that this professional development for teachers will begin on 1 January 2000? I hope the minister will respond to those questions in his summing up.

The other issue that needs to be addressed in the short time left to me is the government's claims that it does not favour one school sector over another. We know from the leaked minutes of a June 1991 shadow ERC meeting that the current minister for education has always supported government policies that encourage a steady, continuous decline in the proportion of students attending government schools. He has always made it clear that that is his preferred policy direction.

The point we make is that, in the budget delivered earlier this year, there was a significant increase in funding for non-government schools and we welcome the fact that some needy non-government schools will get additional funding; but having provided a significant increase in funding for non-government schools, there was no balancing equivalent increase in federal funding for government schools. In fact, there was actually an average of $210 in additional funding provided in the discretionary decisions listed in the budget papers for every child attending a non-government school.

Adding together the additional funding for Catholic schools and the new funding which is to be made available to non-government schools under the switch from the ERI assessment of needs to the SES assessment of needs will provide $756 million over four years. If you add to that 30 per cent—because about 30 per cent of students are in non-government schools in Australia—of the quality teacher money and 30 per cent of the new literacy money for middle years, you get an average of $210 for every child attending a non-government school in Australia.

The extra amount on average given to students in government schools across Australia is calculated by simply adding together 70 per cent of the quality teacher money and 70 per cent of the new literacy money for middle years over four years. As I said, there is an average of $210 per child per year for the children attending non-government schools, and an average of $10 per child per year for those attending government schools—a ratio of 21 to one. For every extra $1 in discretionary decisions made by the government in the budget given to a child at a government school, $21 went to children attending non-government schools. That could hardly be described as fair, and it certainly does not address the great needs that are out there in public education. We would certainly argue that a great deal needs to be done.
When we asked questions in Senate estimates about the need to provide more funding for public education, an answer which was presumably approved by the minister for education stated:

In 1999-2000 the Commonwealth financial assistance grants paid to the states and territories will increase by almost five per cent in real terms providing additional resources for the funding of government schools.

This claim is completely wrong. The additional federal funding provided to the states simply takes account of adjustments to movements in prices and changes in population growth. Budget paper No. 3 states that the FAGs have been maintained in real per capita terms, so once price increases and population growth are accounted for, states and territories have no additional funds to direct to government schools.

So someone, presumably Dr Kemp, the federal minister for education, misled the parliament when, in an answer to a question in Senate estimates, they claimed that there was a five per cent increase in real terms in funding for government schools because the Commonwealth FAGs—the financial assistance grants to the states—had increased by five per cent in real terms. That was simply misleading the Senate and misleading all of us.

We make the point that, through the introduction of the enrolment benchmark adjustment, through not providing balanced increases in government and non-government school funding and through undermining the quality of our universities and TAFE colleges, this government has set out on the deliberate policy of undermining Australia's public institutions in education. This government under this minister has an ideological obsession with privatising education and undermining public institutions. It is for that reason I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) using the important issue of literacy in a cynical political fashion;
(2) failing to provide government schools with additional resources in line with its increased expenditure for the non-government sector; and
(3) failing to meet its 1996 promise and 1999 Budget commitment to maintain funding for teacher professional development".

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—What we have just heard from the member for Dobell is fairly typical—high on rhetoric and distraction but rather short on pertinent facts. It is pretty obvious that the member for Dobell does not like good news. He tries to carry on as though there have been cuts to funding for schools. Let me remind him of the facts. In the last three years, this government has increased funding for schools by $800 million. There was $3.3 billion in funding in Labor's last year; in just three years, we have had an increase in spending from $3.3 billion to $4.1 billion.

speech.para: It is obvious that the member for Dobell does not like good news. He wants to scratch around like mad in a frenzy until he can find something he can present as bad news. That was typical of his comments regarding national literacy. Let me remind the member for Dobell of the comments in the Sydney Morning Herald on 4 August this year—just four weeks ago—about the national literacy program and the application of national testing for literacy and numeracy across the country. It said:

Education ministers from five States and Territories have agreed to standardise primary school literacy tests, a move which for the first time will allow meaningful national comparisons of the literacy levels of Australian citizens.
It represents a breakthrough in the ongoing row between Federal and State education ministers and comes on the eve of nationwide testing of children in Years 3 and 5.
The article goes on to state:

In a joint statement by education ministers from NSW, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland and the ACT issued last night, the five ministers said the new approach would provide meaningful information compared to the previously unviable national literacy benchmarking process.

They said the information would provide parents and teachers with comprehensive data about children's progress and allow extra assistance to be targeted at students identified as having poor literacy skills.
That is a positive message in stark contrast to what the member for Dobell was trying to tell us.

The third point I want to make about the comments by the member for Dobell is that he seems to be determined to continue with the divisive comments regarding the comparison between funding for public education and funding for non-government schools. I remind the member for Dobell that in the last three years direct Commonwealth government funding for public schools has increased by 20 per cent, by $243 million. That is in addition to the financial assistance grants and in addition to the indirect funding. There has been an increase of 20 per cent in direct Commonwealth government grants to public schools.

I ask the member for Dobell this: if you are really saying that this government allocated too much money for non-government schools in this budget, which of the programs would you cut? Would you reduce the funding that increased spending for Catholic systemic schools that raised them from category 10 to category 11? Would you put the Catholic schools in the electorate of Dobell back down to category 10? Or would you oppose the measure to introduce the SES standard system for funding for non-government schools which gives greater equity, which changes the ERI system to an equity based, income based SES system? Would you change that, or would you just cut funding across the board? That is what I would like to know from the member for Dobell.

Further, I implore the member for Dobell to stop this divisive approach that pits public school against non-government school. It is not helpful. It is fostered by the teachers unions. It is encouraged by the ALP, and it is doing nothing for the children in our schools. It is simply fuelling a sense of rivalry and antagonism that the Labor Party is keen to see grow. I urge the member for Dobell to encourage our teachers and to encourage our students, be they in the public system or the non-government system. We have a system that works well side by side. We do not need members from the other side like the member for Dobell trying to create hostility between the two school systems.

This bill, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999, reinforces this government's commitment to school education. As I have already indicated, there has been an increase of $800 million over the past three years. This bill recognises the vital importance of school education in the development of our young people, in developing their skills, in developing their values and attitudes, in helping them to attain their achievement, in helping to build confidence and self-esteem, in helping to prepare them for a fulfilling and meaningful place in our society, and in helping them to be prepared to enter the work force. As I said, this government has already increased funding by 20 per cent in the last three years with 6.8 per cent in this budget for government schools.

This bill gives effect to a number of initiatives outlined in the budget earlier this year. Its provisions include $36.3 million next year for increased funding under the literacy and numeracy program to improve literacy and numeracy outcomes for students in the early and middle years of schooling. It allocates $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy for the year 2000. It continues the previous capital funding arrangements for non-government schools. It provides contingency funding for those struggling non-government schools in the transition to the new system of equity based funding, to which I have already referred. This allocation is part of a broader range of spending commitments by this government in the last budget.

I now turn in more detail to the issue of literacy and numeracy, the highlight of this bill. The emphasis on literacy and numeracy is part of this government's commitment to seeing that all young people reach adequate levels in literacy and numeracy by the time they leave school. It is to the shame of the former government that they were happy to support a system that let children slip through the net and leave school without adequate levels of literacy and numeracy. It must be a high priority of this government's program—of any government's program—to ensure that young people are literate and numerate by the time they leave school not only for their own self-fulfilment, satisfaction and self-esteem in life but also to enhance their employment prospects.

There has been much said of the correlation between literacy and numeracy levels and employment. For that reason alone, it is essential that we do whatever we can to redress shortcomings in literacy and numeracy standards. The essential link between levels of literacy, numeracy and employment has been shown in a number of studies over recent years. For instance, a study released in 1997 by the Australian Council for Educational Research showed that males with poor literacy and numeracy levels were twice as likely to be unemployed in their late teens as those with average skills or better. A 1996 study by Miller and Chiswell for the ABS showed that unemployment levels for those with excellent literacy skills averaged 3.6 per cent, those with good literacy and numeracy skills averaged five per cent, and, sadly, those with poor literacy skills averaged 18 per cent. The connection is clear.

Further, that same study showed that the length of time spent in unemployment is considerably longer for those with poor literacy and numeracy levels than it is for those with adequate skills. Finally, that study showed that the work force participation rate for those with high literacy skills is much better than those with poor skills. In fact, those with poor literacy skills had work force participation rates of less than 40 per cent whereas, according to this study, those with good or better literacy skills had work force participation rates over 85 per cent. The connection is quite clear, and thus this government has a commitment to do whatever it can to raise literacy and numeracy standards in our school system.

The Commonwealth government are working closely with state and territory governments to raise standards of literacy and numeracy across the board. Their commitment in March 1997 to an agreed national literacy and numeracy goal made this clear, when they said that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level. Just last month, as I said already, a number of states and territories introduced a common literacy and numeracy test for year 3 and year 5 students to ascertain the level of literacy and numeracy across the country to allow meaningful comparisons and to allow us to better target policies to meet those areas of need. I have already referred to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald regarding that.

This government has supported its commitment to literacy and numeracy with funding dollars. This government has put its money where its mouth is when it comes to literacy and numeracy levels. In this bill we have committed an extra $131 million over the next four years to literacy and numeracy programs, bringing it to a total of $869 million. That is, from the Howard government, a commitment of $869 million over the next four years to improve literacy and numeracy, with $216 million being provided in the next financial year alone.

This $131 million has two main components: firstly, an extra $84 million over the next three years to government and non-government schools under the existing arrangements to focus on literacy and numeracy needs in the early years of schooling; and, secondly, a new initiative—an additional $47 million over the next four years for literacy and numeracy initiatives in the middle years of schooling to address the needs of those who have slipped through the net, aimed at identifying and providing remediation for underachieving students from years 5 through to 10. The Commonwealth will develop guidelines to tightly target those students in need in these years and address that need.

As I have already indicated, these initiatives also include an extra $26.4 million next year and $90 million over the next three years for Asian language studies. This builds on programs already in place, particularly in the Chinese, Japanese, Korean and Indonesian languages. It aims at strengthening understanding of our region, at increasing the ability of our young people to engage in meaningful exchange with other countries in our region, at increasing meaningful and productive international interaction. It better places our young people in a position to capitalise on growing trade and tourism links and therefore employment opportunities.

Thirdly and fourthly, the program includes ongoing capital funding arrangements for non-government schools as per existing programs and emergency funding as we switch from the ERI based system for non-government schools to a much fairer income based SES indicator—the socioeconomic status indicator—that will better target money to those schools in need. That is an initiative which will provide great relief to many struggling lower income based non-government schools.

I would like to raise a few more general issues that arise both out of this bill and out of the recent budget in relation to this government's commitment to education and also respond to some of the comments of the member for Dobell. Firstly, this government's priorities to school education have been made clear. As I have said already, there has been an increase of $800 million over the past three years in the commitment of money to school education. This government is committed to quality education, with the commitment to literacy, the commitment to numeracy, the commitment to addressing those areas of need and ensuring that across the country we can reach sustainable, measurable and acceptable standards of literacy and numeracy. That shows our commitment to quality.

Secondly, this government is committed to education which leads somewhere in terms of employment potential and employment opportunities. This government has increased spending over the past couple of years on vocational education programs. It has been committed to the Jobs Pathway Program to link young people from school straight into traineeships and apprenticeships and into employment opportunities. That shows our commitment to education for our young people will deliver results in terms of employment opportunities for them.

Thirdly, it shows this government's commitment to choice in education. Contrary to the rantings and ravings of the member for Dobell, this government is not committed to any ideological position—either public education or non-government education. This government is committed simply to supporting the choice of parents. Parents have a right to choose whether they want their children educated in a public school or in a non-government school. This government is committed to supporting that choice in any way that we can that is equitable to both groups of parents. Seventy per cent of our parents choose to send their children to public schools. This government supports that choice and supports the education of those children in public schools. Thirty per cent of parents choose to send their children to non-government schools. This government likewise supports their choice to send their children to non-government schools and is committed to ensuring that those children also receive well deserved quality education.

This government is committed to equity in education, be it in the public sector or the non-government sector. This government is committed to assisting families—particularly struggling families and young people from disadvantaged families—to receive a fair level of education. The changed funding that I have already referred to for the non-government system switches funding from a faulty, inequitable ERI system to a system based on needs and the ability of parents to pay. It is a strong equity measure aimed at helping our poorer schools and the children from families attending those poorer schools.

The decision by this government to support parental choice and to provide assistance to non-government schools has, at times, brought a barrage of misinformed criticism from some parts of the teacher unions, from the ALP and, unfortunately, from some representatives of some of the P&C associations. These criticisms are not rational, not accurate and, as I said to the member for Dobell, not fair and not helpful in the debate about education. Instead of encouraging our schools to work together and instead of supporting our whole education system they attempt to make political mileage by pitting one part of our system against the other.

This government's support for the non-government school sector, which is based on equity and choice, is not at the expense of the government sector. It is not at the expense of the public sector. We have seen a 20 per cent increase in direct Commonwealth government funding to public schools in the past three years. In the 1999-2000 financial year there will be an extra $243 million in direct Commonwealth government funding, in addition to the indirect financial assistance grants, to public schools. In the next quadrennium, we will see an extra $1 billion in direct Commonwealth funding to our public schools, bringing the total annual funding by the end of that quadrennium to $1.9 billion.

I have a couple of other comments to make which the member for Dobell, many of those opposite and many in the teacher unions seem to ignore. It is the states that have traditionally had prime responsibility for the public school system and the Commonwealth government has picked up the bill for the struggling non-government schools to bring them up to a standard that is comparable. Over the past two years the financial assistance grants, from which the state governments fund those public schools, have increased by five to six per cent a year. That is extra from the Commonwealth government which the state governments use to assist public schools.

It is surely fair to help the families who choose to send their children to non-government schools. After all, in public schools students are 90 per cent taxpayer funded and in non-government schools they are only 55 per cent taxpayer funded. The parents of children in non-government schools subsidise to a level of 45 per cent the education of their children. The average government funding per student for a secondary student in a Catholic systemic school is around $3,500. The average government funding for students in public schools is about $5,600. Parents who send their children to non-government schools subsidise the education of their children on average by $2,000 per head, thereby reducing the pressure on the public system and allowing public education money to be greater per student in the public system.

The government support for the public and non-government system is based on choice, equity and a determination to maintain quality in both the public and non-government systems. This bill is a further indication of this government's support for the schooling of our children, be they in the public or non-government sector.

talk.start.para: —The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 , amongst other things, makes provisions in the year 2000 for $36.3 million in funding for literacy and numeracy outcomes for students in the early and middle years of schooling. I am glad the member for Macquarie got on to per capita spending on education. If he had developed that argument he may have come a bit closer to the truth about what is actually going on in education in this nation.

speech.para: This is a government, along with most state governments, which has simply lost the plot when it comes to the education, the schooling, of primary and junior secondary children. These governments once totally ignored primary education. That they now recognise the importance of literacy and numeracy outcomes is a little step forward, but that is all it is. There is little or no recognition of greater intellectual skills developing in children aged seven to 14. The lowly intellectual knowledge skills are praised. The higher intellectual skills of insight, analysis, synthesis, comprehension, translation, interpretation, comparison, prediction, probability, estimation, aggregation and so on are ignored.

Literacy and numeracy skills are important, but so too are attitudinal skills, social skills, technological skills, physical skills, and, with respect to the wishes of families and communities, cultural and spiritual skills. It is the togetherness or the confluence of all these skills that determines the future success or otherwise of all people. The time that occurs is largely when a child is aged seven to 11.

In a watershed longitudinal study published in The Times Education Supplement in 1986, the London Education Authority highlighted that the most successful determinant of future success or otherwise was the schooling re ceived by a child aged between seven and 11 and that schooling was far more important than race, socioeconomic background, gender, religion or ethnic background. Of course, in Australia there are far too many people who simply ignore the needs of not only our children but also this nation's future requirements. Drug programs and crime prevention programs are not worth the paper they are written on when seven to 12 year olds are overlooked.

You can find numerous examples of the funding of education in Australia, public and private—it is not a matter of equity and choice; that is absolute nonsense—that reflect tradition and privilege but nothing else, and certainly not a sound education rationale. Funding levels in education fly in the face of commonsense and absolute truth in education. For example, the older the learner the more self-reliant, the more independent, the more self-directed and, just perhaps, the lesser the need for resources in many cases. The younger the learner the more vulnerable, the more dependent and the greater the need for resources.

If a comparison is made between per capita grants in primary schools and universities, the differential is a whopping 400 per cent. The differentiation between primary and senior secondary schools can be over 100 per cent. Something marvellous must happen in the Christmas holidays if you can jump from 100 per cent to 400 per cent funding. By making these comparisons, I am not arguing for lower per capita fees at universities or secondary schools, but I am arguing for higher per capita grants for primary aged students.

If I can use my own state of South Australia as an example, an examination of a current school budget is illuminating. The per capita grant for all children is $2,659—that is the basic grant. If a child is in reception to year 2, the supplementary funding is $709, making a total of $3,468. If a child is in years 8 to 10, the supplementary funding is $911, making a total of $3,570. If a child is in years 11 to 13, the supplementary funding is $2,142, making a total of $4,801. It is simply amazing what Christmas holidays do to resource levels. But what if a child is in years 3 to 7? That is the time when schooling is the single largest determinant of future success. What would you say would be a reasonable allocation? Three thousand dollars? Not quite. Two thousand dollars? No, not really. One thousand dollars? No, not quite. Five hundred dollars? No. Two hundred dollars? No. One hundred dollars? No. Fifty dollars? It surely has to be 50 bucks? No. Twenty dollars? No. Ten dollars? No. It is $6, Mr Deputy Speaker. I know that sounds incredible, but it is true. If it were not so sad it would be laughable.

A number of voices have pointed out the stupidity of poor resource levels for primary schools, and I am pleased to report what is apparently one more. In the Adelaide Advertiser on 19 August, the following was attributed to South Australian Chief Executive Officer, Mr Geoff Spring, formerly Director-General in Victoria:
Funding for schools also needed to change with primary schools becoming better funded than high schools.
But we now need to recognise that we need to put more resources into primary schools.
If we invest in the primary area we have less drop-outs.
With more funding we can ensure there is more communication between teachers and schools to ensure students do not slip through the net.
We need to make sure they get the teaching they need, and recognise at an early age the kids who need early help.

Hear, hear! I congratulate Mr Spring on his sane and very rational comments. Since I made my maiden speech in this House some 11 years ago, Mr Spring, a senior bureaucrat, is the only bureaucrat of that status I have ever heard say something that should have been said 20 years ago when even simple-minded principals recognised there was a problem and mounted a campaign called `Primary Means First'.

This attempted to rectify the unfair differential funding as existed then. Unfortunately, the bureaucrats of the day—the secondary school principals, the teachers union leadership and other sectors of education at TAFE and university—white-anted the `Primary Means First' campaign, as they did subsequent campaigns—`Into the 90s' and the `South Australian Primary Review'. Perhaps that is ready to change in South Australia, a state that, up to 1979, led the nation in innovations in education for over a century, but which has allowed itself to be dragged back to lowly lowest common denominator over the past 20 years. Let us hope Mr Spring withstands the coming white-anting which certainly will be directed at him. Notwithstanding that predicted reaction among the powerful tradition and privilege in education I wish Mr Spring deserved success, for if he is successful he will, within a generation, change the modus operandi and the whole psyche of South Australia for a whole lot better; certainly he will change the negative psyche that it is operating with at the moment.

Much has been claimed by this government as to the improvement in literacy and numerary outcomes with their stewardship. Nothing could be further from the truth. The government have missed the point completely, as have members opposite, and people out there in the electorate know. On 3 August, A Current Affair ran a segment focussing on the literacy and numeracy needs of Australian children. I did not see the program, but I was called about it by a constituent of mine, Mrs Val Pudney. Mrs Pudney informed me that her interest in the literacy and numeracy issue stems from problems being experienced by a young family member. At the end of the segment the station provided a telephone number for viewers to call if they wished to express a view on the matter. Mrs Pudney called that number but she had to wait more than three hours to get through, such was public interest in the particular report. The level of concern in the community about this matter is emphasised by the fact that callers were being asked only for their name and contact details. No discussions were taking place—at least by the time Mrs Pudney got through.

This is very clear evidence that government funding to help solve this problem—that is, the literacy and numeracy problem—is, in the eyes of the community, wholly inadequate. The view is that the government is merely skimming the surface, and that is true. There is enormous concern about this problem in the community, and this bill and the meagre increase in funds it offers is demonstration that the government is failing to take the matter seriously and is failing to listen to community concerns. It is a trivial allocation and just a bit of window-dressing. Furthermore, the issue is far more complex than simple literacy and numerary skills.

Young people need those skills but they also need attitudinal skills, social skills, technological skills, physical skills, cultural skills and spiritual skills as well. It is the confluence of all these skills that enables young children to succeed in life. As far as attitudinal and physical skills are concerned, there are some splendid examples reported in today's Australian. Like other athletes, Ian Thorpe said it does not matter whether or not you come first, it is more important that you are having a go. He was referring to his pretty average `go' at sports. But his attitude is right.
Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Mr Hockey, you do not know what you are talking about. Keep quiet. Nick Green is part of the Oarsome Foursome. He rows for Australia. He had a fantastic time at school. His attitudes and his physical skills were well developed. Moneghetti said that he certainly was not a star at school sports, but he loved them anyway. Gillian Rolton was a bit of a duffer at sport, but there is an interesting little comment about her from the age of seven to 11—everything went by the board when Rolton got her first horse at the age of 11 and became a great world champion.

speech.para: The federal government would have you believe that, by throwing a few million dollars here and there and having a testing program for years 3 and 5, they are serious about the needs of young primary age children. But of course they are not. As any parent or grandparent of a child having literacy or numeracy learning difficulties knows, the federal government's remedies to the problem fall a long way short of what is required. In fact, the government are quite perfunctory in many things and they are perfunctory in education: they just go through the motions.

The government is trying to get away with a small amount of funding and a lot of rhetoric. But the community will not let the govern ment get away with taking this problem lightly. Whether you agree with the line taken by A Current Affair is irrelevant. What is relevant is that it focused on a great need of our young people, and the overwhelming response to the story right across the country is testimony to that.

During the week beginning 2 August this year, in my home state of South Australia, literacy and numeracy testing programs were being conducted. Teachers, professional and union bodies opposed these testing programs. I suppose that on philosophical and educational grounds their opposition and stance are valid. However, in political terms, their opposition is short-sighted. The real problem in primary schools is a resource problem—which no-one, except maybe the current chief executive officer in South Australia, recognises is the problem.

Since 1979, and despite the denials of state and federal governments, the real value of resources allocated to Australian primary schools, public and private, has diminished. You need to look at the per capita grants, which have all fallen. Whether they be for university students, vocational and TAFE students, senior secondary, junior secondary, primary or early primary, they have all fallen. Anyone familiar with resources that are allocated to primary schools knows this to be true. The $6 supplementary funding in South Australia for students in years 3 to 7 that I outlined earlier is testimony to this.

That other sectors of education—universities, TAFEs and senior secondary—continue to fail to assist their primary school colleagues and their school communities in securing a higher level of allocation of resources is highly regrettable. That they continue to do this against their own future interests—because these primary students will all become TAFE, senior secondary or university students at some time in the future—is simply beyond my comprehension. For some reason, those sectors have been convinced that a fair deal for young children in resources means fewer resources for their particular sector, and they have behaved accordingly over the last 20 years.

That is just gross irresponsibility. The overwhelming majority of these young children will in fact take their place at senior secondary, TAFE and university level at some time in the future. There are many examples of those three sectors criticising governments for taking on short-term goals, and we have had evidence of that almost every year for the past 20 years. But, in this instance, they are guilty of exactly the same offence.

Why is there no effective voice in this country to defend and promote the interests of young children? It seems that it does not matter what is discussed—whether it be education, drugs, literacy and numeracy, family relationships or whatever—when the subject of the debate is children aged between five and 15 no-one is seriously interested. Take drugs, for example. Governments around the world are struggling to deal with the drug problem in their communities. At the risk of causing offence to others who have occupied this House, I suggest that no government has embarked upon a serious drug education program in this country.

It is well known that prevention is always far cheaper and far more effective than cure. It is also well known that the attributes and skills of our young are largely acquired between the ages of seven and 12. If our efforts with that age group fail, then no program, no amount of money, no amount of bleating and no amount of rhetoric and grandstanding will solve the problems that drugs and dysfunctional behaviour are causing in our communities.

Who in this House could identify a business, a union, a welfare group, a religious or community group or a teaching or political organisation that reflects accurately the needs of our developing young and does something positive about it? Absolute silence would greet that particular question. What happens in this country is a deliberate demeaning of any need expressed by any group of people trying to address the primary needs of young children. It is something to be greatly ashamed of and something which started very badly 20 years ago, and we are paying for the consequences now. This is a generational negligence. The negligence is demonstrated a generation down the track.

The literacy and numeracy problem among young children should not be a partisan matter. It is a matter of national importance and should be treated as such. But the failure to do so has allowed the problem to become progressively worse. In 1979, it was largely accepted that 10 per cent of children had grave literacy and numeracy problems. In the late 1980s, the figure was 20 per cent. Now, in the late 1990s, it is 30 per cent. It is an escalating problem and it is about time that serious action was taken to turn it around. Bureaucrats have fudged their findings because they have averaged out the top 20 per cent of students, who over the past 20 years have done progressively very well indeed.

The problem for the non-achievers has got progressively worse. The question is how much longer parents and grandparents will have to put up with an inadequate response to literacy, numeracy and other resource implication problems for young children in this nation. The answer is at least until the removal of the Howard government—and maybe a few state governments along the way—if the trivial provisions in this bill are any indication of their intentions.

The bill also makes provision for the continued funding of the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools Strategy, an initiative of the previous Labor government. Labor instigated this program because it understood just how important it is for the future of this country that young people develop a better understanding of our near neighbours, including a competence in their languages. But the irony is that, while on one hand the government is encouraging young people to take up the study of foreign languages, on the other hand it is doing virtually nothing towards helping them gain a better grasp of their own language.

It should be obvious that if they are unable to operate effectively in their own language then it is so much harder to learn to speak a foreign language. With grave literacy and numeracy problems on the rise, the study of foreign languages and the job opportunities it gives rise to is becoming an impossible goal for an increasing number of our young people. Perhaps if the world language were Russian or Chinese, then governments in Australia might do something serious about literacy and numeracy inadequacies amongst our young. But, with English being the language of politics, finance and trade, we continue to delude ourselves about the failings of the education system in Australia.

Everyone in this House knows that those countries in our region and in Europe which have enjoyed great success in recent years have committed gross amounts of national gross domestic product back into massive investment in education, and they did it a generation ago. The latest figures I examined, which compared the investment in education by countries in the OECD, placed Australia right down near the bottom of the list. This fact does not seem to have registered with state governments and the current federal government, and that is a cause of great national shame.

While the federal government must take the primary responsibility for this situation, the problem is endemic right across the country. Religious, other private schools and institutions also fail to acknowledge the differential resources between primary, secondary and further education. Business, union, welfare and other organisations still fail to acknowledge the needs of children in primary school. Until this outlook changes, until a more appropriate allocation of resources is achieved, the problems we are facing in this nation with our young will simply get worse. Unfortunately, this bill will do very little to address what is becoming a very grave problem in this country, and one that will harm our collective future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Contrary to what the member for Port Adelaide says, this government has not missed the point with regard to funding for literacy and numeracy programs. It is not just going through the motions. I commend the Howard government's steps to ensure that Australian youth are equipped with the necessary reading and writing skills. In this modern age, if you cannot read or write it is very difficult to hold down a job. It is like when the starter's gun goes and you cannot get your feet out of the starter's block—you cannot move, your feet are caught. You cannot progress. You cannot even start the race, let alone reach the finishing line.

speech.para: Research shows that young Australians who have poor literacy and numeracy skills are more likely to leave school early. They also have poor access to further education and training and are at much higher risk of unemployment. Acquiring literacy and numeracy skills has been proven to reduce people's risk of unemployment by boosting their ability to participate in education. Acquiring literacy and numeracy skills improves one's ability to successfully participate in the work force, and acquiring literacy and numeracy skills enables one to make decisions in life.

In the past, many young people could leave school early and get a semiskilled or unskilled job. Nowadays these jobs do not exist. Jobs have shifted as the second half of the 20th century has seen the explosive growth in communications and information technologies. The reality is that society has changed. We are moving into a society which is driven by technology and requires higher literacy skills. While at school, the experiences a child gains shape his or her skills, attitudes and knowledge. As a government, we have a responsibility to ensure that each Australian child has the opportunity to acquire literacy and numeracy skills.

Dr David Kemp, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, said last week in this chamber that improving the literacy and numeracy levels of young Australians is probably the single most important thing you could do to assist the educationally disadvantaged people in this country. As a mother of three adult children who had tremendous opportunities in the government school system, I am a strong advocate of ensuring that every child is given the best chance to fulfil his or her potential and that each child has access to educational programs and resources to acquire the skills he or she needs for their future.

I strongly support any government measures to ensure our children do not miss out on opportunities but are given the best chances for success in life. The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 reflects the coalition government's concern with literacy and numeracy achievements of Australia's school students. Literacy and numeracy have been a concern of the Howard government since coming to office, and Dr Kemp has played a tremendous role in ensuring Australia has a clear direction and goals for a national approach to literacy and numeracy.

This government, for the first time, has put into place a comprehensive range of programs which are opening up for young people horizons and opportunities which they were denied for the 13 years that the Labor Party was in office. We now have a national plan to make sure that every child coming out of primacy school has the foundation skills for life. The governments of the states, the territories and the Commonwealth have committed themselves for the first time to national literacy standards, to a system of comparable testing for young children and to a national goal that every young person coming out of primary school should be able to read, write and spell at an adequate level.

This plan follows the government bringing together the best experts in Australia to tell us what level of literacy skills children need to have at the end of year 3, at the end of those early years of schooling, to continue successfully through their schooling. Out of this we put in place the national literacy standards. We conducted the first national literacy survey. We analysed the results against those standards and found that 30 per cent of young Australians in year 3 were below that standard.

The Commonwealth has agreed with the states that every child in the government system will be assessed against that standard and that they will report those results from year to year so that we can see whether every child is coming up to the standard. Following further negotiations with ministers, we have had another victory for Australian youth and their parents, with the standardising of primary school literacy tests across state borders to ensure that every young child acquires the literacy skills to enable them to read at the national standard.

Since the beginning of last month, the states and territories have engaged in assessments of young people in years 3 and 5 against the national literacy benchmarks. As a result of these measures in developing a regime of comparable testing against benchmark standards, for the first time school children in Australia are being assessed as to whether or not they meet literacy standards and whether or not they have the skills to continue successfully with their education. As Dr Kemp said last week in the chamber:
Parents have a right to this information. Young people have a right to learn to read and write effectively.
The additional funding allocated through this legislation is a positive step in improving the literacy and numeracy skills of students in the early and middle years of schooling.

A significant point I wish to make is that the legislation focuses on middle years of schooling. In the past, those years have not been addressed to such an extent as this. By `middle years of schooling', we refer to students in upper primary and secondary school through to year 10. In the past the coalition government has focused on numeracy and literacy standards in the early years of schooling and in the final years through the Full Service Schools Program, which caters for students who are at risk of not completing school or who have returned to school through mutual obligation requirements.

The legislation currently before the parliament takes into account those students in middle schooling. An amount of $47.1 million over four years will be provided for strategies to improve the literacy and numeracy skills of underachieving students in the middle years of schooling. The funding will be directed towards students who have not developed basic literacy and numeracy skills and who, therefore, have difficulty coping with the demands of the school curriculum. Literacy and numeracy support for such students will reduce the risk of unemployment by increasing their ability to participate in education and training and improve their ability to successfully participate in the work force.

The allocated funding is, in a sense, a completion of the government's policy focus on literacy and numeracy. It recognises that there is a need for support for improved literacy and numeracy achievement throughout schooling, particularly for those students who miss out on acquiring adequate skills in their early years of schooling. Ensuring that our children have adequate literacy and numeracy skills is vitally important in the education equation. As I mentioned earlier, research shows that those without these skills increase their risk of unemployment. Our unemployment rate is the lowest it has been in decades—7.2 per cent. The coalition government is committed to lowering this rate even further. I believe it is through programs like those of literacy and numeracy that we will ensure our youth have adequate skills for the workplace.

Australia is a bountiful nation by any measure, including where I live on the Gold Coast, the nation's sixth largest city and arguably the nation's tourist capital. We are also rich in our diversity of people. Programs such as those of literacy and numeracy enhance opportunities for our youth and allow us to best prepare for the future. While in Japan recently at a lunch hosted by Japanese business organisations, the Prime Minister announced his intention that Australia become a can-do country. These simple words formed headlines in many of our Australian newspapers the following day. While they are simple words, they convey a tremendous amount about the will of the Australian people and the government's determination to ensure that Australians have a fertile ground in which to achieve their potential, whether it be through innovative business opportunity or fast growing industries such as biotechnology.

Programs of literacy and numeracy are in line with the Prime Minister's vision to create a can-do country; literacy and numeracy programs parallel this vision. I would go so far as to say that the Australian government is taking steps to ensure that, as a government, we foster the development of can-do children so that, when they are ready to exit school, they have acquired adequate literacy and numeracy skills.

The additional capital grants funding which forms part of this legislation is another real example of the coalition government's commitment to education in this nation. This funding for non-government schools is a continuation of the government's commitment to maintain funding at current, real levels. Likewise, the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy is a forward thinking program, designed to equip our youth for the future. Asia is important to Australia and will continue to be so. This strategy goes far in supporting our links to key regional neighbours including China, Indonesia, Japan and Korea.

Under this strategy, by the year 2006, 60 per cent of students in years 3 to 10 will be learning one of the four targeted languages—that is, Chinese, Indonesian, Japanese and Korean. The remaining 40 per cent will be learning other languages. Fifteen per cent of year 12 students will be learning one of the four targeted languages, and another 10 per cent of year 12 students will be learning other languages. All school students in years 3 to 10 will have Asia content incorporated into the subjects that they are studying.

This legislation extends funding to the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools Strategy. The Commonwealth, states and territories have endorsed this strategy and its associated targets until 2006. If we do not continue with this strategy, I firmly believe it will be to the detriment of Australia in the medium to long term. Many leading authors and foreign affairs experts, including Professor Stephen FitzGerald, Australia's first Ambassador to China, have argued the point that, if Australian children are not educated about our Asian neighbours, we will be left behind in the next millennium as we participate in the global economy.

This legislation takes funding for the strategy to the end of 2002. Including this funding, the Commonwealth will have provided $207 million to support the study of Asian languages and studies since the commencement of this strategy in 1994-95. This is a tremendous indication that we are committed to educating our Australian youth to ensure that Australia is in the best position to work with our Asian neighbours to benefit our nation in the 21st century.

I commend the government's plans in allocating this funding in a move designed to develop students' understanding of Asian languages and cultures so that tomorrow's work force is well placed to participate in the global economy. Our children will be the winners out of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 . They will become better equipped with the vital skills of reading, writing and counting that will better prepare them for the decisions they will make in life. They will also be better prepared for participating in the global economy.

The government's renewed commitment to literacy and numeracy and expanding education programs for our youth is an indication that the coalition is responding to the education needs of our young students. It is an indication that the coalition is determined to ensure that we have equity in our schools and attention is paid to the needs of students likely to be educationally disadvantaged. The policies this government is putting forward will create jobs for young Australians. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —In the time allocated to me this evening I want to address two major issues in connection with the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 . The first is the very severe doubt that has been cast over an election promise from the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, to improve the quality of schoolteachers in Australia through the National Professional Development Program. The second is the entire area of literacy and numeracy—where we are heading in improving literacy and numeracy in Australia.

speech.para: In relation to the first issue, I would be very interested if the minister could explain to the House and the people of Australia whether he intends to keep the promise he made to improve the quality of teaching in Australian schools or whether he has in fact scrapped that 1998 election promise. This bill was an ideal opportunity to include the commitments made by the minister in the lead-up to the 1998 election. Going back to the 1996 election campaign, the Howard government promised not to abolish Labor's Professional Development Program, but they did abolish it. I refer to a statement contained on page 2 of the `1996 Coalition Schools and TAFE Policy', which says:
A Coalition Government will continue the National Professional Development Program.

Obviously, this was a non-core promise. Just a couple of years later, in the 1998 election campaign, they realised their mistake and promised to restore the program. Here I refer to page 10 of the `1998 Coalition Schools Policy', which says:
The Coalition will provide $75 million over three years to strengthen the skills of the teaching profession.

If the minister plans to keep this promise, he must explain to us why there is no money in the schools legislation that is now before this parliament and how he will meet his promise that `program activities will commence at the beginning of 2000'. That statement was contained in the minister's press release of 11 May this year. How can those program activities commence at the beginning of the year 2000 if there is no provision in the legislation for that funding? It is an ideal opportunity lost. We would be very interested in the minister's explanation on this matter.

I want to now spend some time discussing the second issue of literacy and numeracy. This legislation allocates $36.3 million for the year 2000 to increase funding under the literacy and numeracy program, especially for the middle years. So there is a special program to boost literacy and numeracy in the middle years. This is obviously something that we support. We think it is terrific that there is an increase in funding for literacy and numeracy, and we do not really have any difficulty with the concentration on the middle years. However, I do question, very gravely, the adequacy of funding for literacy and numeracy under this government.

A very significant statement was made in March 1997 by the Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers. They agreed to the national literacy goal that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level. That is an admirable goal and one to which all members of the House of Representatives would be committed. However, my concern is that the minister is spending a lot of time trying to create some sort of political row over this issue of increasing literacy and numeracy in Australia—more for the sake of his own self-aggrandisement and getting himself on programs such as 60 Minutes, and less fortunately for him Four Corners. He is trying to fabricate some sort of fracas so that he can say, `I am the hero and the rest of you are the bad guys.' That is simply not true.

In fact, in early August of this year there was a historic announcement by the state and territory governments of New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria, Queensland and the ACT that they would undertake nationally comparable literacy testing. That announcement has everything to do with a sensible, bipartisan, cooperative approach based on the basic skills test introduced by the New South Wales Labor government 12 years ago and nothing at all to do with the minister's bullying and grandstanding. My colleague the shadow minister for education and member for Dobell earlier in this debate very eloquently pointed to the deficiencies and criticisms of the minister in his grandstanding on this matter. I will simply repeat a number of the statements that have been made about the minister's behaviour—not by Labor state ministers but by the Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, Phil Gude. He said, among other things, in the Herald Sun on 12 May 1997:
Literacy is our highest priority and, despite Dr Kemp undermining the previous collaborative process, we are determined this important process goes ahead.
Next, Mr Gude, in the Herald Sun on 15 September 1997, said:
He ought to do the right thing . . . own up to the fact that he's manipulated the figures in a most dishonest and disgraceful fashion.
Then Mr Gude, in the Age on 16 September 1997, said:
It is a debate that has hit the public arena as a result of political grandstanding by Dr Kemp.

The Liberal Minister for Education has exposed the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs for what he is: someone who is content with grandstanding and creating division around this issue instead of using a collaborative approach. We should not be surprised about this, because the Prime Minister was very happy with the entry of the current Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs into the parliament. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may recall that the current minister took over from the then sitting member for Goldstein, Mr Ian Macphee, in 1990. Mr Ian Macphee would be generally regarded as a wet, someone with a genuine social conscience. He was preselected out of that seat by the present minister.

I see the present minister as being someone from a long line of punishers and straighteners. He is more concerned with punishing kids and schools where there are real difficulties and funding problems. He has said publicly on a number of occasions that his own idea of a literacy and numeracy program is to have a national list of the schools, which then puts the students in those schools in the position of being shamed. What he really wants is a shaming list. Why does he want that? Because it makes great headlines in the tabloid newspapers, in radio interviews and on television. You get the television cameras and say, `The kids in these schools are illiterate and innumerate. Isn't this a terrible thing?' That is not a constructive approach to education and addressing a vital issue in this country, an issue that goes to the heart of inequality.

The member for Curtin and I will be sharing a platform at the Sydney Institute on 6 October, where we will be talking on the issue of inequality. Going to the heart of inequality is the problem of literacy and numeracy in Australia. What is the minister's approach to it? `We'll get a list, and we'll expose the schools that are performing poorly, and then we can get the media and get photographs of the kids.' There is nothing more despicable, in my mind, than that sort of approach. That is self-aggrandisement and promotion on the part of the minister but absolutely devastating for the kids involved.

The states have got their act together: they have been doing literacy and numeracy testing for a number of years—the Victorian government for 12 years. In my state of Queensland, they have been doing that since the mid-1990s, when funding was provided by the then Goss government for a literacy and numeracy program called the Year 2 Diagnostic Net. It is working extremely well. However it could do with a greatly increased influx of funding. The Year 2 Diagnostic Net identifies the kids who are having difficulties in reading and writing, and then a Reading Recovery program follows for those children so they get the intensive assistance—which is costly—to enable them to boost their literacy and numeracy.

The results are tremendous. After the Reading Recovery program, more than 90 per cent of the children who are identified in the Year 2 Diagnostic Net in Queensland have been brought up to the appropriate level of reading and writing for their age. This is a tremendous result, made possible by the foresight of the Goss government and by the funding the Goss government provided. Here, I give credit where credit is due: the Borbidge government continued the funding for that program. Now the Beattie government has continued the funding and is applying additional resources. It is a very encouraging situation in Queensland. It is a less encouraging situation in Victoria where, I am advised, the state government has very substantially reduced the number of teachers. That then detracts from the intensive support that the children who are identified through these literacy and numeracy testing programs are able to receive.

We do not need punishers and straighteners when it comes to literacy and numeracy and looking after the future of our children. We need expanders and creators. Sadly, the minister is neither an expander nor a creator. But that is the sort of approach that we need. In this budget, in the vital area of education, it is regrettable to report that the government has provided less than $10 a year of extra funding to the children in government schools. The minister likes to incorporate in his figures an adjustment for the cost of living and then say, `See—we're providing more money.' That is not more real resources. At a time which is absolutely vital to Australia's future, kids in government schools are receiving an extra $10 a year from this government. Yet, through its enrolment benchmark adjustment, the Commonwealth government has presided over a $21.1 million cut to funding for government schools. In my home state of Queensland, there has been a lift in enrolments between 1996 and 1998 of 9,351 students and a commensurate curtailment of funding of $3.5 million through the enrolment benchmark adjustment. What are the priorities of this government when they cut funding to government schools through the enrolment benchmark adjustment?

As my colleague the member for Dobell, the shadow minister for education, mentioned earlier in this debate, if the Prime Minister of Australia had maintained the previous government's investment in education and research—that is, the Labor government's investment in education and research—at three per cent of gross domestic product, which is where it was when this government assumed office, Australia would be spending an extra $2.87 billion on education and research. Tragically, we are seeing a very substantial reduction in the investment in the future of this country and the investment in education and research.
This should not really surprise us. On 2 March 1987, when he was under siege from the Joh for PM campaign, the Prime Minister boasted proudly in an interview with John Laws in these terms:
Everybody who knows me knows that I am the most conservative leader the Liberal Party has ever had.

There was never a truer statement, and he is at least as conservative today as he was then.
