That statement was made within weeks of a declaration by the Prime Minister that he would take a scalpel to Medicare and pull it right apart. He was beaten badly at that poll and decided that he needed to rescind that policy, but he has put a very large nick in the vein supplying funding to Medicare, and it is bleeding to death. He is still achieving his objective there.

On industrial relations legislation, it is the same thing. His long cherished goal was to tip the balance in favour of employers over employees. Now we have the second wave of industrial relations legislation designed to do precisely that. Going back to his days as Treasurer, his other long cherished objective was for a GST. It has been a long time coming as far as he is concerned, but from 1 July next year we will have a GST. Yet on the fundamental issues of closing the loopholes and repairing the income tax base through the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and foreign tax credit system, the current Prime Minister described those taxes in debates in the parliament as `nasty', `stupid' and `madness'. There we have the attitude of the current Prime Minister and the attitude of the current Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. They come from the same stable. They boast about how conservative they are, and they are right.

The future of federal-state relations is brought sharply into question through the legislation that has been through this parliament in relation to the tax package, the sorts of funding arrangements that are contained here and what will happen to those arrangements from 1 July next year. From 1 July next year, the untied grants from the Commonwealth to the states will not be reduced or diminished but will be abolished in their entirety. Eighteen billion dollars will be gone because the states are going to get the GST. It has been made quite clear that there are no guarantees from the Commonwealth about ongoing funding in the tied grants to the states after the so-called GST transition period. That transition period may be three or four years, but Treasury officials made it quite clear to their state counterparts at the most recent Premiers Conference that there are no guarantees on funding for the tied grants.

What are the tied grants spent on? They are spent on literacy and numeracy programs. Australia is confronting the prospect of having those tied grants, including literacy and numeracy programs, cut back or abolished after the so-called GST transition period. Our fears about that were compounded the other day when the Treasurer declared, `I am an income tax cut man.' He wants to continually reduce the top marginal rate of income tax. He said a few weeks before that that he would like to see the top rate pushed out to many multiples of average weekly earnings. A couple of weeks ago, he said, `I am an income tax cut man. We've got to get that top rate down.' That is how they are going to finance it—they will keep reducing the top rate of income tax and providing extra income tax relief for high income earners, funded by cuts in these vital literacy and numeracy services through the tied grants to the states.

The country's future is in the balance when we are faced with these sorts of choices. People say, `What really is the difference between Labor and the coalition?' There are fundamental differences, but nothing more fundamental than the commitment of Labor to invest in the nation's future. What is the nation's future? It is our children. I have three children. I want to see them succeed. There are children in Logan City who would love to get some extra support at school in literacy and numeracy through home visiting, parenting programs and so on.

All of these possibilities are open to us, and the funding can be identified, except we are facing a choice between the government's risky tax scheme or Labor's commitment to provide affordable basic services. The Labor commitment is to provide decent, affordable services in the form of education of our kids and investment in the nation's future in research and development. That is the choice that we are looking at. That is the choice that will clearly be put in front of the Australian people at the next election: either further income tax cuts and a risky tax scheme or an investment in the nation's future by the Labor Party. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There could be few greater gifts to a young child than the opportunity to have an early and successful start to learning to read. If children are provided with the right literacy and reading experiences in their early years and learn to read, they will go on to read to learn. To introduce young children to lan guage and literature at an early age so that they learn to read successfully is to open a world of adventure to them, to feed their appetites for learning, wondering and living, as the member for Rankin rightly acknowledges. I look forward to our shared platform at the Sydney Institute on these issues on 6 October.

speech.para: The supreme importance of positive literacy, language and reading experiences for young children must surely be acknowledged as setting the stage for useful and productive citizenship in later years. Reading is indeed learned. It therefore must be taught, supported and sustained. Reading does not come naturally, as speech does. Reading the English language requires understanding of the alphabetic writing system. There has been research at national and international levels to support the view that effective classroom instruction in the early grades by well-prepared teachers is the most powerful method for preventing reading and learning problems. The most effective classroom method for early reading, so the experts say, involves a combination of explicit instruction in word recognition skills and reading comprehension strategies with opportunities to practise these skills in literature.

The importance of a progressive and effective education system cannot be overstated. Our education system is the vehicle by which our young people learn many of the skills that will ultimately take them into the work force or into further education and training. Our education system should be the best it can be, constantly looking forward with new ideas and measures to provide the maximum opportunities for our young people in the increasingly competitive Australian and global labour market.

I have spoken of the need for literacy skills. Numeracy skills are no less important. The ability to have a good basic understanding of mathematics is no less applicable in our information age of highly sophisticated computerisation. To prepare for further education, for employment or for everyday activities, our young people require basic numeracy skills. Mastering the challenge of mathematics for success in higher education is one thing, but basic mathematics can teach a way of thinking that will apply in every workplace and is essential for informed civic participation.

We need numeracy skills to understand a daily newspaper, to pay taxes, to invest for the future and to participate in any community activities where budget decisions are made. Whether a young person aims to be a mechanic and needs to apply physics formulae to wire electrical circuits for today's cars, whether they aim to be a research scientist in the biotechnology industry or whether they want to work in a retail store, their introduction to numeracy skills in early school years will help set their path. Mastering basic mathematical concepts or more complex approaches to solving problems will prepare young people for the careers of the 21st century as well as the demands of everyday life.

Possibly one of the most important policy decisions by this government in terms of education has been the focus on literacy and numeracy. This focus has extended from early school years now to middle school years and, in the context of employment policy, as an aspect of mutual obligation. Reading, writing and basic numeracy are amongst the most essential skills one needs in order to get ahead in life. The absence of such skills is a distinct disadvantage in today's competitive job market.

With the emerging digital world and its driving force in the economic wellbeing of our nation, we must ensure that Australians have the necessary information tools and skills which will be crucial to their participation in the information technology age. In the 21st century, our work force will need to be technology literate. We must not allow anyone to be left behind because we did not give them the opportunity to get the fundamentals right in their early schooling. This government recognises the importance of literacy and numeracy and has done something about it. In March 1997, Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers agreed to a national literacy goal that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level.

The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 gives effect to the national literacy and numeracy plan and the subsequent initiatives announced in the 1999-2000 budget, building on the coalition's commitments to delivering better education for our young people—and I note the gracious acknowledgment of the member for Rankin in respect of his support for this bill, as far as it went. The bill does have a number of provisions, including a $36.3 million increase in the year 2000 under the literacy and numeracy plan to improve literacy and numeracy outcomes for students in not only early but also middle years of schooling.

I have spoken of the necessity to improve literacy and numeracy skills in the crucial early years where there must be a mix of early diagnosis and assessment, appropriate teaching strategies and professional development. In 1998, the government focused on the early years of schooling when it provided $176 million for literacy programs. In the 1999 budget, there was a general increase in funding for the national literacy and numeracy plan, but it went further than that. The funding was extended to support new initiatives targeting students in the middle years of schooling, just beyond the early years, in upper primary and secondary school through to year 10.

Why is this so? It is apparent now that those children who went through their early years of schooling more than three years ago, before this government came to office, did not have the benefit of this government's policies in funding literacy and numeracy programs for early schoolers. Labor did nothing of note in its 13 years in government to address the fact that we had an unacceptably low level of literacy and numeracy standards among our school children. It has only been since 1998 and the advent of the national literacy and numeracy plan that it has been an aim of federal, state and territory ministers for classroom teachers to assess the literacy needs of all children in their first year of school, with the aim of having every child reading and writing properly by the end of primary school.

Having focused to date on the early years of schooling, the government also supported students, through the full service schools program in their final years of schooling, who were at risk of not completing school or who had returned to school as a result of the mutual obligation provisions of the youth allowance. The government is now completing the circle—mutual obligation, of course, being the concept we embrace; reciprocal responsibility being the British Labour leader's description of that same concept that he has embraced.

The new literacy funding provided for by this legislation targets those students who have slipped through the net between the literacy programs for the early years and those directed to the final years. These middle years of schooling are also of critical importance in a child's literacy and numeracy skill development at a time when their rapid physical, emotional and intellectual development is crucial.

The coalition's commitment to lifting literacy and numeracy standards has been adopted in a number of innovative ways, and not just in primary schools. A special school in my electorate of Curtin, the Speech and Hearing Centre for Deaf Children in Wembley, receives some funding under the national literacy plan for educationally disadvantaged children. It is an exceptional institution that works with children with hearing disabilities or hearing impairments and whose oral language or speech development has been retarded compared to their chronological peers. This school assists children with special language or speech needs to acquire skills so that they are able to enter regular school programs.

Under the national literacy plan, a number of schools have shown great initiative in enhancing children's appreciation for language and literature. Another school in my electorate, Mount Hawthorn Junior Primary, introduced a program whereby older members of the community visited the school and told the children stories of their life and experience as they grew up in the area. The children then adapted the stories told to them by these older people and created their own pieces of inventive and imaginative work. This literacy program was designed to nurture their skills in comprehension, expression and language.

This government is committed to raising literacy and numeracy standards to give young people the best possible chance in life. The total funding of almost $680 million over the next four years to 2001-02 is money spent that will have an immense impact on educational opportunities for young Australians in our competitive knowledge-based economy. The funding provision of $36.3 million in this legislation for the year 2000 is an increase to government schools grants in literacy and numeracy from $111.7 million to over $135 million and to non-government schools from $43.2 million to nearly $48.6 million. Grants for national projects to foster literacy and numeracy are to be extended into the program year 2000 with nearly $7.63 million allocated.

It is perhaps a matter of serendipity that we speak on this bill just days before we celebrate National Literacy Week. Next week, Australia will celebrate for the first time National Literacy Week to coincide with International Literacy Day on 8 September. The federal government initiative has been developed in collaboration with state and territory governments and non-government education authorities to celebrate the progress Australian schools are making to improve the literacy and numeracy levels of all students, as well as acknowledge publicly the results that have been achieved. I am confident that National Literacy Week will raise the community awareness of the importance of all students developing effective literacy and numeracy skills.

There is another important aspect to this bill about which I propose to speak—that is, the provision of $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools, the NALSAS strategy, for the year 2000. Just as the government wants to give school students the fundamental skills in literacy and numeracy to give them every possible chance to lead a productive life, we are also committed to giving our students a range of other skills to assist them in their employment opportunities.

To speak another language is a much admired ability. If that other language has the potential to add to one's employment prospects in the short or longer term, it becomes a much sought after ability. The government's funding commitment targets the enhanced and expanded study of Asian languages, specifically Chinese Mandarin, Japanese, Indonesian and Korean. The aim of the government's NALSAS strategy is to ensure 60 per cent of year 10 students and 15 per cent of year 12 students are studying an identified Asian language by 2006. The $90 million allocated in the 1999-2000 budget provided for in this legislation extends the funding over the next three years to 2002.

This far-sighted objective for Australian students recognises that closer engagement with Asia is a foreign and trade policy priority of this government. The study of Asian languages throughout the school system can only improve Australia's capacity and preparedness to interact with our Asian neighbours through their economies, their cultures and their communities. This gives our students greater opportunities when they enter the work force to participate in the global economy.

I am personally aware of the impact a second language, particularly an Asian language, can have on a potential employer. As the managing partner of a large law firm in Perth, I was responsible for employing our solicitors. In that role, I was increasingly aware that there was a need for lawyers to work in areas with an increasing interaction with Asian clients or Asian businesses. Any prospective employee with Asian language skills was at an immediate advantage, for there was an escalating need for our law firm to demonstrate that it had the skills within its work force to do work for or with Asian companies and businesses. I know I speak for many other employers in that regard.

Finally, this legislation provides for the continuation of previous capital funding arrangements for non-government schools to maintain funding at current real values. This is a continuation of our election commitment to provide additional funding to maintain capital grants in current real terms. Further, this legislation provides for contingency funding for struggling non-government schools in the transition to the new system of funding for non-government schools.

In this year's budget, the government introduced some fundamental reforms to the way non-government schools are funded. We have moved away from the old notion that funding is based mostly on the way the schools structured their finances. This only limited the ability of non-government schools to respond to the needs of their communities or to raise additional income.

The socioeconomic status funding approach is more equitable. It is a fairer assessment of the school's needs because it focuses on the school's communities, not the school's accounts. This funding model measures the ability of the school community to support a school, and thus their level of entitlement for federal recurrent funding. No school will be financially disadvantaged. No school will be advantaged over another.

The additional short-term funding provided for in this legislation recognises that, if a school is affected by the changes in arrangements, there is a contingency fund to assist those schools that need support during the restructuring phase. These changed funding arrangements provide educational equity and offer choice. It better allows Australians choice in selecting a school which meets their children's needs. The increased funding has not been provided at the expense of the government schools.

Government schools are of course the domain of the states essentially, but the federal government has added to that pool with an additional $243 million in this year's budget for government schools. There is an extra $1 billion from the Commonwealth over the next four years, which will build on the 25 per cent increase in federal funding for the government sector already provided by the Howard government since 1996. So this legislation increases the capital grants for non-government schools from $74.5 million to $84.6 million for the year 2000 and increases the amount of short-term emergency assistance for the transition phase in the funding model changeover from $614,000 to $2.5 million in the year 2000.

This legislation is another step forward in the implementation of this government's education policy. It is a policy of equity, fairness, opportunity and vision. Labor's education policy? Total disorder. As the member for Werriwa said last October of the Labor election policy on education, `They stuffed it up.' Perhaps not how others would phrase it—

talk.start.para: —You wouldn't use that language, would you?

—I certainly would not, but we do get the picture. This government is working to prepare our young people for the demands and challenges they will face in the years ahead, in a world with a rate of change the likes of which we have not seen before. Tonight I recall the opening line in one of the books I studied, L.P. Hartley's novel, The Go Between , which goes something along the lines, `The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there.' Perhaps a truism we would do well to recall from time to time, but the 21st century is also a foreign country and we must do whatever we can as federal legislators to ensure that our young people have the skills and the opportunities to not only survive but also thrive in their journey through that foreign country—beyond the year 2000. I commend this bill to the House.

—One of the subjects which is never far from a parent's mind is the quality of their children's education. I know from very recent experience just how important this becomes when your children are about to start school. Parents know that the early years can be the most important. Problems that occur with literacy or numeracy in the very first years of schooling will be very hard to correct. When parents are worrying about that, they want to know that governments, both state and federal, share that priority. The only way governments can demonstrate that sense of priority is to ensure by their policies and funding that both government and non-government schools are able to provide the quality education that children need.

speech.para: More than ever before, it will be a good education that will be the key to your child realising his or her full potential. The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 helps by providing a modest amount of funding to the states as specific purpose grants for education in four areas: $36.3 million to fund literacy and numeracy programs for students in the early and middle years of schooling for the 2000 school year; $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy for the 2000 school year; continuation of previous capital funding arrangements for non-government schools; and contingency funding for struggling non-government schools in the transition to the new system of funding non-government schools. The literacy programs funded by the Commonwealth provide grants to schools to foster literacy and numeracy development, targeting educationally disadvantaged students. The additional money provided by this bill will support new initiatives for middle school—that is, upper primary to year 10 students.

The national Asian languages strategy deserves special mention. As a result of it, children in their first year of schooling are learning a language. My five-year-old son who has just started at a local primary school is learning Japanese. That will open up for him and his classmates 12 years from now opportunities which probably would not otherwise have been available to them. The capacity to speak Japanese will certainly improve their job prospects. Some examples are running a cellar door at McLaren Vale catering to Japanese tourists, working as an engineer at the local Mitsubishi engine plant and negotiating trade contracts for Australian products or commodities in Tokyo. Much of the credit for the national Asian languages strategy must go to my colleague the member for Griffith who, in one of his former professional lives as the Director-General of the Queensland Cabinet Office, extracted a commitment to it from the former federal Labor government.

The additional capital funding grants for non-government schools honours a coalition commitment to maintain that funding at the same real value as was provided by the former Labor government in the years 1993 to 1996. The additional funding for short-term emergency assistance for non-government schools will assist those schools which are expected to benefit from the new funding system announced in the 1999-2000 budget but which are having difficulty surviving until it takes effect. But these modest provisions to help fund our children's education should not be looked at in isolation. What needs to be kept in focus is how the Howard government has reduced the capacity of the states to fund education.

At the time the Howard government came to office, Commonwealth grants represented about 13 per cent of total funding on government schools with the balance being met by state governments. About 38 per cent of total support for non-government schools is provided by the Commonwealth with 18 per cent being provided by the states and territories and the remaining 44 per cent from private sources. The Howard government has cut financial assistance grants to the states and territories which has reduced their capacity to fund schools from the resources available to them. In both 1994 and 1995 the federal Labor government had provided the states and territories with a real terms per capita guarantee for financial assistance grants. But when the Howard government took office in 1996 it maintained the real per capita guarantee base but negated it by requiring the states to make a fiscal contribution to the Commonwealth.

That fiscal contribution amounted to $1.5 billion over the first three years of the Howard government. The precise amounts were $619 million in 1996-97, $627 million in 1997-98 and $313 million in 1998-99. The liability for those contributions was allocated amongst the states on an equal per capita basis. That meant that the smaller states, like South Australia, carried a disproportionate burden given their relatively higher cost structures and smaller capacities to raise revenue. The result was a reduced capacity for the states to fund their school systems. The ABS government financial estimates show how much in total the South Australian government was able to spend on primary and secondary education since 1993-94.

In South Australia's case, severe budget pressures predated the cut to financial assistance grants in 1996-97. The last year that Labor was in office at a state level was 1993. Because of Premier Arnold's commitment to education—he was both a former teacher and education minister—he had endeavoured to quarantine funding for schools from the significant cuts that were necessary elsewhere in his budget. Spending on schools from the state's own sources, including financial assistance grants, was $834 million in 1993-94. As soon as the Liberals took office, they cut it, first to $807 million in 1994-95 and then as low as $744 million in 1995-96. South Australia's education system has been struggling ever since.

There was a small increase in 1996-97 to $776 million. Schools got a larger increase to $899 million in 1997-98, which was, of course, a state election year and a year in which the education department got some supplementation from the state government for a pay rise for teachers. Commonwealth grants to South Australia for current school spending over that period rose steadily from $198 million in 1993-94 to $208 million in 1994-95, $218 million in 1995-96, $213 million in 1996-97 and $261 million in 1997-98. However, in the Howard government's first budget in 1996, it made a general cut to direct Commonwealth funding for education by applying an efficiency dividend to Commonwealth own purpose outlays and specific purpose payments. The consequence for the total education budget was a cut of $13 million in 1996-97, $35.2 million in 1997-98, $46.5 million in 1998-99 and $55.4 million in 1999-2000. With this efficiency dividend spread over the whole of the education budget, the implications for school funding are small.

The big issue with specific purpose payments for schools is the shift in funding growth from government to private schools. The 1996 budget papers showed expected growth in funding to government schools of 3.8 per cent in 1996-97, 1.1 per cent in 1997-98, 1.2 per cent in 1998-99 and 0.7 per cent in 1999-2000. By comparison, growth in funding to non-government schools was expected to be much stronger: 6.1 per cent in 1996-97, 6.9 per cent in 1997-98, 6.9 per cent in 1998-99 and 6.3 per cent in 1999-2000. This shift in funding is the result of a combination of factors, including higher average specific purpose payments for children in non-government schools and a growth in the number of parents seeking better educational opportunities for their children through private education.

However, in the 1996 budget the Howard government introduced a more controversial factor—the enrolment benchmark adjustment. The Howard government claims that the cost to state governments of a child in a non-government school is some $3,400 less than the cost of a child in a government school. The enrolment benchmark adjustment uses 1996 as the base year and compares shares of enrolments in the government and non-government sectors for each subsequent year.

Each year, if the comparison with 1996 shows a decline in the percentage of enrolments in government schools, the Commonwealth takes away approximately half the claimed savings to the states. That is around $1,700 per student represented in the percentage change. The calculation is done on a state by state basis. A buffer has been applied in each of the EBA's two years of operation—500 in 1997 and 1,500 in 1998. The Howard government claims that the states achieve significant savings from declines in government school enrolments, but in reality the changes that occur are spread thinly across the state education system and there are no significant changes in teaching or administrative costs.

The enrolment benchmark adjustment has cost South Australia $2.28 in 1997 and $3.1 million in 1998. Nationally the savings to the Commonwealth were $11.9 million in 1997 and $21.1 million in 1998. The EBA cut is a cut in addition to any shift in per capita payments from the Commonwealth as a result of changing enrolment populations. Because the EBA formula is based on the proportion of enrolments rather than raw numbers, government schools can actually increase the absolute number of students they enrol and the state will still be subjected to EBA cuts.

talk.start.para: —And still lose money.

—Yes, they will still lose money, because private school enrolments have increased by more. Fortunately, this has not happened in South Australia. It is also the case that the EBA does not work in reverse. That is, if the proportion of students in government schools grows, no additional EBA funds are provided.

speech.para: There is also a big question mark hanging over the future of Commonwealth funding for the states general purposes including schools and directly for schools. Financial assistance grants will be replaced by the revenue from the GST from 1 July 2000. Initially the GST revenues will not be enough to fund the states' current expenditure and the new responsibilities they will have to assume. The arrangements for distributing GST revenues between the states are yet to be worked out. That means that it is an open question whether the states, particularly the smaller states, will have a large enough revenue base to properly support their education system, in the long term. While there will be a transitional period during which the Commonwealth has guaranteed that the states will not be worse off under the new arrangements, this is far from a long-term guarantee of maintenance of all of their funding. Clause 5(v) of the Intergovernmental Agreement on Commonwealth-State Financial Relations says:

The Commonwealth will continue to provide Specific Purpose Payments to the States and Territories and has no intention of cutting aggregate SPPs as part of the reform process set out in this Agreement, consistent with the objective of State and Territory Governments being financially better off under the new arrangements.

The words `no intention' are very far from a guarantee that SPPs will not be cut. Even if they are maintained in aggregate, they may be cut in real terms or not given growth funding commensurate with growth in demand for the services they are supposed to cover. This is how the Howard government will claw back the growth in state revenues which the GST is expected to provide. Whenever it is necessary to cut Commonwealth expenditure, it will always be easier for a coalition government to cut specific purpose payments to the states for education than it will be to cut the federal government's own programs.

South Australia's school system will be extremely vulnerable to any adverse changes in specific purpose payments or the level of GST revenues. One of the main functions of a federal system is to ensure that there is a fair redistribution of resources amongst the states to fund essential government services like education. Whether or not running a school system is, in the first instance, a role of the states, at the end of the day the federal government shares the responsibility to every child in Australia to see that their school is properly funded.

talk.start.para: —The member for Kingston reminds me of that lost ABC radio program The Could Have Beens . I do not know whether members recall that radio program. It used to be on late at night. It was quite a good program. One of the big features of that program was the regular appearance of `Stan the Statistician'. `Stan the Statistician' could prove anything by way of statistics. For example, he knew how many left-handed Australian batsmen were nightwatchmen in tests where the Australians had lost the toss. He knew important bits of information like that. When that radio program was gone, I lamented the loss of `Stan the Statistician'. At the time the program was running, I thought that `Stan the Statistician' was just an eccentric listener. It turns out that he was in fact the member for Kingston. I am relieved to be here to witness the wit of the member for Kingston and to hear some more of those great statistical high points.
—He was halfway there.
—He was halfway there. I suppose it is a below par performance for a statistician, but it was a pretty good exercise in remembering past glories.

speech.para: The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 amends the States Grants (Primary and Secon dary Education) Assistance Act 1996. It enacts several initiatives from the 1999-2000 budget. I will refer to some of the budget announcements relating to education. For example, the budget increased funding for education of $870 million over the four coming years. This money will support higher standards, increased opportunity and greater choice in education for all Australians and in 1999-2000 represents an increase of $183 million over the previous year. The $11 billion allocated to education includes approximately $5 billion for schooling.

Some of the other highlights included in the budget is funding for indigenous education programs totalling $996 million over the five years to 2004. The government announced strengthened accountability arrangements for particular programs, including literacy and numeracy programs, which are to be simplified and streamlined. In 1999-2000, $354 million is allocated for New Apprenticeships and $1.6 billion for vocational education and training.

There was a provision for the maintenance of funding of about $13 million per year for the continuation of the Jobs Pathway Program to help young people move successfully from schools to work. Some $60 million is to be provided over four years to continue the Job Placement, Education and Training Program. The funding allocated to JPET will allow 40,000 young people to be assisted in that period. Those were the general attributes of the 1999-2000 budget.

We are looking today at a couple of the important specifics announced in that budget. To begin with, I refer to increased funding of $36.3 million for literacy and numeracy in the year 2000. We find in the budget that the government has allocated an additional $131.1 million for 1999-2000 through to 2003-04 for literacy and numeracy programs for school students, making a total of almost $869 million to assist students with special needs in literacy and numeracy in those four years.

There were some important milestones recognised with regard to literacy and numeracy. The increased funding supported two initiatives announced as part of the government's 1998 election commitments. The first is to improve literacy and numeracy in the middle years of schooling, for which $47.1 million has been allocated. The second is funding of $84 million for a national literacy and numeracy plan.

At the time, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs stated that there was a great need for action to deal with the problems of the middle years of school because in many cases those students had missed out on acquiring vital skills in the early years of schooling. As a result, they have difficulties coping with the demands of the school curriculum. Dealing with literacy and numeracy problems does not end in the infant years of schooling. For the people experiencing difficulties with literacy, those problems can worsen dramatically as time goes by and their self-esteem and the problems associated with a lack of basic skill get worse.

Another $26.4 million was allocated to extend the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools program, NALSAS, to the year 2000. That is an allocation dealt with in this bill. That harks back to the budget announcement of additional funding over the next three years of $90 million to continue NALSAS and recognise the important goals that NALSAS is seeking to realise. To highlight some of the achievements of that program, between 1994 and 1997 the number of students studying Japanese increased by over 50,000, the number studying Chinese by 20,000 and the number studying Indonesian by over 100,000. Those are important achievements and we must set about continuing to promote the study of those languages.

Another area dealt with in this bill that reflects the budget announcements is the change to a more appropriate system for funding non-government schools. The budget announcement states that Australia's 2,519 non-government schools will get Commonwealth funding based on a socioeconomic status assessment of the school communities. That comes straight out of the very reliable and reputable ABS data, and it is an important improvement on what has gone before. The new arrangements will give non-govern ment schools drawing enrolments for low income communities a substantial increase in funding. Schools serving the neediest communities at present receive 56 per cent of average government school recurrent costs. Under the new arrangements they will receive 70 per cent. This represents, in 1998 dollars, an estimated increase of $672 per primary student and an estimated increase of $762 per secondary student in schools serving the neediest communities.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —It is a sad irony that, in this International Year of Older Persons, in Tasmania those responsible for caring for the aged in our community hold grave fears for the future of the nursing home sector. Furthermore, their frustration over this government's handling of funding to nursing homes is an indictment of the minister responsible. May I give you an example. Aged Care Tasmania, an association representing nursing homes in my state, tells me it has written to Minister Bishop no fewer than seven times in the past three months expressing its concerns and seeking answers to funding questions. It has had just one reply which, I am told, did absolutely nothing to alleviate its fears.

speech.para: Nursing homes in my electorate and around Tasmania are bracing themselves for harsh funding cuts that they fear will cost jobs and severely impact on the quality of aged care. In Tasmania there are currently more than 4,000 people in nursing homes and the demand for nursing home beds and quality care certainly is not diminishing. In my electorate there are 24 aged care facilities with a combined total of 800 nursing home places. Half of the elderly residents in these nursing homes require a high level of care, yet double the amount of beds would not even go close to meeting the demand. As I have just said, the demand where I come from is not diminishing. Close to 24 per cent of the population is 50 and over, and 10 per cent is 65 years and over. Nursing home operators are only too well aware of the demands an ageing population puts on the system, but the government has responsibility to look after the elderly in our communities.

Aged care providers in Tasmania sum up one of the biggest threats to their industry in one word—coalescence. We have recently seen the second stage of this government's coalescence policy introduced, a policy aimed at equalising Commonwealth funding for aged care providers across Australia; in other words, working towards a national average. While in theory this may seem equitable, in practice it is a looming disaster for Tasmanian nursing homes and their elderly communities. It is recognised that the cost of providing aged care in Tasmania is considerably higher than in other states and territories. We cannot do anything about that—it is the price we continually pay for living where we live—and there is little scope for Tasmanian nursing homes to mitigate their relatively high cost structure. But at least the cost differential was recognised under the previous funding arrangements where sufficient compensation was paid for the higher input costs faced by Tasmanian homes. That is why Tasmania received the highest care subsidies in Australia and therefore stands to be the hardest hit and to suffer most under this policy.

Aged care providers in Tasmania have done their homework. They have done the sums and they do not add up to a fair and responsible funding policy. They have calculated that cuts to nursing homes because of coalescence will see a reduction in Commonwealth subsidies to Tasmania of around eight per cent over the next six years. This will mean the loss of about $6.8 million a year to nursing homes in my state. On average each nursing home resident will receive $2,730 less a year—and it gets worse. It has been estimated that coalescence, once fully implemented, will result in the loss of more than 330 jobs in the aged care industry in Tasmania and will result in redundancy payments of more than $5 million. Not only will basic care standards be jeopardised; coalescence threatens to impinge further on the quality of life of elderly Tasmanians, affecting the little things that now may be taken for granted—things like the regular bus outings for residents of the Eliza Purton Home at Ulverstone. For this home, like many others around Tasmania, it will be a matter of survival. They will be forced to prune costs if they want to survive. Yet this Minister for Aged Care continues to turn a blind eye to the dilemma.

It is claimed by the minister the impact of coalescence in Tasmania will be offset by a 38 per cent increase in aged care funding to Tasmania, yet despite its best efforts through the department and within its own membership the industry cannot find the extra money. In fact, by its own calculations funding from the Commonwealth this year is $20 million short. The industry is concerned someone is attempting to fudge the figures, so I challenge the minister to prove these concerns wrong and I urge Tasmanian Liberal senators to vigorously take up this cause. I join the providers of aged care in Tasmania in their challenge to the minister to implement the findings of this government's own Productivity Commission report into aged care. The Productivity Commission proposed the government identify a benchmark of quality care and then determine how much funding was required to reach that level of care in each state in regions like my own. As Aged Care Tasmania puts it:
We support coalescence rates for the provision of care throughout Australia but we cannot support coalescence rates where money is taken from some and given to others to make it `even'.

This policy of coalescence directly contradicts the overriding policy objectives in aged care of ensuring quality of access and a nationally accepted standard of care to all Australians in need, irrespective of their personal circumstances or where they live.

talk.start.para: —This week in the Sydney Morning Herald it was reported that the Sydney Young Labor Annual Conference unanimously supported a call to the Premier to wind back the prevalence of pokies and the reliance of unscrupulous governments on gambling revenue, now topping $1 billion a year. It is a fact that New South Wales has one-tenth of the world's poker machines and a very high share of this nation's 330,000 gambling addicts. Still we have governments suggesting new forms of gambling to raise revenue. The terrible impact all this has on our fellow Australians is evident in this letter I received last week from a constituent, whose permission I have to use it. It reads:

speech.para: My name is Karen Richardson. I am 39 years old. I have two teenage children, Dale who is 17 and Kirby who is turning 16 the day before Father's day. Kirby won't celebrate her birthday or spend the following day, Father's day, with her Dad. She won't take him breakfast in bed, nor will she choose a gift for him. She will, as will Dale and I, take flowers to his grave, as we did one week ago when he had his 40th birthday.

My husband's name is Gavin and, as well as being a hard-working man who joined the Navy when he was just 15 years of age, loved to play footie and have a beer with his many friends, he was addicted to gambling. At the time of my husband's death, he had accumulated more than $25,000 worth of debts. My husband gassed himself in one of our cars.

We had two cars, a nice home, my husband did a lot of work, we both worked fulltime, our two children are both young people any parents would be proud of. But like most people in the world today, these things just aren't enough, people want more and they think that money will bring them happiness.

Gavin (my Husband) took care of all our finances, so I did not realise until it was too late, that something was not quite right. Fifteen months approximately, that's all it took to hook my husband on the thought that he could beat the poker machine. Of course he hadn't done any research, as we now have, so every pay he took our savings card to a pub or club in our local town and put all of it in the poker machine—over two days of course, because you can only take out $500 at a time, which is what he did.

When that ran out, he was able to get loans from finance companies who ran no credit checks and did their dealing with him over the phone. My signature is on most of these but I knew nothing about them. I did not have to speak to any member of staff from these companies, or say to them, yes, I want this loan and I do understand the details of it.
Gavin did all his banking over the phone. When Gavin couldn't get the money that way, he cashed cheques—
at a local Nowra hotel—
which bounced, but that didn't matter, they cashed them anyway—$13,000 worth! Then he went to unsuspecting friends. Friends that would never dream that Gavin could do what he did.

It was all so easy. Why is it you can put all your money into a poker machine? I've paid taxes and so did my husband, since I was 16 years old and over the last 17 years of our marriage, I have not received any assistance from the Government. Even in the last eight years I have not received family allowance. Was it not enough to take our taxes that you then had to take my husband's life?

Poker machines are designed, as you well know, to take your money. Money that most families cannot afford to spend. Yet you allow these machines to take not only our money, but people's dignity as well, till there is nothing left. You the Government stand by and watch this all happen. You do nothing to stop this degrading practice that ruins families and leaves people broken hearted and grieving for what will never be.

Millions of dollars a year go into building schools, roads and hospitals. Most of this money comes from gambling, but at what cost? At the time of Gavin's death, I was left with not one red cent, every household bill was overdue, school fees were not paid, cheques bounced one after another, finance companies accused me of being a cheat and banks threatened to take away my home. No assistance was available from the Government as I was not eligible. I was just another interruption to their day, as were my children.

As leaders of this country you set the example of take whatever you can get, anyway you can get it. People's lives are not what's important. Money is the most important thing and with the Olympic Games coming up and overspending raging, poker machines and gambling in any form is a great way of getting easy revenue, and never mind the cost. It's only someone's Dad, it was only my Husband. He didn't keep you warm at night, make you feel safe; no, he was just a way to get more money faster.

It is very sad that governments have forgotten the Ten Commandments, because if they had not, the world would be a place where people cared about people. To you, my Gavin is just another statistic. To us, he was our world, and because of your greed that's been taken away. When will enough be enough? When will you consider people first and money next?

I have to budget each week to make ends meet and pay the many outstanding bills that are left to me. I do not blame my husband. I blame a system that made it all so easy. In the end, when the demons of gambling overtook him and he felt he had no way out, he did what he thought was best for all of us—he killed himself!! We all pay in one way or another for this problem. I hope you choose the right way or may God help you.

I sincerely hope that there will be no more Karens, Danes or Kirbys left destitute and alone and without assistance because of the curse called gambling. I thank what is left of the Richardson family for bringing their grief to us. I urge all members to read the recent draft report into Australian gambling industries and to take action.

talk.start.para: —Recently I supported a petition in my seat of Swan which addressed the issue of the proposed deregulation of the pharmaceutical industry. The text of this petition reads as follows:

speech.para: The petition of electors of Swan points out to the House our desire to see community pharmacists retain their unique position in Australia's health system.

We trust and respect our local pharmacists and are opposed to any moves to allow supermarkets to compete against them. We believe that the community benefits from pharmacies being owned by pharmacists.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House heeds our wishes and allows our local pharmacy to continue to play a vital role in our health care.

In only a period of weeks this petition received overwhelming support, with over 2,600 individuals becoming signatories. Currently Australia has a network of 5,000 community pharmacists who provide professional advice and service on over 270 million occasions every year. Independently owned pharmacies provide over 40,000 jobs for pharmacists and pharmacy assistants and the Pharmacy Guild spends $1.5 million a year on a national training scheme.

In Western Australia there are 467 pharmacies and they employ 3,736 pharmacists and staff. These community pharmacies employ local people and provide a personal service to 494,000 customers every week and contribute more than $513.7 million per year to the state economy. In my electorate of Swan there are 40 such pharmacies that employ 213 people. Many of these businesses are located near or about large shopping centres. The average person visits a pharmacy 14 times a year.

Current legislation ensures that pharmacies are owned and operated by a pharmacist who is qualified to dispense medicines and provide quality advice. Pharmacies currently operate in a market where 60 per cent of their business is deregulated, competing with other businesses to provide products such as cosmetics, hair and health products. The remaining regulated 40 per cent of pharmacy business consists of the provision of medications and drugs.

Western Australian pharmacists currently provide Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme medicines at set prices—one of the most internationally admired pharmaceutical subsidisation programs in the world. Under the PBS, Western Australians have access to high quality medicines at costs that are around half the world averages. For example, one of the most widely used medicines for asthma, Ventolin, costs about $30 a unit in the USA but costs only $13 for two units in Western Australia.

It is also of interest to note the equity argument. About 80 per cent of this PBS expenditure is spent on medicines for such people as seniors holding concession cards. It also represents an effective brake on escalating health prices, as the affordability of these medicines improves the quality of life through better control of symptoms and reduced hospitalisation.

Deregulation could lead to higher priced pharmaceuticals, particularly in regional and remote areas. It would also lead to the closure of many smaller pharmacies. The current network of community pharmacies provides quality care and equal access to pharmaceuticals for all customers. However, the general public needs to be made aware of the significant loss they will suffer if the legislation that maintains industry regulation is abolished as a result of the national competition policy.

The proponents of national competition policy argue that market forces should be allowed to operate freely in a truly competitive environment where no participant is given any artificial assistance or protection. But the reality is that pharmacists and their employees provide much more than just a product. Pharmacies provide advice to the community based on which product is best suited to their needs, regardless of price or brand. They stock generic products as well as specialist brands of medicine and provide cost alternatives for customers who cannot afford expensive medicine. Most importantly, they will often forgo a sale and refer to other health professionals when necessary.

This is now under threat, as the government is poised to consider allowing large supermarkets to sell pharmaceuticals. This will inevitably lead to the loss of many community pharmacies and the expertise and valuable advice they provide. There is also considerable evidence that the deregulation of pharmacies overseas has shown that free market forces do not meet everybody's needs and the community bears the financial and social costs. I urge the government not to deregulate this industry any further. I will be supporting the views of my constituents on further occasions if this retrograde step is pursued.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak tonight not as the member for Bradfield so much but as the Chairman of the Sydney Airport Community Forum. Although it is not a job I coveted, it is one to which I was appointed in October last year ostensibly to oversee the implementation of government policy in relation to Sydney airport. Like all the issues that I come across, I always approach them with an open mind, examine the facts, examine the arguments both for and against any particular proposition and try to present, as honestly and as effectively as I can, the facts as they are.

speech.para: The government, prior to the March 1996 election when it was elected to office, developed a policy for air traffic management for Sydney proper called `Putting people first'. That policy had two essential pillars. The first pillar of that policy was to develop, in consultation with the community and the aviation industry including Airservices Australia, a long-term—noise sharing—operating plan for Sydney airport, known as LTOP. The essence of that plan was, as distinct from the north-south concentrated parallel operations under the Laurie Brereton regime from the time of the opening of the third runway, to try to distribute as fairly as possible air traffic throughout Sydney.
The second pillar of the government's policy was to construct a second airport at Badgerys Creek. I will just read from the government's policy:
The Coalition is committed to building a second major airport in the Sydney region.
The Coalition will ensure that Sydney West Airport is developed to a full international standard as a matter of priority, subject to the results of the environmental impact statement.

We will work closely with the New South Wales Government, local authorities and the private sector to ensure the necessary road and rail infrastructure is developed and to ensure that the land around the airport is zoned appropriately.

At the time the Australian Labor Party criticised the coalition parties not because they were committed to building a second airport subject to the EIS but because the coalition was proposing to conduct another EIS. The Labor Party at the time criticised us for not simply proceeding to build the airport on the basis of the 1985 EIS. Well, $12.4 million later, we now have an environmental impact statement and an audit which essentially gives the environmental clearance for the government to implement its policy.

One of the other things that needs to be emphasised is that it was not only a long-term operating plan but also a commitment to maintain continued access of regional planes to Sydney airport, to introduce and implement a cap on the number of hourly movements that would go through Sydney's airport and also to implement a curfew which goes from 2300 to 0600 hours. One of the propositions that has been proposed by some people in the air traffic industry is that regional planes or light planes which occupy 40 per cent of the slots at Kingsford Smith can instead be sent to Bankstown airport.

One thing that seems very reasonable to those of us who do not understand how air traffic is managed at Sydney airport is that `Kingsford Smith airport can be run more efficiently'. Those who say that are quite right. If you want to run north-south parallel operations 24 hours a day with a precision radar monitor to the north of the airport, you can run up to 120 movements an hour. I have spent 18 months of my life fighting with Airservices Australia to get one simple thing—a 2,000-foot turn at the western end of the east-west runway—and after 18 months Airservices Australia have said they cannot do it. The reason they cannot do it is that they would have to re-sectorise Bankstown airspace.

It is a nonsense and a lie for anyone to suggest that you can send 30 movements an hour into Bankstown airport and not have to resort to north-south parallel operations at Kingsford Smith airport. To send 30 movements an hour of instrument rated planes to Bankstown airport means—and make no mistake about this—the closure of the east-west runway. If the government adopted those recommendations it would be breaking not one but two of its policies: one would be to break the commitment to build Badgerys Creek airport which would serve, amongst other things, the economic development of one of the most impoverished parts of Western Sydney and, secondly, it would break the important long-term operating plan which we spent over a year developing in consultation with the Sydney community. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Tullamarine Tollway
Health Services: Victoria

talk.start.para: —I rise in this adjournment debate to highlight the disadvantage that people from central Victoria face because of the policies of both the state and federal Liberal-National Party coalition. I refer in particular to the City Link toll rip-off and the GST, plus the impact of Jeff Kennett on Victoria's health system.

speech.para: The City Link tolls on the Tullamarine Tollway will cost motorists around $150,000 a day. This calculation is based on figures of the projected use of the Tullamarine Tollway as given in City Link's own prospectus. This projects a weekday use on the Tullamarine Tollway by 104,000 cars, 21,000 light commercial vehicles and 7,000 heavy commercial vehicles. Over one year the total payout of tolls on the Tullamarine alone will be around $50 million. The projected figures for weekend use of the Tullamarine Tollway have not been given, but I calculate that the total City Link toll grab over one year will add up to close to that $50 million figure that I mentioned.

Now add in the GST tax grab. The GST will add another $15,000 to the amount paid out per day on the Tullamarine Freeway, and $5 million more for one year. This is a huge financial drain on motorists from central Victoria and others who use the Tullamarine Freeway. The GST raises the cost of a day pass from $7 to $7.70 and a $50 electronic tag to $55. Add to that our region being especially victimised because we are automatically funnelled into the western link toll complex, which is now open. So motorists from the Bendigo region and others who use the Tullamarine Freeway and the western link will be bled with City Link tolls which will increase with the GST.

This situation adds insult to injury. The Tullamarine Freeway is the only country access into the city where City Link tolls are to be imposed. Motorists from central Victoria are the only ones who will be slugged and taxed to drive into their own capital city. Therefore, if you live in Ballarat and drive to Melbourne, you do not pay a toll. If you live in Warrnambool and drive to Melbourne, you pay no toll. If you live in Shepparton and drive to Melbourne, you pay no toll. If you live in Albury-Wodonga and drive to Melbourne, you pay no toll. But, if you live in Bendigo and central Victoria, you pay a toll. So we have to ask ourselves: what has Bendigo and central Victoria done to the Premier of Victoria to warrant this impost?

Transurban, the company that operates the tolls, can increase these tolls every three months for the next 34 years under its agreement with the Melbourne City Link Authority. So central Victorians who travel on the Calder Highway may face an ever-increasing penalty, plus a GST, thanks to Prime Minister Howard and Premier Kennett. This is just one of the many areas of state and federal coalition policies that have impacted so severely in regional Victoria.

I now refer to the 12 small country Victorian hospitals that have closed and the public hospitals in Taralgan and Mildura that have been privatised by Mr Kennett—and, if this were not bad enough, the Premier is on the public record as wanting to scrap Medicare. Premier Kennett put his `scrap Medicare' plans on the national agenda at a Premiers Conference in July when he demanded that Medicare be abolished. The Kennett strategy is to force Victoria and Australia back to the bad old days before Medicare—the days of the two-class health system, when the public hospital system was third rate and run down and when people were forced to have private health insurance or miss out on quality care. That is another area that, as a result of Jeff Kennett's policies, will impact very badly particularly on Bendigo.

Mr Kennett has been the manipulator of the coalition's ADI privatisation agenda ever since he was recorded as pushing it at a public meeting in Eaglehawke in March 1994. Mr Kennett privatised the Bendigo railway workshops some years ago and claimed that its work force would grow to equal that of the Australian Defence Industry's plant in Bendigo. What has really happened is that its work force has been slashed from 262 to 55 under that very policy.

We do not want a disaster like that in Bendigo as a result of the privatisation of ADI. We do not want Jeff Kennett's philosophy imposing on the workers who are employed in that plant and their families. We simply cannot afford it. The region cannot afford it. Mr Kennett should be called to account for it.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Government Policy

talk.start.para: —I continue reading a letter which I received from pork producers in my area, Mr Ross and Vicki Schmidt. It states:

speech.para: You and your government allocated $8 million to provide grants to specialist pig processors. The same processors are importing pork. Therefore, you are actually helping them to become more efficient in their importing. To qualify for these grants, you must have a minimum throughput of 250,000 pigs per year. Again, it is only the big boys who qualify.

Now you have come up with $45,000 in grants for farmers when they have left the pork industry. We do not want to leave. Australia has the best pork in the world. Our safety measures are second to none. Canada and Denmark do not have the same high standards we have. If disease is found in an imported product, it is not going to be imported pork to the consumer, it is just going to be pork, and that will totally destroy our industry completely, even though we are totally innocent.

You say we have to learn to export, but who is going to take our 30 pigs a week? We could expand but there is no bank who will provide finance for such a venture. There is no bank who will give us one more cent.

Mr Minister, would you work 14 to 16 hours a day, seven days a week, if your profit was non-existent when in fact you are actually going backwards? All we want to do is work our farm. Many, many others produce excellent quality pork but still we cannot survive. We do not know what more we can do.

When are you going to introduce tariffs? When are you going to look after your own country? Why do you need to look so good in the eyes of other countries? Doesn't Australia come first? We are the ones that pay your wages, we are the ones you are working for, not some other country. The rural industry in Australia is dying and you are directly responsible for this death.

You must decrease the imports today, not spend another six months discussing it hoping it will go away. The only thing that will go away is the number of successful farmers. How many more farmers have to shoot themselves before you will do something? We need something done now, today. Tomorrow will be too late.

Certainly a cry from the heart. Similarly, I will read another letter out. These letters tumble into our office almost on a daily basis and, wherever I go in my electorate, I confront the same sort of feeling—as I do in other parts of Australia. But, in reading this letter out, I will skip over the first paragraph which refers to me. It states:
When this legislation goes ahead—
this is a letter to me—
it is estimated by the Queensland Hotels Association that over half of the hotels in Queensland will close down or become financially unviable.
This refers to a proposal by the Queensland government, which is being addressed at the present moment, to allow alcohol to be sold by the big retail chains. The letter continues:

My family has been involved in the hospitality industry for over 30 years. Currently three of us hold licences in Roma, Charters Towers and Rollingstone. From our experience, we can see it is inevitable that our businesses in country Queensland will not survive this latest attempt by the government to bow to the power and influence of multinational companies.

In Charters Towers alone, it is a fair estimate that six hotels will no longer be viable if Woolworths is permitted to sell takeaway liquor. These six hotels employ 24 people. My business employs 12, eight of whom are under 20 years of age. My business sponsors local sporting and charity groups to the tune of $14,000 per year. All of my business is conducted locally and, if we close, approximately $300,000 worth of revenues will also evaporate. Obviously Woolworths will not be employing any of the staff who will lose their jobs, should these changes be allowed to go ahead.

From a justice point of view, is it fair that we pay $80,000 each year to the government to keep my licence when now it appears that more licences are to be given free of charge to bigger companies? Three years ago I left the education system, seven years a school principal, to borrow heavily into a business, believing that no more licences would be given out in this town. Our future is not secure now the minister is considering changing the rules. Why? To please larger companies who have greater influence on him.

What interest does Woolworths have in our community? How much does Woolworths contribute in cash or services to our community? What does the National Competition Policy do for consumers in our community? Does the minister think the nine existing licences do not compete for sales and therefore the good of consumers?

Our business contributes over $1 million to the government each year in taxes. We are revenue earners and taxpayers. I am prepared to bet that, when this revenue is lost to the government, Woolworths contribution will fall well short, GST or no GST.

Have they bothered to do their figures on this issue? This decision is yet another nail in the coffin of rural Queensland. Once again it is apparent that life away from the coast is inconsequential. Be careful, Bob. In a few years you will have no communities to represent.

That is rather an interesting observation because more and more my electorate is becoming the suburbs of Townsville and Cairns. What the writer of this letter has said is absolutely true. I now read from the letter to the minister himself. It states:
I know you are probably busy dining with the economic rationalists or board members of Woolworths and Coles and therefore have no time to reply to my letters.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 8 p.m. the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: The following notices were given:
Dr Theophanous to move—
That this House:

(1) expresses its concern regarding the aims and content of Migration Series Instruments (MSI) 244, which permits the transfer of asylum seekers from Migration Detention Centres to State prisons, where they are then held without charges or court proceedings;
(2) recognises that the actions permitted under MSI-244 constitute an arbitrary executive imprisonment of people, of the kind which Australia has condemned when it occurs in other countries;

(3) recognises the concerns expressed by the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Amnesty International, the Refugee Council of Australia, the Human Rights Commissioner and others, concerning the arbitrary powers of imprisonment given to immigration officers and detention centre officials under MSI-244;

(4) notes that MSI-244 itself states that "there is no clear statutory basis for the selective transfer of detainees" to a State prison, and that this specific provision has never been approved by Parliament; and

(5) calls upon the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to immediately withdraw MSI-244 and draft a new MSI, that only allows transfers of refugees claimants to State prison in circumstances when they are being charged with an offence under a State or Commonwealth law, other than breach of migration visa laws).
Ms Hall to move—
That this House:
(1) notes the progress that has been made by the States in moving towards truth in labelling for the egg industry;
(2) requests the Commonwealth to show leadership and further facilitate all the States adopting national labelling standards; and
(3) supports the phasing out of the practice of intense battery hen and egg farming.
Mr Williams to present a bill for an act to amend the Copyright Act 1968, and for related purposes.
Mr Williams to present a bill for an act to amend the law relating to telecommunications interception, and for related purposes.
Mr Anthony to present a bill for an act to amend the law relating to social security, and for related purposes.
Mr Slipper to move—

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of 90 apartments in Darwin.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I raise the issue of migration agency regulation. On the ABC's 7.30 Report of 25 August 1999, Mr Kerry O'Brien said:

speech.para: Thousands of hopeful migrants have had their futures cast into doubt following the closure of Australia's biggest immigration law firm. Barlow & Company—which had offices in Sydney and Melbourne has suddenly closed its doors after 20 years; its principal lawyer, Neil Barlow, declaring himself bankrupt. Of the firm's 3,000 clients, many stand to lose thousands of dollars in up-front fees.
Reporter Jacinta Tynan noted:

Just days before, staff at Barlow & Company were telling clients they would be closing for an inventory and back in business this week, in fact the firms's principal, Neil Barlow, had already filed for personal bankruptcy, the day after he deregistered himself as a migration agent.
Clients were told nothing. Dr Charles Sinclair, a former employee, said in the report:

A notice was put up saying that an inventory was being carried out. I don't know how you carry out an inventory in a law office. But the switchboard was also told that no calls were to be put through to us and that they could call back on 20 August, by which time, of course, we had all departed.

The 7.30 Report notes Dr Sinclair worked as a migration agent at Barlow and Company for the past 15 months. Dr Sinclair became concerned about the firm's business practices. Clients were made to pay up front on the promise of a refund if the case was unsuccessful. Charles Sinclair believes those funds were being withdrawn before the work was complete. The 7.30 Report interviewed Mr Ray Brown of the Migration Agents Regulation Authority, MARA, who said:
I can't say he was under investigation but there were complaints that were before us and we were looking into those complaints.
MARA has limited powers to investigate agents or audit their books. Since Neil Barlow deregistered himself as an agent, he is no longer accountable to the authority. Dr Sinclair further notes:

I think that the clients have really been short-changed. They have paid monies to have a contract executed. They have paid for a whole lot of work which will never be done and I feel very sorry for these clients because they have no redress at all now.

The immigration department says that because of the `human impact' of the collapse of Barlow and Company it will grant special concessions to the firm's former clients by extending the deadlines for processing visas. But under present law there is little that can be done to prevent this happening again. Just two weeks ago Neil Barlow was advertising in the ethnic press, trading on his expertise as a lawyer, to attract clients.

My electorate of Lowe is one of the most culturally diverse electorates in Australia. The vast majority of my constituency work is immigration work, resulting many times from constituents who have lost confidence in the legal system. I agree with Dr Sinclair's following comments:

I think the Law Society has an utter hide, the way they have carried on in this case. They have a responsibility to clients. They have a responsibility to solicitors. There is no doubt at all in my mind that Mr Barlow was a solicitor.
The Law Society is under a duty to all clients and society as a whole in this matter. I note Mr Bitel's comments:

I'm amazed that . . . the Law Society won't speak to the 7.30 Report . I would have thought that whenever a firm goes under—and they do from time to time—the Law Society's public relations department should at least come on line and assure the community that the Law Society is in control.

I urge the minister for immigration to conduct an inquiry into this matter, especially the conduct of the New South Wales Law Society because the Law Society refuses to intervene in assisting those displaced clients and restore confidence in the legal profession. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On the weekend of 27 to 29 August, the Frankston community joined in the 75th anniversary celebration of Frankston High School. It was quite an experience for all involved, particularly as we look back over the history of Frankston High School, from its very early beginnings in the Masonic Hall in Young Street with 64 pupils, to the 1,500 students who gain a first-class education from Frankston High School, and the transition from ink wells to laptop computers, from simple woodwork models to a school that now constructs its own aeroplanes. A lot has happened at Frankston High School and there were plenty of good reasons for the celebration over the weekend.

speech.para: What I found most striking was the deep affection all those involved in the celebrations had for the school. The guest list read like a Who's Who of people that have come out of the Frankston community and made a very significant contribution to the nation more generally.

Debbie Flintoff-King was there, and was delighted to have the sporting centre that has recently been completed at Frankston High School named in her honour. Also there were Graeme Horsburgh, Mary Evans and Heather Murray. Mary and Heather did terrific work in bringing together a history of the high school called Optima Semper, which means `The best always' for those who have not done their Latin. It was a great occasion for all concerned.

What I enjoyed most of all was seeing the interchange between Harry Carter, an ex-principal, and Stephen Fyfe, a year 7 student, as they compared the experiences of their different times at Frankston High School. A lot of other first-class young people at Frankston High School were involved in the celebrations. Michael Caridakis, Ricky Taylor and Amey Lee talked about what Frankston High School meant to them. Associate Professor Anne Stonehouse, who is the school council president, also emphasised that the academic and sporting excellence that Frankston High School embodies is something they will continue to work to.

The school has a terrific academic record. In 1998, the VCE pass rate was 99.3, with the highest university ranking at 99.55, and 83 per cent of students going on to tertiary education. The school has a strong music program; a laptop computer program, which is well recognised as a leading application of that technology in government schools; and a big international program where students travel to sister schools in Japan, France, and Soweto in South Africa.

The school ventured into a new initiative in 1998 with the year 9 students studying aviation theory. This year that is going to the next step. The students are starting to build a two-seater Jabiru aeroplane for next year as well as obtaining a pilot's licence as part of their studies. There is a great deal of extracurricular activity. It is a first-class educational institution. Principal Ken Rowe, the school council and all those that have been involved in Frankston High School's development over the last 75 years deserve to be congratulated for their contribution to the Dunkley community.
